Subsubsection Text: We are making this offering in reliance on an exemption from registration under the Securities Act for offers and sales of securities that do not involve a public offering. The Notes may not be offered or sold except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the Securities Act and any applicable state securities laws. Laws in certain jurisdictions may restrict the distribution of this offering memorandum and the offer and sale of the Notes. Persons into whose possession this offering memorandum or any of the Notes are delivered must inform themselves about, and observe, those restrictions. You must comply with all applicable laws and regulations in force in any applicable jurisdiction, and you must obtain any consent, approval or permission required for the purchase, offer or sale by you of the Notes under the laws and regulations in force in the jurisdiction to which you are subject or in which you make such purchase, offer or sale, and neither we nor the initial purchasers will have any responsibility therefor. By purchasing the Notes, you will be deemed to have made acknowledgments, representations, warranties and agreements as set forth under “Transfer Restrictions” in this offering memorandum. We are not, and the initial purchasers are not, making an offer to sell the Notes in any jurisdiction except where an offer or sale is permitted. You should understand that you will be required to bear the financial risks of your investment for an indefinite period of time. This offering memorandum summarizes documents and other information in a manner we believe to be accurate, but we refer you to the actual documents for a more complete understanding of the information we discuss in this offering memorandum. In making an investment decision, you must rely on your own examination of such documents, our business and the terms of the offering and the Notes, including the merits and risks involved. The initial purchasers make no representation or warranty, express or implied, as to the accuracy or completeness of the information set forth in this offering memorandum, and nothing contained in this offering memorandum is, nor should you rely upon it as, a promise or representation, whether as to the past or the future. The initial purchasers are acting exclusively for the Issuer and no one else in connection with the offering contemplated by this offering memorandum. They will not regard any other person (whether or not a recipient of this offering memorandum) as their client in relation to the offering of securities contemplated by this offering memorandum and will not be responsible to anyone for providing the protections afforded to a client nor for giving advice in relation to the offering or any transaction or arrangement referred to herein. This offering memorandum is being provided on a confidential basis (1) to persons reasonably believed to be “qualified institutional buyers” as defined in Rule 144A under the Securities Act for informational use solely in connection with their consideration of the purchase of the Notes and (2) in offshore transactions outside the United States complying with Rule 903 or Rule 904 of Regulation S under the Securities Act. Its use for any other purpose is not authorized. This offering memorandum may not be copied or reproduced in whole or in part, and it may only be distributed and disclosed to the prospective investors to whom it is provided by us or by the initial purchasers. The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the European Economic Area (the “EEA”). For these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of Directive 2014/65/EU (as amended, “MiFID II”); or (ii) a customer within the meaning of Directive (EU) 2016/97 (as amended, the “Insurance Distribution Directive”), where that customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II. Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) 1286/2014 (as amended, the “PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the EEA has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful. This offering memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of Notes in any member state of the EEA will be made pursuant to an exemption under Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 (as amended, the “Prospectus Regulation”) from the requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of Notes. This offering memorandum is not a prospectus for the purposes of the Prospectus Regulation. ii ----- Solely for the purposes of the product approval process of each initial purchaser that considers itself a manufacturer pursuant to MiFID II, the target market assessment in respect of the Notes described in this offering memorandum has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for such Notes is eligible counterparties and professional clients only, each as defined in MiFID II; and (ii) all channels for distribution of such Notes to such persons are appropriate. Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending such Notes (a “distributor”) should take into consideration the manufacturers’ target market assessment; however, a distributor subject to MiFID II is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by either adopting or refining the manufacturers’ target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels. The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the United Kingdom (the “UK”). For these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (8) of Article 2 of Regulation (EU) 2017/565 as it forms part of UK domestic law by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 (as amended, the “EUWA”), and as amended; or (ii) a customer within the meaning of the provisions of the UK Financial Services and Markets Act 2000, as amended (the “FSMA”) and any rules or regulations made under the FSMA to implement Directive (EU) 2016/97, where that customer would not qualify as a professional client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2(1) of Regulation (EU) 600/2014 as it forms part of UK domestic law by virtue of the EUWA and as amended (“UK MiFIR”). Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) 1286/2014 as it forms part of UK domestic law by virtue of the EUWA and as amended (the “UK PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the United Kingdom has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the United Kingdom may be unlawful. This offering memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of Notes in the United Kingdom will be made pursuant to an exemption under Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 as it forms part of UK domestic law by virtue of the EUWA and as amended (the “UK Prospectus Regulation”) and the FSMA from the requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of the Notes. This offering memorandum is not a prospectus for the purposes of the UK Prospectus Regulation. Solely for the purposes of the product approval process of each initial purchaser that considers itself a manufacturer pursuant to the FCA Handbook Product Intervention and Product Governance Sourcebook (the “UK MiFIR Product Governance Rules”), the target market assessment in respect of the Notes has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is only eligible counterparties, as defined in the FCA Handbook Conduct of Business Sourcebook, and professional clients, as defined in UK MiFIR; and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to eligible counterparties and professional clients are appropriate. Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending the Notes (a “distributor”) should take into consideration the manufacturers’ target market assessment; however, a distributor subject to the UK MiFIR Product Governance Rules is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by either adopting or refining the manufacturers’ target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels. The above selling restrictions are in addition to any other selling restrictions set out in this offering memorandum. By accepting delivery of this offering memorandum, you acknowledge that (1) you have been afforded an opportunity to request and to review all additional information considered by you to be necessary to verify the accuracy of, or to supplement, the information contained in this offering memorandum, (2) you have not relied on the initial purchasers or any person affiliated with the initial purchasers in connection with the investigation of the accuracy of such information or your investment decision, (3) this offering memorandum relates to an offering that is exempt from registration under the Securities Act, and (4) no person has been authorized to give information or to make any representations concerning us, this offering or the Notes described in this offering memorandum, other than as contained in this offering memorandum, and in information given by our duly authorized officers and employees in connection with an investor’s examination of us and the terms of the offering of the Notes. We and the initial purchasers make no representation to you that the Notes are a legal investment for you. You should not consider any information included in this offering memorandum to be legal, business or tax advice. You should consult your own attorney, business advisor and tax advisor for legal, business and tax advice regarding an investment in the Notes. Neither the delivery of this offering memorandum nor any sale made pursuant to this offering memorandum implies that any information set forth in this offering memorandum is correct as of any date after the date of this offering memorandum. iii ----- You should contact the initial purchasers with any questions about this offering or if you require additional information to verify the information contained in this offering memorandum. We reserve the right to withdraw this offering of the Notes at any time. We and the initial purchasers also reserve the right to reject any offer to purchase the Notes in whole or in part for any reason, to sell less than the entire principal amount of the Notes offered in this offering memorandum and to allot to any prospective investor less than the full amount of Notes sought by such investor. We are making this offering of the Notes subject to the terms described in this offering memorandum and the Indenture, as applicable. Each series of Notes will be available in book-entry form only. We expect that each series of Notes sold pursuant to this offering memorandum will be issued in the form of one or more global certificates. The global certificates will be deposited with a common depositary and registered in the name of the nominee of the common depositary for the accounts of, with respect to the Euro Notes, Euroclear and Clearstream and, with respect to the Dollar Notes, DTC. Beneficial interests in the global certificates will be shown on, and transfers of the global certificates will be effected only through, records maintained by DTC, Euroclear and Clearstream and its direct and indirect participants. After the initial issuance of the global certificates, Notes in certificated form will be issued in exchange for the global certificates only as set forth in the Indenture. See “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form.” We do not intend to apply for listing of the Dollar Notes on any securities exchange or for inclusion of the Notes in any automated dealer quotation system. We intend to apply to list the Euro Notes on the Exchange after the issue date of the Euro Notes. There can be no assurance that the application to list the Euro Notes on the Exchange will be approved and settlement of the Euro Notes is not conditioned on the Issuer making an application or obtaining such listing or admission to trading. Neither the admission of the Euro Notes to be listed on the Exchange, nor the approval of this offering memorandum pursuant to the listing requirements of the Authority shall constitute a warranty or representation by the Authority as to the competence of the service providers to, or any other party connected with, the Issuer, the adequacy of information contained in this offering memorandum or the suitability of the Issuer for investment or any other purposes. In connection with this offering, the initial purchasers may, but are not required to, effect transactions that stabilize or maintain the market price of each series of Notes at a higher level than such series of Notes might otherwise achieve in the open market. Such stabilizing, if commenced, may be discontinued at any time. For a description of these activities, see the section entitled “Plan of Distribution” in this offering memorandum. This offering memorandum is strictly confidential and has been prepared by us solely for use in connection with the proposed offering of the Notes described in this offering memorandum. This offering memorandum is personal to each offeree and does not constitute an offer to any other person or the public generally to subscribe for or otherwise acquire the Notes. Distribution of this offering memorandum to any person other than the offeree and those persons, if any, retained to advise such offeree with respect to this offering memorandum is unauthorized and any disclosure of any of its contents without our prior written consent is prohibited. By accepting delivery of this offering memorandum, you agree to the foregoing and not to make any photocopies, in whole or in part, of this offering memorandum or any documents delivered in connection with this offering memorandum. This offering memorandum, as well as any other documents related to this offering, will not be reviewed or approved by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the “SEC”). The Notes and related guarantees described in this offering memorandum have not been registered with, recommended by or approved by the SEC or any other federal, state or foreign securities commission or regulatory authority, nor has the SEC or any such federal, state or foreign securities commission or regulatory authority passed upon the accuracy or adequacy of this offering memorandum. Any representation to the contrary is a criminal offense. There are no registration rights associated with the Notes, and we have no intention to offer Notes registered under the Securities Act in exchange for the Notes offered in this offering or to file a registration statement with respect to the Notes. The Indenture will not be qualified under the Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended (the “Trust Indenture Act”). iv -----

This offering memorandum includes statements that express our opinions, expectations, beliefs, plans, objectives, assumptions or projections regarding future events or future results and therefore are, or may be deemed to be, “forward-looking statements.” These forward-looking statements can generally be identified by the use of forward-looking terminology, including the terms “believes,” “estimates,” “anticipates,” “expects,” “seeks,” “projects,” “intends,” “plans,” “may,” “will,” or “should” or, in each case, their negative or other variations or comparable terminology. These forward-looking statements include all matters that are not historical facts. They appear in a number of places throughout this offering memorandum and include statements regarding our intentions, beliefs or current expectations concerning, among other things, our results of operations, financial condition, liquidity, prospects, growth, strategies, position in the market and the industry in which we operate. Statements contained in this offering memorandum that are not purely historical are forward-looking statements and may include, but are not limited to, management’s expectations of competition; market share; revenues, margin, expenses and other operating results and ratios; economic conditions; vendor terms and conditions; pricing strategies; customer terms and conditions; organizational changes and related restructuring, integration and other reorganization costs; additional cost reduction measures and related restructuring costs; process and efficiency enhancements; our ability to take advantage of market trends; our international expansion; macroeconomic conditions; cost-savings; cash flows; working capital levels and days; capital expenditures; liquidity; capital requirements; effective tax rates; acquisitions and integration costs and the benefits to our business; operating models; exchange rate fluctuations and related currency gains or losses; resolution of contingencies; our competitive advantages; seasonality; interest rates and expenses; and rates of return, as well as other statements regarding our future operations, financial condition and prospects, and business strategy. By their nature, forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties because they relate to events and depend on circumstances that may or may not occur in the future. We believe that these risks and uncertainties include, but are not limited to, those described in the “Risk Factors” section of this offering memorandum. Those factors should not be construed as exhaustive and should be read with the other cautionary statements in this offering memorandum. Among the risks and uncertainties that may significantly impact us are, without limitation, risks associated with: - failure to develop and market new products and optimally manage product life cycles; - failure to appropriately manage process safety and product stewardship issues; - changes in tax, environmental and other laws and regulations or political conditions in the countries in which we operate; - conditions in the global economy and global capital markets, including economic factors, such as inflation, deflation and fluctuations in currency exchange rates, interest rates and commodity prices, as well as regulatory requirements; - protectionist measures, including tariffs and other barriers to trade; - fluctuations in our industry that could adversely affect our end market customers; - impact of business disruptions, including supply chain disruptions, and security threats, regardless of cause, including acts of sabotage, cyber-attacks, terrorism or war, weather events and natural disasters; - inability to protect and enforce our intellectual property rights; - successful integration of acquired businesses; - liquidity of Ashland (as defined herein) from which we have significant indemnification assets; - fluctuations in interest (SOFR, LIBOR, EURIBOR or other applicable reference rates) rates which may affect service costs on our external debt; v ----- - acquisitions and divestitures of our competitors; - our ability to successfully consummate the Acquisition; - the incurrence of substantial transaction-related costs in connection with the Transactions; - a resurgence of the COVID-19 pandemic or the widespread outbreak of an illness or any other communicable diseases, or other public health crisis; - the impact of sanctions or other actions taken by the United States or other countries, and retaliatory measures taken by Russia in response, or, in connection with, the war in Ukraine; - systemic bank failures and the impact on markets, liquidity and economic conditions; - energy and raw material pricing, availability and allocation by suppliers as well as related costs; - the competition our products and services face and our ability to adapt to industry and market changes; - the consolidation of customers; - current and potential litigation involving us; - malfunction or intentional hacking of our technological systems; - compliance with privacy laws and adequate protection of personal data; - our ability to retain and attract qualified employees and key personnel; - our financing efforts; - our ownership structure, including Parent not controlling the acquired business until completion of the Acquisition; - the successful, long-term implementation of optimizations from the Legacy Acquisitions (as defined herein) and the Acquisition and the continued effect of the Legacy Acquisitions and the pendency of the Acquisition, including on our ability to retain key personnel and on our business relationships, operating results and business generally; and - the outcome of any legal proceedings that have been or may be instituted related to the Acquisition. Although we base these forward-looking statements on assumptions that we believe are reasonable when made, we caution you that forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and that our actual results of operations, financial condition, liquidity, prospects, growth, strategies, position in the market and the development of the industry in which we operate may differ materially from those described in or suggested by the forward-looking statements contained in this offering memorandum. In addition, even if our results of operations, financial condition, liquidity, prospects, growth, strategies, position in the market and the development of the industry in which we operate are consistent with the forward-looking statements contained in this offering memorandum, those results or developments may not be indicative of results or developments in subsequent periods. Given these risks and uncertainties, you are cautioned not to place undue reliance on these forward-looking statements. Any forward-looking statements that we make in this offering memorandum speak only as of the date of those statements, and we undertake no obligation to update those statements or to publicly announce the results of any revisions to any of those statements to reflect future events or developments. Comparisons of results for current and any prior periods are not intended to express any future trends or indications of future performance, unless expressed as such, and should only be viewed as historical data. vi -----

To supplement our financial information presented in accordance with U.S. GAAP, we use the following non-GAAP financial measures to clarify and enhance an understanding of past performance: EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies), Segment profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing cash flows. We believe that the presentation of these financial measures enhances an investor’s understanding of our financial performance. We further believe that these financial measures are useful financial metrics to assess our operating performance from period-to-period by excluding certain items that we believe are not representative of our core business. We use certain of these financial measures for business planning purposes and in measuring our performance relative to that of our competitors. We utilize Segment profit as the primary measure of our segment specific performance. The following terms have the following meanings: - “Adjusted EBITDA” means EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to (i) for Solenis, the impact of non-recurring charges, non-cash purchase accounting adjustments related to the Legacy Acquisitions and the Sigura Contribution, non-service costs for pensions and other non-operational items, one-time consulting and transaction costs related to the Acquisition, management fees paid to Sponsor, realized and unrealized foreign exchange gains/losses, as well as other non-recurring and unusual costs and, (ii) for Diversey, the impact of non-recurring charges, non-cash purchase accounting adjustments, nonservice costs for pensions and other non-operational items, one-time consulting and transaction costs related to the Acquisition, realized and unrealized foreign exchange gains/losses, tax adjustments not related to income tax, factoring and securitization fees, COVID-19 inventory charges, as well as other non-recurring and unusual costs. - “Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega)” means Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to, with respect to Solenis the impact of incentive compensation at 1.0x of the applicable targets, the pre-close EBITDA of Clearon and the unaudited pro forma impact for certain estimated run-rate annual cost synergies from actions (i) that were taken within 18 months of the closing of the Solenis Acquisition and (ii) that were taken or are expected to be taken within 24 months of the closing of the Clearon Acquisition and, with respect to Diversey, expected savings from Project Mega. - “Adjusted net operating cash flows” and “Adjusted net investing cash flows” means, for Solenis, reported net cash (used in) provided by operating activities and net cash provided by (used in) investing activities, each adjusted for the effects of cash subsequently received as part of our Accounts Receivable Facility (as defined herein). - “EBITDA” means net income (loss) before interest expense, income taxes, depreciation and amortization (including amortization of pre-publication investment cash costs). - “Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA” means Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to the Transactions. - “Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and _Project Mega)” means Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and_ Project Mega) further adjusted to give effect to the Transactions. - “Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies)” means Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to the unaudited pro forma combined impact for certain estimated run-rate annual cost synergies from actions expected to be taken within 24 months of the closing of the Transactions. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition and the Legacy Acquisitions—We may not achieve some or all of the expected benefits from the items reflected in the adjustments included in Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted vii ----- EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies).” - “Pro Forma Combined EBITDA” means EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to the Transactions. - “Segment profit” means, for Solenis, EBITDA adjusted for (i) non-operating income or expense, (ii) the impact of certain non-cash, non-recurring or other items that are included in net (loss) and EBITDA that we do not consider indicative of our ongoing operating performance and (iii) certain unusual or non-recurring items impacting results in a particular period. We believe the EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies), Segment profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing cash flows measures are commonly used by investors to evaluate our performance and that of our competitors. However, our use of the terms EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies), Segment profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing cash flows may vary from that of other competitors in our industry. These financial measures should not be considered alternatives to income before income taxes, net (loss), or any other performance measures derived in accordance with U.S. GAAP as measures of operating performance and liquidity. See “Summary—Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Parent—Non-GAAP Financial Metrics—Reconciliation of Net income (loss) to EBITDA and Segment Profit.” With respect to Adjusted net operating cash flows and Adjusted net investing cash flows, Accounting Standards Update (“ASU”) 2016-15 requires us to evaluate the transfer of title of receivables sold under our Accounts Receivable Facility against cash received on previously-sold receivables in exchange for the transfer of title. Since there is a dichotomy between when we legally transfer title of receivables to ING Luxembourg S.A. or, in prior periods, MUFG Bank, Ltd. under the receivables purchasing agreements and when the cash is received on previously-sold receivables, receivables are deemed transferred in exchange for a beneficial interest in the collection of that receivable. This is considered a non-cash investing activity. Furthermore, ultimate receipts of cash, when settled with ING Luxembourg S.A. or, in prior periods, MUFG Bank, Ltd., are considered cash flows from investing activities, as the receipt is considered a return of capital on the beneficial interest. We believe that this may cause net cash (used in) provided by operating activities and net cash provided by (used in) investing activities to be potentially misleading to investors. While we do not retain legal ownership of the receivables sold, the nature, timing, and extent of cash flows have not materially changed as a result of the agreement. We use these non-GAAP metrics to assess our own liquidity. We believe these non-GAAP metrics supplement the user’s evaluation of our cash flows and liquidity. The adjustments reflected in our Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies) have not been prepared with a view towards complying with Article 11 of Regulation S-X. Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies) are intended to provide additional information on a more comparable basis than would be if provided without such adjustments because they account for initiatives related to back office, sales and support staff optimization, warehouse and temporary labor efficiency and technology, among others. The non-GAAP measures noted above are the primary indicators that we use internally to conduct and measure our business and evaluate the performance of our consolidated operations. We believe these non-GAAP financial measures are useful because they provide meaningful comparisons to prior periods. These non-GAAP financial measures are used in addition to and in conjunction with results presented in accordance with viii ----- GAAP. These non-GAAP financial measures reflect an additional way of viewing aspects of our operations that, when viewed with our GAAP results and the accompanying reconciliations to corresponding GAAP financial measures, provide a more complete understanding of factors and trends affecting our business. A material limitation associated with these non-GAAP measures as compared to the GAAP measures is that they may not be comparable to other companies with similarly titled measures that present related measures differently. The non-GAAP measures should be considered as a supplement to, and not as a substitute for or superior to, the corresponding measures calculated in accordance with GAAP. The Indenture governing the Notes, the Existing Indentures and the Credit Agreements include definitions of EBITDA-based metrics that are different from the definition of EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies) used herein. EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies) should be considered in addition to, not as a substitute for, or superior to, measures of financial performance prepared in accordance with GAAP. You are encouraged to evaluate each adjustment and the reasons we consider them appropriate for supplemental analysis. In evaluating EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies), you should be aware that in the future we may incur expenses similar to the adjustments in this presentation. Our presentation of EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies) should not be construed as an inference that our future results will be unaffected by unusual or non-recurring items. The non-GAAP metrics do not necessarily indicate whether cash flow will be sufficient or available to meet our cash requirements and may not be indicative of our historical operating results, nor are such measures meant to be predictive of our future results. Our non-GAAP metrics have limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in isolation. Some of these limitations are: - they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments; - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs; - they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary, to service interest or principal payments on our debts; - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often need to be replaced in the future and EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies) do not reflect any cash requirements that would be required for such replacements; - some of the exceptional items that we eliminate in calculating EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted ix ----- EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies) reflect cash payments that were made, or will be made in the future; and - other companies in our industry may calculate EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies), Segment profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, or Adjusted net investing cash flows differently than we do, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures. We compensate for these limitations by using EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies), Segment profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing cash flows along with other comparative tools, together with U.S. GAAP measurements, to assist in the evaluation of operating performance and liquidity. Such U.S. GAAP measurements include income before income taxes, and net (loss) amongst other performance metrics. In evaluating these financial measures, one should be aware that in the future we may incur expenses similar to those eliminated in this presentation. Our presentation of such measures should not be construed as an inference that our future results will be unaffected by unusual or non-recurring items. We may incur expenses similar to the adjustments noted herein to calculate Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies). However, the magnitude of such adjustments for the periods noted below is not necessarily indicative of the magnitude of such adjustments in future periods. See “Summary—Summary Historical Financial and Pro Forma Financial Data” for a reconciliation of these measures to our directly comparable GAAP measures. Because the leverage ratios presented in this offering memorandum are based, in part, on Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies), these measures are similarly impacted by the limitations referenced above and also should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for GAAP measures. x -----

Throughout this offering memorandum, we refer to our market position or market share in various markets or regions. These references represent our best estimates of our market position or market share at the time of this offering memorandum and are based on management’s knowledge of the industry and/or the market data and other statistical information obtained from independent industry publications, reports by market research firms or other published sources, as further specified below. Certain market and industry data included in this offering memorandum, including the size of certain markets, are based on estimates or beliefs of our management. These estimates or beliefs have been derived from or based on our management’s knowledge and experience in the markets in which we operate, as well as information obtained from surveys, reports by market research firms, our customers, vendors, suppliers, trade and business organizations and other contacts in the markets in which we operate. In addition, these estimates and beliefs reflect management’s understanding of the various distinct markets for our products. We confirm that the information in this offering memorandum that is based on statistical information from independent industry publications, reports by market research firms or other published sources has been accurately reproduced and that, so far as we are aware and are able to ascertain from information published by publicly available sources and other publications, no facts have been omitted which would render the reproduced information inaccurate or misleading. Such sources and other industry publications, reports and other published data generally state that the information contained therein has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but we cannot assure you that the information contained in these reports, and therefore the information contained in this offering memorandum that is derived therefrom, is accurate or complete. This information may prove to be inaccurate because of the method by which we obtain some of the data for our estimates or because this information cannot always be verified with complete certainty due to the limits on the availability and reliability of raw data, the voluntary nature of the data gathering process and other limitations and uncertainties. As a result, although we believe these sources are reliable and we are not aware of any misstatements regarding our industry data included herein, neither we nor the initial purchasers have independently verified the information and cannot guarantee its accuracy and completeness.

The consolidated financial statements of Parent (“Successor”) and Solenis (“Predecessor”) as of and for each of the years ended September 30, 2022, September 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020 and as of and for the three and six months ended March 31, 2023 and the three months ended March 31, 2022, and the periods November 9, 2021 to March 31, 2022, and October 1, 2021 to November 8, 2021 have been prepared in accordance U.S. GAAP, and include the financial statements of Parent and its wholly-owned subsidiaries. The consolidated and combined financial statements of Diversey Holdings, Ltd. as of and for the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021 and as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2023 and March 31, 2022 have also been prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP, and include the financial statements of Diversey Holdings, Ltd and its wholly-owned subsidiaries. Parent was formed on June 29, 2021 and exists as the “Successor” entity for the specific purpose of having consummated the Solenis Acquisition. Parent also exists as the Successor entity for the specific purpose of having received the contribution of the Sigura business, which was acquired by Platinum on February 28, 2019 and was contributed to Parent (the “Sigura Contribution”) immediately following the Solenis Acquisition on November 9, 2021. Parent was formed under a group of holding companies. These holding companies and partnerships are collectively referred to as the “Holding Companies.” The Holding Companies have no business operations or assets other than cash, cash equivalents, certain related party loans between and among the Holding Companies and Solenis, and investments in the ownership interests described above. Upon the consummation of the Solenis Acquisition, Platinum acquired all of the capital stock and equity interests of the entities comprising the legacy Solenis operations from Solenis UK Holdings Limited. Immediately following the Solenis Acquisition, the Sigura Contribution was effected, which included all of Sigura’s direct and indirect subsidiaries, and which contributed the Sigura business to the Issuer from affiliates of Platinum. Accordingly, the conclusion of the Solenis Acquisition and Sigura Contribution resulted in the consolidation of the operations of the legacy Solenis and Sigura businesses (under the Solenis umbrella) from November 9, 2021 within the financial statements contained in this offering memorandum as presented under the “Successor” periods. Prior to the formation of Parent and the occurrence of the Solenis Acquisition, the Solenis business existed under the “Predecessor” entity known as Solenis UK International. Solenis UK International itself was not acquired as part of the Solenis Acquisition. Instead, the Solenis Acquisition was structured to acquire all of the entities that were direct or indirect subsidiaries of Solenis UK International. The consolidated statement of operations of Parent for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2022, September 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020, and the consolidated balance sheet data as of September 30, 2022 and September 30, 2021 have been derived from the audited consolidated financial statements and related notes of Parent for the year ended September 30, 2022, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. Due to the impact of the Solenis Acquisition by Parent on November 9, 2021, the audited consolidated financial information of Parent for the fiscal year ended September 30, 2022 is presented in two distinct periods to indicate the application of a different basis of accounting between the periods presented: (1) for periods prior to the Solenis Acquisition (October 1, 2021 through November 8, 2021, labeled Predecessor) and (2) for periods after the Solenis Acquisition (November 9, 2021 through September 30, 2022, labeled Successor). This offering memorandum also includes the unaudited interim consolidated financial information of Parent for the six months ended March 31, 2023 and the three months ended March 31, 2022, and the periods November 9, 2021 to March 31, 2022, and October 1, 2021 to November 8, 2021, which has been derived from the unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements of Parent. Due to the impact of the Solenis Acquisition by Parent on November 9, 2021, the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial information of Parent for the six months ended March 31, 2022 is presented in two distinct periods to indicate the application of a different basis xviii ----- of accounting between the periods presented: (1) for periods prior to the Solenis Acquisition (October 1, 2021 through November 8, 2021, labeled Predecessor) and (2) for periods after the Solenis Acquisition (November 9, 2021 through March 31, 2022, labeled Successor). The unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial information of Parent for the six months ended March 31, 2023 is presented at the level of Parent, labeled Successor. The consolidated statement of operations of Diversey for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, and the consolidated balance sheet data as of December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021 have been derived from the audited consolidated financial statements and related notes of Diversey Holdings, Ltd. as of and for the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. This offering memorandum also includes the unaudited interim consolidated financial information of Diversey for the three months ended March 31, 2023 and March 31, 2022, which has been derived from the unaudited consolidated financial statements of Diversey as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2023. Financial data of Parent for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 has been derived by subtracting data from our unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements for the six months ended March 31, 2022 from our audited consolidated financial statements for the year ended September 30, 2022, and adding data from our unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements for the six months ended March 31, 2023. These figures are not presented in accordance with U.S. GAAP, but we believe they provide investors with useful information to assess our recent performance. Financial data of Diversey for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 has been derived by subtracting data from Diversey’s unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements for the three months ended March 31, 2022 from Diversey’s audited consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2022, and adding data from Diversey’s unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements for the three months ended March 31, 2023. These combined results are not considered to be prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP and have not been prepared as pro forma results under applicable regulations. The Non-GAAP Combined operating results are presented for supplemental purposes only, may not be indicative of future results and should not be viewed as a substitute for the financial results of the Predecessor period and Successor period presented in accordance with U.S. GAAP. The condensed combined financial information included in this offering memorandum has been prepared by management and is prepared for informational purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of the combined financial position or results of operation that would have been realized had the Acquisition and the combination occurred as of the dates indicated, nor is it meant to be indicative of any anticipated future results of operations of the combined group. It has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Article 11 of Regulation S-X promulgated by the SEC under the Securities Act or any generally accepted accounting standards. Certain data in this offering memorandum is presented on a pro forma basis to give effect to the Transactions, as set forth under the heading “The Transactions,” as if they occurred on April 1, 2022 for income statement purposes and March 31, 2023 for balance sheet purposes. The Ultimate Issuer was formed on July 1, 2021, the Escrow Issuer was formed on April 27, 2023, Parent was formed and registered on June 29, 2021, and the General Partner was incorporated on June 29, 2021. As a result, the Ultimate Issuer, the Escrow Issuer, Parent and the General Partner have limited results of operations and material financial positions and this offering memorandum presents financial information regarding Parent only for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, September 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020 and for the three and six months ended March 31, 2023 and the three months ended March 31, 2022, and the periods November 9, 2021 to March 31, 2022, and October 1, 2021 to November 8, 2021 and no financial information for the Issuer, the Escrow Issuer or the General Partner is presented in this offering memorandum. If this offering is consummated prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, upon initial issuance of the Notes, the Notes will be obligations solely of the Escrow Issuer, secured by a first-priority security interest in the applicable escrow account and the deposits and investments therein. The Escrow Issuer is not subject to the restrictive covenants under our Existing Indebtedness, but will be limited in its activities by the Indenture, as described below. Assuming the Escrow Release Conditions have been satisfied, on the Acquisition Closing Date, the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors will become parties to the Indenture pursuant to one or more supplemental indentures, the Escrow Issuer will cease to exist as a result of the Escrow Merger and the obligations under the Indenture will become obligations of the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors. The Indenture will require that, prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, the activities of the Escrow Issuer will be restricted to issuing the Notes, performing its obligations in respect of the Notes under the Indenture and the Escrow Agreement and its obligations in respect of the Escrow Agreement, performing any obligations under the Acquisition Agreement, consummating the Acquisition Closing Date and the Escrow Release and redeeming the Notes, if applicable, and conducting such other activities as are necessary, advisable or appropriate to carry out the activities described above or related to the Transactions. Subsubsection Title: History and Evolution
Subsubsection Text: The Escrow Issuer is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Issuer. The Issuer is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent. Parent, doing business as “Solenis” from November 9, 2021, was formed on June 29, 2021 in connection with the Solenis Acquisition as an exempted limited partnership registered and domiciled under the laws of the Cayman Islands. Parent and several other holding companies and partnerships were formed by affiliates of Platinum. Parent exists as the “successor” entity for the specific purposes of (1) having consummated the Solenis Acquisition, and (2) having received the Sigura Contribution. Accordingly, the consummation of the Solenis Acquisition and the Sigura Contribution resulted in the consolidation of the operations of the legacy Solenis and Sigura businesses into the business of Parent from November 9, 2021. On September 9, 2022, Clearon was acquired by Parent and its subsidiaries from Hui Yu Xin American LLC.

Subsubsection Title: Solenis Business
Subsubsection Text: Headquartered in Wilmington, Delaware, Solenis is a leading supplier of specialty chemicals and services to the pulp and paper, mining, food and beverage, power generation, petroleum refining, chemical processing, general manufacturing, municipal and pool markets. Solenis’ product and service line is comprised of chemical and equipment technologies and services designed to help customers improve operational efficiencies, enhance product quality, protect plant assets and minimize environmental impact. Solenis sells products and provide services throughout the Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific primarily to customers operating within the pulp and paper, the water treatment and the pool industries. Solenis has 49 manufacturing facilities strategically located near customers in approximately 22 countries around the globe to ensure seamless supply continuity, and employs a team of more than 6,600 professionals (including more than 2,400 field representatives with deep industry knowledge) in 130 countries across six continents. Solenis has 11 labs consisting of R&D centers and Customer Applications Laboratories spanning every region it serves, aimed at making water work more effectively and more sustainably for its more than 24,500 customers. Key brands delivered by Solenis include Zetag™, Kymene™, Hercobond™, Spectrum™, Praestol™, PerForm™ and Percol™, HTH®, Poolife®, GLB®, Leisure Time®, and HTH Spa®. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, Solenis generated Net sales and Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) of $4.4 billion and $742 million, respectively, reflecting an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 17%. See “—Summary Historical Financial and Combined Financial Data.”

Subsubsection Title: Diversey Business
Subsubsection Text: Headquartered in Fort Mill, South Carolina, Diversey is a leading global supplier and manufacturer of sustainable, high-performance hygiene, retail and grocery, infection prevention and cleaning solutions to the facility management, retail, healthcare, hospitality, food and beverage, commercial laundry, food service, education and government, dairy, agriculture and buildings service contractors (“BSC”) markets. Diversey’s product and service 1 ----- line is comprised of a wide range of hygiene, infection prevention and cleaning solutions that drive operational improvements, enhance customers’ food safety initiatives and protect the environment. Diversey sells products and provides services throughout the Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific primarily to customers operating within the institutional and food and beverage industries. Key brands delivered by Diversey include Lysol®, CLAX®, Suma® and TASKI. Diversey maintains 21 manufacturing facilities (including the “Project Mega” plant facility (the new manufacturing and warehouse facility site located in northern Kentucky)) in 17 countries around the globe to allow Diversey to provide efficient and effective service to its customers across 80 countries. Diversey employs a team of more than 9,000 professionals (including approximately 1,400 technicians to provide on-site services to customers). Diversey has 7 labs spanning every region it serves with over 1,100 patents, over 2,000 unique chemical formulations and an extensive and differentiated suite of dosing and dispensing equipment and floor care machines supporting its intellectual property offering for more than 85,000 customers. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, Diversey generated revenue and Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) of $2.8 billion and $352 million, respectively, reflecting a 13% Adjusted EBITDA margin. For the twelve months ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, Diversey generated Net sales of $2.8 billion, $2.6 billion and $2.6 billion, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of $330 million, $410 million and $401 million, respectively. See “—Summary Historical Financial and Combined Financial Data.” In addition, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, Diversey spent $56 million, $60 million, $55 million and $41 million, respectively, on capital expenditure. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, Diversey spent $78 million, $77 million, $65 million and $46 million, respectively, on dosing and dispensing expenditures.

Subsubsection Title: Combined Company
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the combination of Solenis and Diversey will create a platform with a shared commercial focus and significant global scale in complementary end markets. After giving effect to the Transactions, the combined company will be able to grow and provide a number of attractive cross-selling opportunities, including meeting customers’ increasing demand for “one-stop shop” service models across water management, cleaning and hygiene solutions. After giving effect to the Transactions, we expect to be better positioned to benefit from growing Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) and macroeconomic trends, including those around customer sustainability goals and focus points, such as: heightened focus on water consumption and recycling; the need for improved energy efficiency and raw material management; increased consumer focus on hygiene; increased environmental legislation being implemented globally; and increased levels of shipping and packaging. Together, we will offer a diverse, comprehensive portfolio of solutions and services, which will limit any obsolescence risk as no product or solution represents a material part of our business. 2 ----- Solenis’ and Diversey’s combined segment, geographic and end market breakdown by revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 is illustrated below.[(1) ] (1) Totals may not equal 100% due to rounding. Our leading technology has been at the forefront of the digitization of the water treatment industry and we have a strong pipeline of new and innovative products that we expect will drive significant value for our customers. The combination of Solenis and Diversey represents the coming together of two leading global products, services, and technologies providers with proven track records of product innovation who offer truly differentiated solutions to customers. Prior to the Transactions, we already operate across a diverse set of growing end markets and our broad geographic reach allows us to meet the needs of our customers globally. After giving effect to the Transactions, our combined footprint will continue to span six continents, with reinforced strength and scale of presence, with an increased number of laboratories and production facilities across the Americas, EMEA, and APAC, where we serve all major developed markets and are closely integrated with our customers throughout the world. After giving effect to the Transactions, through our global presence and differentiated service offering in growing markets, we believe we will be a leading provider in all of our segments and will continue to benefit from positive secular trends such as e-commerce for customers, an increased demand for sustainable packaging, a focus on ESG and incremental disposable income increases in emerging markets. The following graphic summarizes the geographic reach of 3 ----- laboratories and production facilities of the combined Solenis company following the Transactions. After giving effect to the Transactions, we will operate 70 manufacturing facilities and 18 laboratories in 23 countries. (1) Includes research, customer application, and development sites. (2) Pro forma for Project Mega facility and associated plant consolidations. See “—Growth Strategy.” There is limited existing overlap between Solenis’ and Diversey’s offerings in water treatment chemicals with legacy Solenis operating in the water treatment and pool solutions markets and legacy Diversey operating in the food and beverage and institutional end markets. We believe the combined company platform will be able to “circle the customer” and create opportunities for new business wins, increasing our customer spending. For example in hotels today, Solenis has a limited presence in pool solutions while Diversey provides kitchen care, building care, floor care, infection prevention and laundry care. After giving effect to the Transactions, we believe the fact that Solenis and Diversey provide different services to their combined customers will provide the combined company with the opportunity to offer existing hotel customers our full suite of products and services, including water treatment. Similarly, Solenis does not currently serve cruise ships or hospitals but will have the opportunity to offer its services to Diversey’s customers in these markets. Protein processing plants are another customer type that each of Solenis and Diversey have a moderate presence with, and going forward, a combined company platform may enable both companies to expand their offerings with such customers. We believe the Transactions present the opportunity to combine our existing services into a “one-stop shop” provider across water management, cleaning and hygiene solutions for our customers. The following graphic summarizes the potential cross-selling opportunities for the combined company. 4 ----- After giving effect to the Transactions, we believe that we will be able to implement near-term strategic initiatives in the legacy Diversey to better optimize processes, drive growth and create value. Some key initiatives will include (i) increasing scale by bundling our leading global cleaning and water treatment solutions across Industrial and Food & Beverage to increase win rates and cross-selling opportunities, (ii) increasing efficiencies by standardizing corporate functions, (iii) implementing a global enterprise resource planning (ERP) system, (iv) investing in growth opportunities such as expansion efforts within: North America commercial and institutional, high growth global strategic accounts (“GSAs”), distributor partnerships and building out new product introduction (NPI) capabilities and (v) applying our performance management capabilities to existing processes. We believe by creating real-time visibility into financial performance we will be able to drive accountability at a more localized level and assist in informing business decisions (such as pricing and have better insight into profitability and distributors’ sell-through). We believe we will be able to further supplement our efforts by deploying commercial excellence tools such as roll-outs and trainings. Additionally, we believe we can continue implementing Diversey’s “Project Mega” by continuing to develop Diversey’s manufacturing and warehouse facility in Northern Kentucky alongside consolidating certain existing service centers to provide manufacturing and logistical efficiencies and insourcing opportunities. We believe our business exhibits highly attractive financial characteristics, including significant recurring revenues, improving margin profile and substantial free cash flow conversion. The combined company will provide greater scale, a broader global reach, superior customer service capabilities and a number of attractive cross-selling opportunities. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, we generated pro forma Net sales on a combined historical basis and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies) of $7.2 billion and $1.3 billion, respectively, inclusive of $205 million of estimated run-rate annual cost synergies from actions expected to be taken within 24 months after the Acquisition and $40 million of cumulative run-rate annual cost synergies from actions that were taken within 18 months of the Solenis Acquisition Closing Date and $13 million of estimated run-rate annual cost synergies from actions already taken or expected to be taken within 24 months of the Clearon Acquisition Closing Date. We believe our combined earnings profile after giving effect to the Transactions will generate significant free cash flow, which we expect will be used to support growth initiatives and drive de-leveraging. We believe that the Transactions create an opportunity to realize meaningful synergies resulting from the integration of Solenis and Diversey. In combining these two complementary businesses, we believe the combined company is entering a new and exciting chapter in a long history of helping customers address core challenges such as water and energy management, partnering on sustainability issues to work towards a cleaner, safer world, and reducing environmental impacts. We expect to realize approximately $205 million of synergies from integration related to the consolidation of support functions and sales teams, the consolidation of sourcing of direct materials, and the consolidation of facilities between the two businesses, as a result of actions expected to be taken within 24 months of the closing of the Transactions. However, there can be no assurance that we will be able to achieve such synergies. For more information on anticipated synergies, including certain factors that may impact our ability to achieve such synergies or operational improvements, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition and the Legacy Acquisitions—We may not achieve some or all of the expected benefits from the items reflected in the adjustments included in Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies).” The prospective unaudited financial information contained in this offering memorandum was not prepared with a view toward compliance with published guidelines of the SEC or the guidelines established by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants for preparation or presentation of prospective financial information. Subsubsection Title: Consumer Solutions Segment (29% of Combined Company Net Sales)
Subsubsection Text: Our Consumer Solutions segment provides chemicals and on-site services to customers in four major end markets: Consumer Packaging, Graphic & Specialty Paper, Tissue & Towel and Food Packaging & Molded Fiber Packaging. The Consumer Solutions segment’s portfolio includes both functional additives that impact the end-use characteristics of the finished product, as well as process additives that improve raw material utilization, process efficiency, reduce costs and protect capital intensive pulp and papermaking assets. Our product offering is extensive and includes products such as Sizing, Strength, Biocides, Retention & Drainage Control (“RDC”), Contaminant Control, Pulp, Crepe & Release and Defoamers. Examples and descriptions of Key End Products, Products / Applications and Customer Benefits for each end market can be found in the chart below.

We will provide products and services to our customers through five segments: Consumer Solutions, Industrial Solutions, Pool Solutions, Institutional Solutions and Food & Beverage, with water treatment spanning all five reporting segments.

Subsubsection Title: Pool Solutions Segment (12% of Combined Company Net Sales)
Subsubsection Text: Our Pool Solutions segment offers water care solutions and value-added services for residential and commercial pools and spas. The water treatment process begins with testing; specifically pool pH and chlorine levels on a weekly basis. The next step is balancing, i.e., maintaining certain levels of pH, total alkalinity and calcium hardness. Sanitizing, which is keeping water clean and disinfected, is most frequently done using stabilized chlorine products. Specialty maintenance products such as algaecides and clarifiers are typically used on a semimonthly basis, in addition to the normal sanitizing process, to target specific pool needs such as algae prevention or stain control. Lastly, shock treatment can be used to address one-off pool care needs, especially following inclement weather and high pool usage. We are a leading producer of pool chemicals for the residential and commercial markets worldwide and provide various water treatment products including shock, sanitizer, specialty maintenance products, and test strips. Our offerings include a full suite of products and applications aimed at public pools, health clubs, aquatic parks, hotels, motels, apartments and condominiums in the form of water-soluble pods, convenient floaters and automatic feeders. Our portfolio of brands includes iconic brands such HTH®, Poolife®, GLB®, Leisure Time® and HTH 9 ----- Spa®. We believe we are the world’s largest producer of calcium-hypoclorite (“cal-hypo”), a primary chemical used in water treatment and sanitation. We believe we are one of only two players with a complete brand and product offering in the U.S. pool and spa chemicals market and we believe we are the only player with a truly global offering. We have total market access to all residential channels from Mass Retail (40.6% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023), to Professional Dealer (29.3% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023), to Commercial (10.1% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023), to Repack and Private Label (18.7% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023) and Other Pool (1.3% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023), as well as growing e-commerce and Direct to Consumer (“DTC”) channels. Demand for products from the Pool Solutions segment is driven by the existing installed base of pools in the regions it operates, which have seen growth tailwinds due to COVID-driven investment in outdoor spaces. Going forward, ongoing maintenance of these pools will drive sustainable and recurring future demand for our products. The Pool Solutions segment generated 12% of pro forma Net sales for the combined Solenis company for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023. We have relationships with key customers across channels including in (i) the mass retail market: Walmart, Ace Hardware, Amazon and Costco; (ii) the pro dealer market: Pool Corp, Leslie’s Poolmart, Poolwerx, Heritage Pool Group and a large fragmented base of individual pool and spa dealers; and (iii) in the commercial market: Pool Corp, Sea World and Bellagio.

Subsubsection Title: Food & Beverage Segment (12% of Combined Company Net Sales)
Subsubsection Text: After giving effect to the Transactions, our Food & Beverage segment will offer a broad range of products, solutions, as well as equipment and machines including chemical products, engineering and equipment solutions, as well as knowledge-based services, including training through our Diversey Hygiene Academy, and water treatment services. As mentioned above, Diversey and Solenis currently have an existing distribution relationship with the Diversey Food & Beverage segment, through which Solenis provides water treatment products to Diversey to be marketed to Diversey’s existing customer base. 12 ----- Examples of key end products, products and applications and customer benefits for each end market can be found in the chart below.

We will be one of the major global players within the segment, therefore, we believe we will have the product breadth, scale, supply chain flexibility and service capabilities to compete with Ecolab. Further, we believe there is an opportunity to capture customers within underserved sectors such as cruise ships, logistics, warehousing, casinos, and theme parks. 11 ----- We believe that our Institutional Solutions segment’s revenue base will be recurring and stable due to the ‘sticky’ nature of our business model. Our cleaning products will be consumable in nature and require periodic replacement, generating highly recurring revenue. Additionally, the optimal application of our chemicals will be controlled by our proprietary dosing and dispensing equipment installed at customer sites, which will increase customer switching costs and generate operating efficiencies for our customers. Subsubsection Title: New Product Development Capabilities and Innovations
Subsubsection Text: Our service and product offering, through all five of our combined company segments and various end markets, is enhanced by our new and innovative products which carry higher than average margin profiles, which represent a significant mix lever for the combined company and which help our customers meet their goals and improve operational efficiencies and product quality. We believe our sophisticated product development capabilities meet our customers’ evolving needs and help keep us at the forefront of macroeconomic trends. Our robust innovation pipeline currently has approximately 47 projects with over 85% including a focus on solving our customers’ environmental and sustainability challenges, placing us at the forefront of the ESG mega trend. Of our 47 projects, 15 projects are in Consumer Solutions, 14 are in Institutional Solutions, 7 are in Industrial Solutions, 7 are in Food & Beverage and 4 are in Pool Solutions. 100% of our Institutional Solutions, Industrial Solutions and Pool Solutions projects include a focus on ESG, while over 87% of our Consumer Solutions and 86% of our Food & Beverage projects include a focus on ESG. The following chart summarizes some of the new product development capabilities and innovations we are creating to help customers meet sustainability goals, improve operational efficiency and enhance product quality. ###### End Market Geography

In our Food & Beverage segment we will serve a wide range of customers. Representative customers will include: Diageo, The Coca-Cola Company, Anheuser Busch, PepsiCo, Heineken, Brenntag, Nestle, Mondelez International and Yili Group. 13 ----- We believe that our Food & Beverage segment’s revenue base will be recurring and stable. Our CleaningIn-Place (“CIP”) and Open Plant Systems will integrate our chemicals, lubricants, floor care equipment, and cleaning and dispensing tools, while our highly skilled technical application experts will help customers achieve production efficiencies through customized solutions that utilize our products. The highly integrated and customized nature of the resulting solutions are expected to drive operational efficiencies as well as high switching costs for our customers, leading to very high customer retention. The food and beverage industry is widely fragmented and we believe the combined company has the ability to win business driven by an increasing customer demand for water treatment being bundled with food and beverage solutions. Based on a third-party report completed in February 2023, food and beverage is growing at a CAGR of 6.5% for the four year period 2022 to 2026. The Food & Beverage segment generated 12% of pro forma Net sales for the combined Solenis company for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023.
