Subsubsection Title: Customers and Suppliers & Procurement
Subsubsection Text: _Customers_ We serve a large base of customers across a diverse set of end markets. Our customer base for the combined company includes many of the top paper and industrial players across our Industrial Solutions and Consumer Solutions segments, including WestRock, International Paper, and Marathon Petroleum, across big-box retailers such as Wal-Mart and Leslie’s Poolmart in our Pool Solutions segment, across Compass, ISS and McDonald’s in our Institutional Solutions segment and across PepsiCo and Nestle in our Food & Beverage segment. We believe that the combination of Solenis and Diversey will further reduce customer concentration. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, the top ten customers for the combined company represent approximately 12% of total pro forma combined company Net sales with the largest customer representing approximately 2% of pro forma combined company Net sales. As of March 31, 2023, at Solenis, the top ten customers represented approximately 19% of total Net sales with the top three customers representing approximately 11%. Historically, large accounts have grown 1.3x faster than the base business, driven by collaboration with customers on new technology development, embedded service engineers and focus on consistent delivery and service. As of March 31, 2023 at Diversey, customer concentration was relatively in line with that of Solenis so low customer concentration is set to become even less concentrated as a result of the combination of Solenis and Diversey. Further, Diversey is a major global player with capabilities to serve GSAs, which represents approximately 20% of revenue. Both Solenis and Diversey have long-tenured, diverse and high quality customer relationships. We believe our customer base is inherently sticky, attributable to the mission critical nature and service-led models that Solenis and Diversey provide, leading to highly recurring, non-discretionary spend on products and services. On-site technicians, employees and equipment at customer locations create high switching costs and disruption risk. As a result, we believe Solenis’ Net sales is approximately 97% recurring, driven by our differentiated solutions and value proposition and will continue to remain over 97% recurring in the combined company. _Suppliers & Procurement_ We source materials from multiple suppliers creating low supply chain concentration. On April 30, 2021, Solenis and BASF agreed to extend the supply agreements applicable to certain products that are critical to Solenis’ supply chain and for which Solenis takes all of BASF’s production, which now will not expire until November 2028. Our largest raw material spend includes General Liquids (5.4% of total spend), Caustic and Chlorine (3.3% of total spend), Acrylonitrile (2.9% of total spend), HDPE (2.2% of total spend) and Sodium Hydroxide (2.1% of total spend) resulting in a top five materials of 15.9% or $590 million. The top five key suppliers represent 23% of total expenditure, or $854 million, with the top supplier representing 13% of total expenditure. 15 Slow Dissolve Calcium** Slowed dissolve tablet platform delivers better solution for pool water Pool Solutions Hypochlorite** clarity and water utilization ----- The following graphic summarizes our pro forma combined company expenditure on raw materials and to key suppliers for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023. ###### Raw Materials Key Suppliers

Subsubsection Title: Specialty Chemicals – Consumer
Subsubsection Text: The Consumer market is comprised of water treatment chemicals and solutions for pulp and paper specific process applications (e.g., strength additives and sizing agents across wet-end/dry-end of paper process). Based on a report by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021, the global Consumer market was estimated to be approximately $8 billion in 2020. The Packaging market is one of the key market segments within the Consumer market that can be broken into consumer packaging and food packaging. Based on the same report, the Consumer packaging market was estimated to be $2.7 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 3.4% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030, which we believe will be driven primarily from the growth of e-commerce and megatrends in pharmaceuticals and cosmetics and beauty. Approximately 10% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated from the consumer packaging market. Based on the same report, the food packaging market was estimated to be $1.8 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 1.9% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030 (including food packaging barrier film expected to grow at a 4.7% CAGR), driven by increased demand for ecofriendly packaging and changing lifestyles centering on more take-away and individually packed food. We believe the shift away from plastic and the growth in the barrier coating market, which is not included in the market size estimate, may drive additional growth in food packaging over this period. Approximately 7% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated from the food packaging and molded fiber packaging market. The Graphic & Specialty Paper market has been adversely impacted by the continued substitution of printed material with electronic media. Reduced use of commercial office spaces in Europe and North America as a result of COVID-19 is also a negative factor for the sector outlook. The Graphic & Specialty Paper market, based on the same report, was estimated to be $1.9 billion in 2020 and is expected to decline at a 0.9% CAGR for the ten-year period from 2020 to 2030. However, we have limited exposure to newsprint, which accounts for approximately 2.5% of Consumer Solutions sales, and we are shifting our focus to higher margin products to offset the expected volume decline in this market. Approximately 5% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated from the Graphic & Specialty Paper market. The Tissue & Towel market is benefiting from strong demographic/socioeconomic trends and increasing hygiene standards, especially in developing markets. However, stagnating population growth in some mature markets, and cost-cutting in the public sector and private company spending is expected to limit global market growth. The Tissue & Towel market, based on the same report, was estimated to be $1.2 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 2.6% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030. Approximately 6% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated from the Tissue & Towel market. 16 -----

Subsubsection Title: Specialty Chemicals — Industrial
Subsubsection Text: The industrial market supplies water treatment chemicals and solutions for heavy and light industries and municipalities (e.g., cooling tower, boiler, influent/effluent, process water). Broadly speaking, the industrial market consists of core water treatment which includes end markets such as pulp, mining and oil and gas, and wastewater, which includes end markets such as municipal and industrial wastewater markets. Based on the same report, the global industrial market was estimated to be approximately $23 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 4.0% CAGR for the five-year period 2020 to 2025 for both the wastewater and core water treatment markets. The municipal market is expected to grow at a 4.3% CAGR for the five-year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same report, as demand continues to increase from higher per capita usage of water, population growth and increasing regulatory demands. Growth in the core water treatment market, including both heavy and light industrial markets, is expected to be driven by increasing sustainability and environmental policies, growing regulatory demands and global industrial growth. This growth is expected to be highest in the food and beverage market (5.5% CAGR for the five year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same report) and the refining and petrochemicals market (4.0% CAGR for the five-year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same report). Approximately 20% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated from the Industrial market.

Subsubsection Title: Pool
Subsubsection Text: The aftermarket for the residential pool industry is comprised of three main segments: (1) Chemicals, (2) Equipment, Parts, and Accessories and (3) Services. Our main focus is on the Chemicals segment which is the largest and most stable component of aftermarket pool spend. Pool chemicals sales are tied to: (1) the pool installed base and (2) total gallons of treatable water, and not new builds. The U.S. pool installed base has displayed long-term stability as it has consistently grown for decades, including all years through the housing-led recession and during the COVID-19 pandemic period, which is providing current tailwinds for the business. As of December 31, 2022, the installed base of U.S. in ground pools was 9 million, based on a recent study by a leading research firm in the pool and spa market. However, new builds account for less than 4% of the installed base annually, meaning that new build rates are unlikely to materially impact our long-term performance. The Pool Solutions segment also benefits from a stable aftermarket spend that mirrors the steady dynamic of the installed base. Our chemical-based products result in 100% aftermarket exposure, which reduces our exposure to cyclical industry trends such as housing starts. Pool chemical use is entirely non-discretionary in that it is a requirement for owning and using a pool. Pool owners who have already made the significant upfront investment of constructing a pool, estimated to cost $40,000 to $100,000, will continue to purchase pool chemicals, at the de minimis annual expense of $300 to $400 in order to maintain their pools. The pool chemical treatment market includes products such as primary sanitizers (71% of total market sales), specialty chemicals, other shocks and alternative sanitizers. Primary sanitizers include cal-hypo, sodium hypochlorite (“sodium-hypo”), trichlor, dichlor and packaged shocks. The total market for U.S. residential pool chemicals, based on retail dollar value, was approximately $2.6 billion in 2020 and grew by 28% in 2021 to approximately $3.4 billion, primarily due to higher prices resulting from scarcity of chlorine based on a recent study by a leading research firm in the pool and spa market. We believe the U.S. residential pool chemical market, on a volume basis, will exceed the expected growth of the installed base of U.S. residential pools, which was estimated to be 3.0% from 2020 to 2025 based on a recent study by a leading research firm in the pool and spa market. We further believe that volumes in our pool solutions segment will exceed the market as we expand our customer base and increase market sale with new dealer relationships and e-commerce.

Subsubsection Title: Institutional
Subsubsection Text: The Institutional Solutions market growth is driven by an aging population, increasing demand for healthcare facilities, return to office policies continued to drive an increase demand for cleaning, the introduction of new sanitization standards arising post-COVID and a focus on new infrastructure bills to expand healthcare and transportation networks. Based on a third-party report completed in February 2023, the Institutional Solutions 17 ----- segment is growing at a CAGR of 5.3% for the four year period 2022 to 2026. The manufacturing and commercial and healthcare and hospitality sub-end markets are expected to grow at a CAGR of 5.1% and 5.5%, respectively, for the four year period 2022 to 2026.

Subsubsection Title: Food & Beverage
Subsubsection Text: The Food & Beverage market growth is driven by an increase in governmental concerns over food safety and oversight driving increased regulation, shifting consumer preferences in (1) mature markets, towards organic and simple and (2) in emerging markets, towards more processed foods and a growing global population driving increased consumption of food and beverage. Based on a third-party report completed in February 2023, the Food & Beverage segment is expected to grow at a CAGR of 6.5% for the four year period 2022 to 2026.

Subsubsection Title: Competitive Landscape
Subsubsection Text: _Consumer Solutions_ We believe, based on a report by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021, that we are the market leader in specialty chemicals for the Consumer Solutions segment. Based on the same report, we believe that we maintain market leadership positions in almost all technologies and regions. The competitive landscape, as segmented by geography or technology, remains fragmented. We have particularly strong market positions in process chemicals within the biocide, contaminant control, defoamer, tissue specialties and pulp specialties technologies. Our strength is based on the complete product portfolio, premium product performance and strong technical support we offer. We believe we have the best and the broadest offering to help customers achieve their operational efficiencies. We are a trusted supplier known for our data analytics capacities, with a focus on service excellence, sustainability, productivity and cost savings for our customers. Many customers are starting to embrace digital technology / data analytics to help track performance and starting to partner with suppliers with strong R&D capabilities to develop innovative solutions to drive efficiency and achieve sustainability objectives. This trend is expected to continue and we expect to benefit from it due to our robust value-added chemistry and technology solutions offering. _Industrial Solutions_ The global industrial water chemicals market is fragmented, with the top seven players, based on a report by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021. This is due to the required application-specific expertise and track-record of performance. Hence, by region and by end-user market, three to five players may have a disproportionately high share. We believe we have an outsized share of the global pulp and paper market, which is one of our larger markets within the Industrial Solutions segment. We believe we offer the lowest per unit cost for comparable chemicals compared to our industry peers and believe that the competitive pricing is our greatest strength in the Industrial Solutions segment. Additionally, we offer an array of innovative solutions and comprehensive product lines both in core water treatment and wastewater segment. Notable competitors include Ecolab / Nalco, Suez, ChemTreat, Kurita, Kemira and SNF. Ecolab, which acquired Nalco in 2011, is the largest water treatment player followed by Suez. Similar to the Consumer market, technology and R&D are becoming increasingly important beyond the chemical product itself as customers are moving towards advanced analytics to optimize the volume of chemical treatment, driving select industry participants to increasingly focus on equipment / engineering solutions as opposed to chemical solutions. 20 ----- _Pool Solutions_ We believe we are the only true global player in the Pool Solutions segment with leading market positions in North America, South America, and EMEA. We believe the acquisition of Clearon further enhanced our market leading position. Our primary competitor in this segment is KIK Custom Products, which provides various pool chemical solutions, with a focus on North America. Other smaller competitors also compete in this market, with varying breadth and geographical focus, including Hasa Pool, Jandy, Lo-chlor and Jack’s Magic. We believe we are the world’s largest producer of cal-hypo, a primary chemical used in water treatment and sanitation. All three of our cal-hypo facilities are co-located with chlor-alkali producers meaning that raw materials (chlorine and caustic soda) are delivered into our production plants via a direct pipeline. We believe this is a major competitive advantage and barrier to entry in the Pool Solutions segment as we believe it would not be economical for our competitors to open a new cal-hypo facility that is not co-located with a supply of raw materials. The acquisition of Clearon provided additional manufacturing capabilities for trichlor and dichlor and we are now the only producer of cal-hypo, trichlor and dichlor, which we believe will give us a significant advantage over our competitors. Further, Clearon’s manufacturing facility located in West Virginia was isolated from the impact of natural disasters that other competitors have experienced with facilities located on the Gulf Coast. _Institutional Solutions_ Diversey is a major global player in the Institutional Solutions segment and competes primarily with Ecolab. Other competitors in this segment include: SC Johnson, Gojo, Kalykim and Jasol. In this highly fragmented market, Diversey and Ecolab together hold approximately a 20% global market share. Geographically, Diversey believes it is the number one or number two player in the North America, Europe, Middle East and Africa, Latin America and Asia-Pacific regions. Other competitors are focused on niche segments and geographies, focusing on regional and local customers. Diversey is positioned to compete using a recurring revenue business model built on consumable products that require periodic replacement and high customer switching costs via a suite of proprietary dosing and dispensing equipment installed at customer sites. Further, to better compete with Ecolab in North America, Diversey is in the process of opening a new co-manufacturing / co-warehouse facility in Northern Kentucky, alongside consolidating certain existing service centers to increase manufacturing and logistical efficiencies and insourcing opportunities. After giving effect to the Transactions, we believe that we will be better positioned to compete with Ecolab for leadership across all markets. We believe that the combined company is best positioned to capture share on a global scale due to Diversey’s strong existing market position, combined with our own position and track record of sustained growth and the white space afforded by such a fragmented market. _Food & Beverage_ Diversey is one of the only two global players in the Food & Beverage segment and competes primarily with Ecolab. The Food & Beverage market is largely consolidated and Diversey and Ecolab together hold approximately half of the global market share. Ecolab and Diversey generally compete within cleaning and hygiene solutions. Other, smaller competitors exist including Zep, Reckitt and Kersia. These players tend to service more regional markets and operate with highly limited product and distribution capabilities. Prior to the Transactions, we entered into a distribution relationship with Diversey through which we provide water treatment products to be marketed to Diversey’s existing customer base within its Food & Beverage segment. This current offering sets Diversey apart from Ecolab and represents an opportunity for additional market capture and cross-selling in the future following the consummation of the Transactions.

Subsubsection Title: Sustainability and Environmental and Social Governance
Subsubsection Text: We drive sustainability by reducing water and energy use and raw materials waste while improving operational productivity. Increased focus on sustainability and ESG is a key trend across both Consumer Solutions and Industrial Solutions segments and is driving demand as our customers aim to reduce water and energy 21 ----- consumption, optimize raw materials spend and reduce waste emission. These objectives require increased chemical use which is driving increased demand for our business. Institutional products are designed to enhance cleanliness, safety, environmental sustainability, and efficiency needed to serve our customers in the healthcare, education, food service, retail and grocery, hospitality, and building service contractor industries. Food & Beverage solutions will maximize food safety, operational excellence, and sustainability for our customers in the brewing, beverage, dairy, processed foods, pharmaceutical and agriculture industries. At the micro level, we provide solutions to customers with specific sustainability goals. For example, our offering of PFAS-free oil and grease resistant technology has been selected by major brand owners as a replacement in food service bowls. We also made a series of recommendations to a chemical company which resulted in a reduction of 28,000 cubic meters of water per year and 3,000 tons of CO2 emissions. The resulting savings for our customer were approximately $27 million per year. Further, our cal-hypo-based shocks that are sold at big-box retailers eliminate the need to drain and refill pools due to over stabilization, resulting in potential water savings of up to 600 gallons per pound used instead of dichlor and we estimate approximate water savings of up to 25 billion gallons per year. Diversey’s Clax® Advanced laundry solution supports clean and bright laundry at low wash temperatures to lower operational costs and reduce its customers’ environmental impact. Further, its delivers excellent linen hygiene and extends linen life. Clax® Advanced provides solutions in a variety of industrial laundry applications globally such as hotels and nursing homes, with substantial operational savings in conserving energy and water while reducing waste. Benefits of this offering include: (1) up to a 35% reduction in water use (or 8,000 kilo liters; the equivalent of three Olympic swimming pools), (2) up to a 40% reduction in steam use (or 600 metric tons), up to a 15% reduction in electricity use (or 5,000 kilowatt hour), (3) up to a 16% reduction in wash time (or ~150 work days), (4) up to 35% effluent (or 8,000 kilo liters), (5) up to 100 metric tons reduction in CO2 emissions and (6) up to 30% extension in linen life. Our management is dedicated to, and focused on, building and marketing our strong ESG reputation, shifting to green products and providing value-added services to help our customers achieve their sustainability targets. Focusing on solving customers’ environmental and sustainability challenges has led to notable results for Solenis. As of September 30, 2022, (1) 86% of innovation projects in the pipeline had a sustainability / circularity focus, (2) 83% of Net sales was driven by projects that support customers’ sustainability goals, (3) 15% of innovation programs focused on carbon footprint projects, (4) reduced our CO2 emissions by 5% from fiscal year ended 2018 and (5) we had an Environmental Incident Classification (“EIC”) score of 49 with a goal to reduce by 10% each year. As of the end of fiscal year 2022, Diversey’s notable results include: (1) eliminating 100 metric tons of waste, (2) conserving 10 billion gallons of water, (3) saving 1.1 billion kilowatt hours of energy and (4) saving 290 thousand metric tonnes of CO2-equivalent emissions. We are also focused on long term sustainability goals for our business that include the following long term goals: (1) over 92.5% of our suppliers to be compliant with our sustainable procurement standards, (2) 20% reduction in CO2 emissions, (3) 5% reduction in water consumption, (4) over 90% of new innovation projects to have a sustainability / circularity focus, (5) over 90% of our revenues to support our customers’ sustainability goals, (6) 100% of our plants to be ISO 9001, RC14001, ISO 14001, ISO 45001 and SEDEX certified and (7) 5% return on investment from every commercial person focusing on reduction in energy, water and raw materials as well as improved productivity. Diversey’s long term sustainability goals for its business include the following long term goals: (1) environment: achieving (i) net positive impact for energy, water, waste and GHG, (ii) net zero carbon emissions and (iii) 100% core packaging contributing to a circular economy, (2) social: (i) fostering an inclusive and diverse workforce with 40% gender diversity globally and 25% ethnic diversity in the United States, (ii) improving its employee engagement score to the top quartile, (iii) ensuring 100% employee safety, with zero workplace injuries and (iv) improving the lives of people in the communities Diversey operates in, and (3) governance: ensure (i) engagement with stakeholders, (ii) transparency of results and (iii) 100% compliance with policies.
(2) Note: Based on data from an expert third-party advisor. 18 -----

Subsection Title: Summary of Operational Improvements and Synergies Initiatives related to the Acquisition
Subsubsection Text: We, along with Platinum, have identified expected synergies resulting from the Transactions. We identified an estimated $205 million in net annual cost synergies expected to be implemented within 24 months of closing the Transactions which are expected to be realized through consolidation of support and sales functions, materials sourcing consolidation and facility consolidation, as follows: 22 ----- - Approximately $97 million of cost synergies are expected to be achieved through organizational design opportunities via consolidation of Diversey’s back office into Solenis’ across the finance, information technology, human resources, legal, environmental, health and safety, commercial, research and development and marketing functions. The foregoing includes $51 million in optimizing overall organizational structure and number of employees for key functions, $33 million in elimination of redundant leadership positions and management roles and $14 million for the leveraging of existing shared service centers across the combined company. - Approximately $44 million of cost synergies are expected to be achieved related to direct and indirect sourcing opportunities, including $30 million related to leveraging combined chemicals and commodities spend and higher purchasing power to drive more favorable contracts by both product type and supplier and $13 million related to leveraging combined indirect spend categories with supplier rationalization to reduce fragmentation and tail spend in certain categories, consolidation of technologies, and telecom, network and data center optimization. - Approximately $64 million of cost synergies are expected to be achieved through manufacturing and distribution center optimization and consolidation, transportation logistics efficiencies and real estate consolidation, including $23 million related to consolidating overlapping footprints and removing excess capacity, $37 million related to optimizing outbound transportation based on facility consolidation and production shifts between plants to optimize shipping networks to nearest point of origin, procuring freight more effectively and improving contract compliance, and $5 million related to optimizing office footprint to reduce redundancies, underutilized office space by renegotiating leases and eliminating smaller offices with little to no headcount by converting to remote work or providing alternative locations. To achieve the identified synergies, we expect to incur approximately $190 million in total of one-time costs related to severance, retention, information technology system integration and consulting, among other costs. The initiatives to realize the Transactions synergies have and will be executed by a dedicated implementation team with support from Platinum operational executives and third-party resources. However, there can be no assurance that we will be able to achieve these synergies or operational improvements. For more information about our anticipated synergies, including certain factors that may affect our ability to achieve such synergies or operational improvements, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition and the Legacy Acquisitions—We may not achieve some or all of the expected benefits from the items reflected in the adjustments included in Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies). The prospective unaudited financial information contained in this offering memorandum was not prepared with a view toward compliance with published guidelines of the SEC or the guidelines established by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants for preparation or presentation of prospective financial information. The prospective unaudited financial information included in this offering memorandum has been prepared by, and is the responsibility of, Parent’s management. PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP has not audited, reviewed, examined, compiled nor applied agreed upon procedures with respect to the prospective unaudited financial information and, accordingly, PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP does not express an opinion or any other form of assurance with respect thereto. The PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP report incorporated by reference in this offering memorandum relates to Parent’s previously issued financial statements. It does not extend to the prospective unaudited financial information and should not be read to do so.

Subsection Title: Summary of Operational Improvements and Synergies Initiatives related to the Legacy Acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: We, along with Platinum, identified synergies resulting from the Solenis Acquisition. We achieved $40 million in annual cost synergies from actions that were taken within 18 months of the Solenis Acquisition Closing Date. 23 ----- We, along with Platinum, also identified expected synergies resulting from the Clearon Acquisition. We identified an estimated $13 million in net annual cost synergies from actions taken or expected to be taken within 24 months of closing the Clearon Acquisition. As of March 31, 2023, we have achieved $6.5 million and expect to achieve $6.5 million from actions taken to date or to be taken in the next 15 months. These synergies are expected to be realized through headcount rationalization and non-labor optimization spend net of certain incremental expenses. The initiatives to realize both the Solenis Acquisition and Clearon Acquisition synergies have and will continue to be executed by a dedicated implementation team with support from Platinum operational executives and third-party resources. However, there can be no assurance that we will be able to achieve the remaining synergies or operational improvements. For more information about our anticipated synergies, including certain factors that may affect our ability to achieve such synergies or operational improvements, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition and the Legacy Acquisitions—We may not achieve some or all of the expected benefits from the items reflected in the adjustments included in Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies).” The prospective unaudited financial information contained in this offering memorandum was not prepared with a view toward compliance with published guidelines of the SEC or the guidelines established by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants for preparation or presentation of prospective financial information. Subsubsection Title: Leading Provider in Growing Water Intensive and Relatively Recession Resilient End Markets
Subsubsection Text: We believe the size of Solenis’ total addressable market was $39 billion as of 2020 and that the market is relatively fragmented, with four top players, presenting an opportunity for us to capture share. Further, we believe the size of Diversey’s total addressable market is $46 billion. Our combined platform will create a scaled leader across all water intensive industries. Based on a report by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021, we believe that we have the #1 market position in the Consumer Solutions segment and are one of the top market players in the highly fragmented Industrial Solutions segment. Additionally, we believe we are one of two top players in the U.S. pool and spa chemicals market. After giving effect to the Transactions, we believe we will be one of the top players in the Institutional Solutions and Food & Beverage markets. We serve a variety of growing diverse water-intensive end markets, including consumer chemicals (estimated by a third-party expert advisor to grow at 1.8% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030), industrial chemical (estimated by a third-party expert advisor to grow at 4.0% CAGR for the five-year period 2020 to 2025), and pool and spa (estimated by a recent study by a leading research firm in the pool and spa market at 3%+ CAGR). As a combined company, other end markets will include institutional (estimated by a third-party expert to grow at over 5.3% CAGR for the four-year period 2022 to 2026) and food & beverage (estimated by a third-party expert to grow at 6.5% CAGR for the four-year period 2022 to 2026). We have a comprehensive portfolio of solutions including Biocides, Antifoams, Raw and Waste Water treatments, Deposit Control, Dosing & Dispensing Equipment, proprietary owned chemical formulas among others for our customers to address their needs in these growing end markets. We believe that the majority of the end markets we serve are relatively recession resilient, which in combination with our business management, will protect us from any severe impact to our profitability in the event of an economic downturn. 24 ----- The following table summarizes our belief on the recession resiliency the end market for each of our segments. Segment End Market Food Packaging & Molded Fiber Packaging End Market Resilience Market Drivers - Minimal impact to food packaging as focus on sustainable High alternatives drives continued momentum Consumer Solutions Consumer Neutral Packaging Tissue & High Towel Graphic & Specialty Neutral - Limited impact to general packaging as lower consumer purchasing is partially offset by continued shift to eCommerce - Tissue & Towel volumes remain robust during recessionary periods driven by continued consumer demand for non-discretionary end products irrespective of macroeconomic conditions - Graphic & Specialty paper is impacted by a shift to online modes and experiences little to no demand impact due to food packaging - Return to work and back to school rebound will continue to drive category up over artificially low post pandemic base - Healthcare, education, and retail largely unaffected in recessionary periods due to criticality of end markets and need for consistent hygiene and infection prevention services, regardless of broader macroeconomic conditions - Food service, hospitality, and building services end markets remain resilient during recessionary periods. Dishwasher chemicals and laundry chemicals are partially tied to end consumer traffic and disinfectants and sanitizers are correlated with foot traffic Institutional Solutions Healthcare High Hospitality Neutral Manufacturing & Commercial - Moderate impact from decline in manufacturing during Neutral recessionary periods - Wastewater treatment is generally resilient due to the critical nature of the process and limited macroeconomic impact - Other industrial water treatment is exposed to industrial manufacturing end markets, which presents a moderate impact during a downturn - Food & Beverage is largely unaffected during recessionary periods driven by continued need for protein processing, beverage production, and other food processing regardless and market conditions - Pool and spa end markets maintain strong demand during recessionary periods due to the necessity of constant maintenance or risk of expensive complications with the pool infrastructure - While commercial pool use may suffer slightly during recessionary periods, increased use of residential pools should lead to stronger consumer pool demand 25 Industrial Solutions Wastewater High Core Water Neutral Treatment Food & Food & Beverage High Beverage Pool Solutions Pool & Spa High -----

Subsubsection Title: Global Leader with Diverse Sticky Customer Base
Subsubsection Text: After giving effect to the Transactions, we will have a large geographical footprint that enables us to provide global service to our customers. We are present on six continents, with both laboratories and production facilities across the Americas, EMEA, and APAC, where we serve all major developed markets. After giving effect to the Transactions, we will have approximately 15,600 employees with a substantial presence across the North Americas, EMEA, and APAC regions. Our strategic global footprint allows us to efficiently and effectively serve customers around the world by providing consistent products and service. Diversey offers further expansion opportunities, particular given by its strength in EMEA. Our service and technical abilities are mission critical to our customers. Typically our trained value-add employees, scientists, and service engineers are embedded at customers’ sites, creating strong and long-term relationships. We represent a lower overall percentage of our customers’ cost base and have been able to achieve significant value add documented savings for our customers. We are highly engrained in our customers’ workflow, and it is often difficult, expensive, and potentially disruptive for customers to switch to a competitor. As a result, we believe Solenis’ Net sales is approximately 97% recurring, driven by our differentiated solutions and value proposition and will continue to remain over 97% recurring in the combined company. After giving effect to the Transactions, the top ten customers for the combined company are expected to represent approximately 12% of total Net sales with the largest customer representing approximately 2% of the combined company Net sales.

Subsubsection Title: Differentiated Business Model with Best in Class Service, Chemistry, and Technology
Subsubsection Text: We believe our suite of comprehensive products and services unlocks customer value as a result of our industry leading employees and innovative technology offerings. Our solutions represent a small portion of our customers’ overall end costs and provide a significant return on investment. Our differentiated service model, with approximately 2,400 of our sales and service engineers on site with our customers, leads to highly recurring, nondiscretionary spending on our products and services, and with our solutions and value propositions including industry leading technology and equipment and artificial intelligence abilities, Solenis was able to achieve $179 million of value-add documented savings for our customers in the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. We offer innovative chemistries to address customers’ operational and sustainability challenges while our technology is at the forefront of the digitization of the water treatment industry. Further, we have product development capabilities to meet customers’ new and evolving needs, based on three main pillars. First, we have approximately 270 dedicated research and development professionals with two-thirds of our annual technology spend supporting those efforts. Second, our innovation pipeline includes approximately 47 projects, representing significant potential run-rate revenue, and features approximately 4,130 patents, including patents for chemical and equipment technologies. In total, Solenis has 2,259 patents issued and 613 patents currently pending, while Diversey has 1,108 patents issued and 150 patents currently pending. Lastly, our strategically located facilities around the world focus on analyzing and diagnosing products and processes, as well as conducting testing to recommend effective improvements that enhance both productivity and quality for our customers. This is critical as new and innovative products carry a higher than average margin and this mix shift is expected to drive increased profitability for our business.

Subsubsection Title: Attractive Financial Profile with Strong Top Line Growth, Expanding Margins, and Robust Free Cash Flow Generation
Subsubsection Text: Our global business has shown strong topline growth, and we believe Solenis’ Net sales is approximately 97% recurring, driven by our differentiated solutions and value proposition and will continue to remain over 97% recurring in the combined company, with the core business growing during the COVID-19 pandemic. By optimizing our cost structure through a strict focus on maximizing operational efficiencies using new technologies, reducing redundancies and leveraging existing infrastructure, we have seen improved Adjusted EBITDA growth and attractive margin expansion. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, our Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies) margin was approximately 18%. Our topline growth and price increases offsetting inflation along with low working capital intensity and minimal capital expenditures allow for significant free cash flow generation. See “—Summary Historical Financial and Pro Forma Financial Data.” 26 -----

Subsubsection Title: Long Tenured, Industry Leading Management Team with Strong Track Record
Subsubsection Text: We have an experienced management team with long tenures in the industry and experience in the sector, which has been recognized as a US Best Managed Company by Deloitte and The Wall Street Journal for 2021, 2022 and 2023. We are led by John E. Panichella, who has been CEO of Solenis since its inception in 2014, following the initial carve-out from Ashland. Through organic growth and M&A, particularly the merger with BASF, Panichella has steered Solenis to global leadership in the specialty chemicals for water-intensive industries. Prior to leading Solenis, John served as President of AWT, SVP of Ashland, Group Operating Officer of Ashland Specialty Ingredients and AWT, and President of Ashland Aqualon Functional ingredients. Surrounding John is a deep bench across operations, technology, commercial and finance, including Philip M. Patterson, Jr, our CFO, Edward Connors, President of the Americas, Jacques Herber, President of Eurasia, and Robert Baird, President of the Pool Solutions business. Our experienced team will drive long-term stability of the business and support future growth.

Subsubsection Title: Well Positioned to Grow with Macro and ESG Mega Trends
Subsubsection Text: We believe our sophisticated product development capabilities meet our customers’ evolving needs and help keep us at the forefront of macroeconomic trends. Our ability to evolve is based on three pillars that allow us to grow our product offering alongside client demands: R&D, Innovation and Customer Application Laboratories. Our R&D team has approximately 270 dedicated professionals and two thirds of annual technology investment supports R&D. Our robust innovation pipeline currently has approximately 47 projects and features approximately 4,130 patents, including those for chemical and equipment technologies. In total we have 3,367 patents issued and 763 patents currently pending. Customer application laboratories are strategically located facilities around the world focused on analyzing and diagnosing products and processes, as well as conducting testing to recommend effective improvements that enhance both productivity and quality. We focus on solving our customers’ environmental and sustainability challenges, placing us at the forefront of the ESG mega trend. Through identification of specific goals such as reduction of water consumption, reduction 27 ----- of energy consumption, reduction of waste emissions or optimization of raw materials utilization, we have been able to work with customers to meet their unique needs. Our sophisticated capabilities have helped customers meet evolving sustainability goals and achieve measurable results.

Subsubsection Title: Pricing Discipline to Drive Margin Growth
Subsubsection Text: We have a track-record of actively monitoring and managing prices, enabling the pass-through of raw material cost increases to maintain margins. Through Solenis’ value-documentation program, sales teams have accountability requirements to show that at least 5% of Net sales deliver a value advantage to customers, which enables price capture even in deflationary environments. This has enabled us to pass through a majority of increases in raw chemical materials, which are one of the major drivers for cost inflation, to customers by adjusting prices accordingly. We began to see a significant increase in the price of our raw materials, including ethylene and propylene, during the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 and we began to pass on price increases to our customers. Typically, we experience an approximately 90-day lag in implementing our price increases, however, during the six months ended March 31, 2023, we exceeded our goals and were able to drive price increases even faster with price exceeding cost during the six months ended March 31, 2023 in all of our business segments. While Diversey continues to adjust prices to pass through increases in raw materials costs, Diversey was slower to react to the inflationary cost environment than Solenis, which resulted in more pronounced margin compression throughout 2022 than Solenis. Once combined, Diversey’s performance is expected to improve as they will operate on Solenis’ value-documentation program. Typically, Diversey experiences an approximately 90-day lag in implementing our price increases, however, during the six months ended March 31, 2023, Diversey exceeded its goals and was able to drive price increases even faster with Cost of goods sold inflation during the six months ended March 31, 2023 in its Institutional Solutions and Food & Beverage segments. The charts below summarize our and Diversey’s success in implementing price increases and maintaining price ahead of cost.

Subsubsection Title: Enhance Profitability Through Identified Synergies and Operational Improvements
Subsubsection Text: We believe that through the realization of the synergies and operational improvement initiatives, which we have identified together with Platinum, we will enhance our profitability and support our strategic initiatives. The approximately $205 million of synergies was identified with the collaboration of the Solenis and Diversey management teams, along with Platinum, and reflect actions which we believe can be implemented within 24 months of the closing of the Transactions. The Platinum team has an extensive track record of leveraging our operational resources to achieve anticipated cost savings. 28 ----- We cannot assure you we will be able to achieve all of these cost synergies. For more information about our anticipated cost synergies and operational improvements, including certain factors that may affect our ability to achieve such cost synergies and operational improvements, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition and the Legacy Acquisitions—We may not achieve some or all of the expected benefits from the items reflected in the adjustments included in Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies).” The prospective unaudited financial information contained in this offering memorandum was not prepared with a view toward compliance with published guidelines of the SEC or the guidelines established by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants for preparation or presentation of prospective financial information. Subsubsection Title: Selectively Pursue Strategic Acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: While our primary focus is on organic growth, our global presence, scale and broad product offering position us well to execute on opportunistic acquisitions given the large and fragmented nature of the markets we serve or to expand into new markets. We estimate that the markets adjacent to our market represent a total market size of $42 billion and represent potential expansion areas, including the ion exchange and coagulants markets. We believe that we can create significant value through strategic acquisitions given our track record of integration. Solenis has completed 17 acquisitions since 2014, including the transformative and successful merger with BASF’s water and paper business in the fiscal year ended September 30, 2019 and the Solenis Acquisition in fiscal year 2022. We will focus on maintaining a disciplined acquisition strategy centered on: (i) expanding our customer base in new and growing end markets and geographies; (ii) improving our customer offering through access to new products and technological capabilities; and (iii) generating significant purchasing and other operational synergies. The graphic below sets forth a summary of our acquisitions since 2014. 29 -----

Subsubsection Title: Strategically Invest in High Return Capital Expenditures Expansion
Subsubsection Text: Our key capital expenditure projects include production capacity expansion for polyvinyl amine (“PVAM”) at our Suffolk, Virginia facility and calcium hypochlorite (cal-hypo) at our Charleston, Tennessee and Kempton Park, South Africa facilities. Our expansion efforts will eliminate existing capacity constraints and better position us to capitalize on customer demand for these high-margin products. Our engineering estimates for all facilities are underway with expansion efforts expected to be online in 2026. We expect the PVAM and cal-hypo expansions to cost $150 million and $100 million, respectively. A majority of our customers, especially those producing packaging and tissue and towel products, are focused on improving strength. We are a market leader in strength chemistry, with the broadest portfolio of synthetic strength additives like PVAM and are the leading supplier of global PVAM production. Previously PVAM was originally sold by BASF and we acquired full commercial rights as part of 2019 merger. However, in advance of the merger, BASF raised prices substantially, resulting in lost sales. Post integration, we refilled the pipeline and returned the product to growth, however, in recent years, our PVAM volumes have been constrained despite debottlenecking programs implemented and we have been unable to return to pre-BASF merger levels. Further, in fiscal year 2022, we experienced shutdowns and product issues resulting in production allocation and customer management challenges. To solve our capacity constraint, we are looking to build incremental capacity at our existing Suffolk, Virginia facility, which is expected to be online by the end of 2026 that will enable us to increase capacity by approximately 100%. Cal-hypo is a highly concentrated source of chlorine in solid form and is a cost-effective solution primarily used for pool sanitization and maintenance with secondary uses to disinfect water in industrial and municipal markets. Our Solenis HTH[ TM] and Poolife[TM] offerings are cal-hypo-based shocks that eliminate the need to drain and refill pools due to over stabilization with other benefits including minimized storage requirements, dry formulation for shelf stability and easy handling, reduced shipping and handling costs and reduced maintenance. We are currently experiencing capacity constraints at our Kempton Park, South Africa facility. Further, given over 50% of global supply is produced in either China or India, importing incremental capacity is both challenging and costly. Due to these constraints, we are looking to expand our capacity. Expansion efforts at our Kempton Park facility are underway and are expected to be completed by fiscal year ended 2023 or 2024. Further, we are pursuing a site selection process for additional capacity including assessing potential new locations, with the expectation that all facilities will be online by 2026. In the interim, we will look to temporarily source incremental capacity via third parties to pre-seed the plant which we believe will drive top line growth in the near team and insourcing savings in the future. Following its return to the United States market, Diversey’s current management team identified potential manufacturing and logistical efficiencies and insourcing opportunities by re-positioning and consolidating certain existing service centers. This supply chain improvement process is referred to as “Project Mega.” Project Mega includes a largely complete consolidation of the North American supply chain footprint through the creation of a manufacturing plant and co-located warehouse in Northern Kentucky, as well as warehouse consolidation in Europe. Diversey started shipping from the new Kentucky warehouse in July 2022 and is consolidating its manufacturing capabilities into the same Kentucky facility. Further, Project Mega is consolidating five Diversey (three Institutional and two Food & Beverage) plants into four plants (two Institutional and two Food & Beverage) and is planning on closing two Wisconsin plants. By co-locating its main warehouse and manufacturing capabilities, and adding more capacity to bring currently contracted volumes in-house and optimizing freight lanes, the project is expected to drive approximately $30 million of annual cost savings. The run rate cost savings includes $11 million related to manufacturing efficiencies from increased insourcing from contract manufacturers, more efficient lines and fixed absorption, co-location of liquid manufacturing and wipes conversion and an optimized flow of processes, $10 million related to logistics and the ability to avoid shipping between sites along with having new sites closer to suppliers and customers, $7 million related to direct savings achieved from materials sourcing using larger orders (i.e. from drums to bulk orders), $1 million related to warehousing from lower rent and co-locating with manufacturing and $2 million related to other. The PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP report incorporated by reference in this offering memorandum relates to Parent’s previously issued financial statements. It does not extend to the prospective unaudited financial information and should not be read to do so.

We believe we are well positioned to grow organically and capture share through several distinct strategies. Supportive end market trends that drove historical growth are expected to continue over the next five to ten years. We have successfully maintained strong pricing discipline to offset inflationary increases to input costs and shift customers to a more profitable mix, driving margin growth. The combination creates unique, value accretive synergy opportunities, with line of sight on approximately $205 million of estimated cost synergies (resulting from actions expected to be taken within 24 months of the closing of the Transactions). Additionally, we achieved $40 million of cost synergies related to the Solenis Acquisition from actions that were taken within 18 months of the Solenis Acquisition Closing Date and we identified $13 million of cost synergies related to the Clearon Acquisition which are expected to be realized from actions already taken or expected to be taken within 24 months of the Clearon Acquisition Closing Date. As of March 31, 2023, we have realized $6.5 million of cost synergies related to the Clearon Acquisition. We are also well positioned to continue to grow through acquisitions via multiple M&A avenues. We have a proven track record as an M&A platform, with 17 transactions completed since 2014, including the transformative fiscal year 2019 merger with BASF’s water and paper business and the Solenis Acquisition in fiscal year 2022. We believe there is an opportunity for both strategic bolt-ons and transformational targets going forward. Subsubsection Title: Solenis
Subsubsection Text: Since the joint venture arrangement with BASF in January 2019, Solenis’ business has principally consisted of three operating segments: Pulp & Paper, Industrial Water, and Reverse Supply Agreements.

Subsubsection Title: Pulp & Paper. The Pulp & Paper (“P&P”) business manufactures and sells a broad array of process
Subsubsection Text: chemistry for the pulp and paper industry including deposit and scale control agents, defoamers, biocides, retention aids and crepe and release additives. These products are designed to deliver benefits such as enhanced operational efficiencies, system cleanliness and superior performance in a wide variety of manufacturing operations globally. In addition, the P&P business offers functional chemistry for packaging, tissue and towel, and printing and writing producers that impart specific properties such as wet or dry strength, colorants, surface size, liquid holdout and printing ability to the final paper or board. Products and technologies include internal and surface sizing agents and wet and dry strength additives.

Subsubsection Title: Industrial Water. The Industrial Water (“IWT”) business offers specialized chemicals for the utility water
Subsubsection Text: treatment market including influent water, boiler water, cooling water and effluent water treatments. Products include scale and corrosion inhibitors, coagulants and flocculants, biocides, defoamers, anti-scaling for desalination, membrane treatments and sludge dewatering. In addition, the IWT business offers process additives such as frothers and collection aids, dust control additives, sterilization treatments, corn oil extraction and scale and corrosion inhibitors for mining and mineral processing, food processing, oil refining, chemicals processing and general manufacturing markets.

Subsubsection Title: Reverse Supply Agreements. As part of the joint venture with BASF in January 2019, Solenis agreed to
Subsubsection Text: provide certain finished goods to BASF, consistent with BASF’s historical cost and pricing structure, intended to allow BASF to uninterruptedly sustain its retained businesses. These arrangements and related activities comprise the Reverse Supply Agreements (“RSA”) segment of Solenis. As part of the resegmentation described below, RSA will become part of the go-forward Industrial Solutions segment. Solenis also provides automated equipment, including performance-based feed and control systems, proprietary monitoring devices and remote system surveillance. The utility products, services and equipment offerings are designed to protect plant assets and optimize energy, water and operational costs at customers’ facilities. As part of the resegmentation described below, equipment destined for packaging mills will become part of the go-forward Consumer Solutions segment. Equipment provided by refineries will form part of the go-forward Industrial Solutions segment.

Subsubsection Title: Sigura
Subsubsection Text: Beginning with the quarter ended March 31, 2021 and following the divestiture of its Surface Water business in October 2020, Sigura moved its commercial pools segment from the previous Industrial, Commercial, Municipal & Surface Water segment (now known as Industrial & Municipal Water segment) to be consolidated with the previous Residential Pool Segment under a newly named Pool Solutions segment. Additionally, Sigura has a third Other segment for other operations. Pools._** Sigura’s pool business offers the sale of sanitizers and other treatment chemicals for pools, spas and water parks. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, Sigura’s Pool segment had Net sales of $540 million, of which 71% was generated in North America, 22% in EMEA and 7% in Latin America. 31 ----- - **_Recreational Water. Sigura’s recreational pool and spa care portfolio brings clean, healthy water to households worldwide with a variety of shock, sanitizers, oxidizers, algaecides and balancers. Sigura’s trusted brands ensure clean and healthy water for its customers’ and consumers’ pools and spas across seasons. - **_Commercial Pools & Spas. Sigura’s commercial pool brands have been at the cutting edge of swimming pool water treatment for over 30 years. Its chlorination solutions are used worldwide for amusement parks, community pools, hotels, resorts, and professional training venues. Sigura specializes in powerful sanitizers, coagulants and pool maintenance products in order to deliver water clarity, color and sparkle to customers’ pools, while ensuring the highest level of water quality, and Sigura’s range of automated feed systems make such professional pool treatment easy to achieve. Industrial & Municipal Water._** Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal Water segment offers treatment of water for drinking, agriculture, irrigation, food processing and industrial applications. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal Water segment had Net sales of $63 million, of which 43% was generated in North America, 43% in EMEA and 14% in Latin America. - **_Industrial Water. Sigura’s Industrial segment (56% of twelve months ended June 30, 2021 total segment sales) is a leading specialty chemical supplier to the global water treatment market and is also a specialty chemical manufacturer. Sigura offers oxidizing and non-oxidizing biocides, feeders and dosing equipment to customers for use in power plants, cooling cycles, food and beverage and the paper industry. The combination of innovative technologies, patented solid biocide feed systems and thorough application knowledge allows Sigura to deliver leading edge solutions to its customers’ most demanding problems. - **_Municipal Water. Sigura’s Municipal segment (44% of twelve months ended June 30, 2021 total segment sales) is focused on helping provide access to clean drinking water and safe water supplies, which is fundamental to human health. Sigura’s global team of drinking water experts provide easy to use, modular chlorination systems, designed to solve each location’s unique operational requirements.

Following a strategic review related to Solenis’ operating segments and in anticipation of the closing of the Solenis Acquisition, changes were introduced in the segment reporting from October 1, 2021 onwards. The segmentation changes were made for the following reasons: (i) to align the segment structure to ensure that our financial reporting segments are in line with its strategic approach in demarcating its operations and (ii) to manage the business and make business decisions based on product lines and services in the most effective manner. Major changes to highlight included: (i) the creation of a new Pool Solutions segment to account for the contribution of Sigura’s Pools segment, focused on delivering products for the treatment of pools, spas and water parks, (ii) the renaming of the Pulp & Paper business as the Consumer Solutions business, (iii) the renaming of the Industrial Water business as the Industrial Solutions business, (iv) the reallocation of the food processing aspects of the business from the newly named Industrial Solutions business to sit with the other consumer-based products and services within the newly named Consumer Solutions business, (v) the reallocation of the pulp processing aspects of the business from the newly named Consumer Solutions business to sit with the other industrial-focused products and services within the newly named Industrial Solutions segment, (vi) the contribution of Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal Water business to the newly named Industrial Solutions segment and (vii) the inclusion of Solenis’ RSA business within the newly named Industrial Solutions segment. Consumer Solutions._** The Pulp & Paper segment of the historical Solenis business was renamed as the Consumer Solutions segment. The Consumer Solutions segment is mostly affected by the removal of Pulp and its reallocation to the Industrial Water segment (now renamed as the Industrial Solutions segment). Industrial Solutions._** The Industrial Water segment of the historical Solenis business was renamed as the Industrial Solutions segment. The Industrial Solutions segment is mostly affected by the inclusion of the RSA 32 ----- segment, the removal of Food and its reallocation to the Pulp & Paper segment (now renamed the Consumer Solutions segment) and the contribution of Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal business. Pool Solutions._** Sigura’s Pool segment, including residential and commercial pools, forms the new Pool Solutions business segment.

Subsubsection Title: The Acquisition
Subsubsection Text: On March 8, 2023, Parent, Merger Sub and Diversey entered into the Acquisition Agreement, pursuant to which Merger Sub will merge with and into Diversey, with Diversey surviving, following which Diversey will be a wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent. At the effective time of the Acquisition, Merger Sub will merge with and into Diversey, with Diversey surviving the merger as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent, each issued and outstanding share of common stock, par value $0.0001 per share of Diversey (other than dissenting shares) (the “Diversey Common Stock”), will automatically be converted into the right to receive, in respect of shareholders other than BCPE (the controlling shareholder of Diversey and an affiliate of Bain Capital), $8.40 per share, and, in respect of BCPE $7.84 per share, in each case, without interest and less any applicable withholding taxes and BCPE will also rollover a portion of its Diversey Common Stock into an affiliate of the Sponsor, and each share of Diversey Common Stock will be cancelled, cease to be outstanding and cease to exist, and the Diversey shareholders will cease to have any other rights with respect to their Diversey Common Stock. Parent will be deemed to be the accounting acquirer for purposes of the Transactions. The purchase price for the Acquisition will be financed through: - proceeds of the Notes offered hereby; - borrowings under a new tranche of the Term Loan; - the New Perpetual Preferred Equity Investment; and - the New Equity Contribution. For a detailed discussion of the expected sources and uses of funds for the Transactions, see “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions,” and “Description of Notes.” The consummation of the Acquisition is subject to various customary closing conditions, including, among others, (i) the affirmative vote in favor of adoption of the Acquisition Agreement by holders of at least two thirds of the shares of Diversey Common Stock then outstanding and entitled to vote thereon, (ii) the expiration or early termination of the waiting periods under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act (the “HSR Act”), (iii) the absence of any order of any court of competent jurisdiction or other legal or regulatory restraint or prohibition preventing the consummation of the Acquisition or enjoining or prohibiting the consummation of the Acquisition that continues to be in effect, (iv) completion of any required information and/or consultation on procedures with a labor organization, (v) the absence of a Company Material Adverse Effect (as defined in the Acquisition Agreement), (vi) the accuracy of the representations and warranties contained in the Acquisition Agreement (subject to certain materiality qualifications), (vii) compliance with the covenants and agreements contained in the Acquisition Agreement and (viii) obtaining certain specified regulatory approvals. The Acquisition Agreement contains certain termination rights, including the right to terminate if the Acquisition has not been consummated by the Outside Date. The Acquisition Agreement also contains customary representations, warranties and covenants. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, Diversey generated revenue and Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) of $2.8 billion and $352 million, respectively, reflecting a 13% Adjusted EBITDA margin. 33 -----

Subsubsection Title: The Offering, Escrow and Escrow Release
Subsubsection Text: This offering may close concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition. If this offering closes prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, the Escrow Issuer will issue the Notes and deposit (or cause to be deposited) the gross proceeds from the sale of each series of Notes into separate segregated escrow accounts pursuant to the Escrow Agreement. At such time and until the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, each series of Notes will be secured by a first-priority security interest in the applicable escrow account and the deposits and investments therein. The Escrow Release will be subject to the Escrow Release Conditions. Unless the Acquisition closes substantially concurrently with, or prior to, this offering, substantially concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition, the Escrow Issuer will consummate the Escrow Merger, pursuant to which it will merge with and into the Ultimate Issuer, with the Ultimate Issuer ultimately continuing as the surviving entity. Assuming the Escrow Release Conditions have been satisfied, on the Acquisition Closing Date, the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors will become parties to the Indenture pursuant to one or more supplemental indentures, the Escrow Issuer will cease to exist as a result of the Escrow Merger and the obligations under the Indenture will become obligations of the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors. The escrowed funds will be released from escrow to consummate the Acquisition even if a default or event of default has occurred and is continuing under the Indenture. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—If the Acquisition is completed on or prior to the Outside Date and the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, the proceeds from the Notes will be released from escrow even if a default or event of default under the Indenture has or would have occurred and is continuing.” In the event that (a) the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date, (b) at any time prior to the Outside Date, the Escrow Release Conditions are deemed, in the Escrow Issuer’s good faith judgment, to be incapable of being satisfied on or prior to the Outside Date, or (c) at any time prior to the Outside Date, the Acquisition Agreement is terminated in accordance with its terms without the closing of the Acquisition, each series of Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption at a price equal to 100% of the initial issue price of such series of Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date, to, but excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—In the event that the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption, and, as a result, you may not obtain the return you expect on the applicable series of Notes.” The escrowed funds will be limited to the gross proceeds from this offering of the Notes, together with any earnings thereon and investments thereof, if any, and will not include cash to fund any accrued and unpaid interest on the Notes that may be payable in the event of a special mandatory redemption. The Ultimate Issuer or one of its affiliates will issue the Equity Commitment Letter to the Escrow Issuer, for the benefit of the Trustee, the Escrow Agent and the holders of the Notes, to transfer to the Escrow Issuer an amount necessary to fund the payment of accrued and unpaid interest on the Notes in the event of a special mandatory redemption, plus certain fees and expenses. If this offering closes substantially concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition, the Notes will not be subject to the escrow procedures described in this offering memorandum. For additional information regarding the terms of, and procedures relating to, the escrow, see “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”

Subsubsection Title: The Refinancing
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and, if applicable, the satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, we will consummate the Refinancing using proceeds from the Notes, borrowings under a new incremental tranche of the Term Loan Facility, the New Perpetual Preferred Equity Investment and the New Equity Contribution. 34 -----

Subsubsection Title: The Credit Facilities
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and, if applicable, the satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, the Issuer intends to borrow an incremental $750 million tranche under the Term Loan Facility and to increase the available capacity under its ABL Revolving Credit Facility to provide for borrowings of up to $700 million, subject to borrowing base capacity.

Subsubsection Title: New Equity Contribution and New Perpetual Preferred Equity
Subsubsection Text: As part of the Acquisition, the Sponsor will fund a portion of the New Equity Contribution of approximately $950 million in cash to an indirect parent of Parent, which will, through a series of transactions, ultimately be contributed to Parent and which will be used as part of the consideration to be paid in connection with the Acquisition. In addition as part of the Acquisition, BCPE will rollover: (i) approximately $617 million of its existing equity interests in Diversey into common units in an indirect parent of Parent as part of the New Equity Contribution; and (ii) approximately $438 million of its existing equity interests in Diversey into preferred units in an indirect parent of Parent as the New Perpetual Preferred Equity, in each case, in satisfaction of a portion of the consideration payable to BCPE under the Acquisition. From the Acquisition Closing Date until the first anniversary thereof, Platinum or its affiliates may acquire the New Perpetual Preferred Equity from BCPE. Platinum may exercise this option in its sole discretion following the closing of the Transactions. 35 -----

This chart is provided for illustrative purposes only and does not represent all legal entities affiliated with, or all obligations of, the combined Solenis company and its affiliates: (1) Prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, the Notes will not be guaranteed. From and after satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions and immediately following the consummation of the Acquisition (or on the Issue Date if the Acquisition closes concurrently with or prior to this offering), subject to certain exceptions, the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by each of the Guarantors. (2) For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, our nonGuarantor subsidiaries represented approximately 68% of our Net sales and approximately 63% of our Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA. As of March 31, 2023, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, our non-Guarantor subsidiaries represented approximately 60% of our total assets (excluding intercompany receivables and investments in subsidiaries) and approximately 43% of our total liabilities (excluding intercompany payables). (3) The Issuer had total direct indebtedness of $4,398 million as of March 31, 2023, comprising the amounts outstanding under the Existing Notes, the ABL Revolving Credit Facility and the Term Loan Facility. The Issuer also had $440 million of undrawn capacity under the ABL Revolving Credit Facility, subject to borrowing base capacity. See “Description of Certain Indebtedness” for a description of these debt commitments. (4) In connection with the Transactions, the Issuer intends to borrow an incremental $750 million tranche under the Term Loan Facility and to increase the available capacity under its ABL Revolving Credit Facility to provide for borrowings of up to $700 million, subject to borrowing base capacity. (5) This offering may close concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition. If this offering closes prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, the Escrow Issuer will deposit (or cause to be deposited) the gross proceeds from the sale of each series of Notes into separate segregated escrow accounts pursuant to the Escrow Agreement. At such time and until the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, each series of Notes will be secured by a first-priority security interest in the 36 ----- applicable escrow account and the deposits and investments therein. The Escrow Release will be subject to the Escrow Release Conditions. Unless the Acquisition closes substantially concurrently with, or prior to, this offering, substantially concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition, the Escrow Issuer will consummate the Escrow Merger, pursuant to which it will merge with and into the Ultimate Issuer, with the Ultimate Issuer ultimately continuing as the surviving entity. Assuming the Escrow Release Conditions have been satisfied, on the Acquisition Closing Date, the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors will become parties to the Indenture pursuant to one or more supplemental indentures, the Escrow Issuer will cease to exist as a result of the Escrow Merger and the obligations under the Indenture will become obligations of the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors.

Founded in 1995 by Tom Gores, Platinum is a global investment firm with approximately $47 billion of assets under management and a portfolio of approximately 50 operating companies that serve customers around the world. Platinum specializes in mergers, acquisitions and operations – a trademarked strategy it calls M&A&O® – acquiring and operating companies in a broad range of business markets, including manufacturing, distribution, transportation and logistics, equipment rental, metals services, media and entertainment, technology, telecommunications and other industries. Over the past 27 years Platinum has completed more than 400 acquisitions. 38 -----
