Although no such amendment, waiver or consent is presently contemplated, if the parties to the Acquisition Agreement decide to make changes to the terms thereof (including to the purchase price) or to waive conditions thereunder, the holders of the Notes will not be able to prevent the release of the escrowed property to fund the Acquisition as a result of any such action or object to any such amendment and will not have any veto or consent rights in respect of any such actions.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness
Subsubsection Title: If the Acquisition is completed on or prior to the Outside Date and the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, the proceeds from the Notes will be released from escrow even if a default or event of default under the Indenture has or would have occurred and is continuing.
Subsubsection Text: The escrowed funds will be released from escrow and utilized as described under “Use of Proceeds” upon the Escrow Issuer’s delivery to the Escrow Agent of an officer’s certificate stating that the conditions to the release of the proceeds from escrow have been satisfied. The escrowed funds will be released from escrow even if a default or event of default under the Indenture has occurred and is continuing. 100 -----

Subsubsection Title: The Offering, Escrow and Escrow Release
Subsubsection Text: This offering may close concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition. If this offering closes prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, the Escrow Issuer will issue the Notes and deposit (or cause to be deposited) the gross proceeds from the sale of each series of Notes into separate segregated escrow accounts pursuant to the Escrow Agreement. At such time and until the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, each series of Notes will be secured by a first-priority security interest in the applicable escrow account and the deposits and 101 ----- investments therein. The Escrow Release will be subject to the Escrow Release Conditions. Unless the Acquisition closes substantially concurrently with, or prior to, this offering, substantially concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition, the Escrow Issuer will consummate the Escrow Merger, pursuant to which it will merge with and into the Ultimate Issuer, with the Ultimate Issuer ultimately continuing as the surviving entity. Assuming the Escrow Release Conditions have been satisfied, on the Acquisition Closing Date, the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors will become parties to the Indenture pursuant to one or more supplemental indentures, the Escrow Issuer will cease to exist as a result of the Escrow Merger and the obligations under the Indenture will become obligations of the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors. The escrowed funds will be released from escrow to consummate the Acquisition even if a default or event of default has occurred and is continuing under the Indenture. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—If the Acquisition is completed on or prior to the Outside Date and the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, the proceeds from the Notes will be released from escrow even if a default or event of default under the Indenture has or would have occurred and is continuing.” In the event that (a) the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date, (b) at any time prior to the Outside Date, the Escrow Release Conditions are deemed, in the Escrow Issuer’s good faith judgment, to be incapable of being satisfied on or prior to the Outside Date, or (c) at any time prior to the Outside Date, the Acquisition Agreement is terminated in accordance with its terms without the closing of the Acquisition, each series of Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption at a price equal to 100% of the initial issue price of such series of Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date, to, but excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—In the event that the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption, and, as a result, you may not obtain the return you expect on the applicable series of Notes.” The escrowed funds will be limited to the gross proceeds from this offering of the Notes, together with any earnings thereon and investments thereof, if any, and will not include cash to fund any accrued and unpaid interest on the Notes that may be payable in the event of a special mandatory redemption. The Ultimate Issuer or one of its affiliates will issue the Equity Commitment Letter to the Escrow Issuer, for the benefit of the Trustee, the Escrow Agent and the holders of the Notes, to transfer to the Escrow Issuer an amount necessary to fund the payment of accrued and unpaid interest on the Notes in the event of a special mandatory redemption, plus certain fees and expenses. If this offering closes substantially concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition, the Notes will not be subject to the escrow procedures described in this offering memorandum. For additional information regarding the terms of, and procedures relating to, the escrow, see “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”

Subsubsection Title: The Refinancing
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and, if applicable, the satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, we will consummate the Refinancing using proceeds from the Notes, borrowings under a new incremental tranche of the Term Loan Facility, the New Perpetual Preferred Equity Investment and the New Equity Contribution.

Subsubsection Title: The Credit Facilities
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and, if applicable, the satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, the Issuer intends to borrow an incremental $750 million tranche under the Term Loan Facility and to increase the available capacity under its ABL Revolving Credit Facility to provide for borrowings of up to $700 million, subject to borrowing base capacity. 102 -----

Subsubsection Title: New Equity Contribution and New Perpetual Preferred Equity
Subsubsection Text: As part of the Acquisition, the Sponsor will fund a portion of the New Equity Contribution of approximately $950 million in cash to an indirect parent of Parent, which will, through a series of transactions, ultimately be contributed to Parent and which will be used as part of the consideration to be paid in connection with the Acquisition. In addition as part of the Acquisition, BCPE will rollover: (i) approximately $617 million of its existing equity interests in Diversey into common units in an indirect parent of Parent as part of the New Equity Contribution; and (ii) approximately $438 million of its existing equity interests in Diversey into preferred units in an indirect parent of Parent as the New Perpetual Preferred Equity, in each case, in satisfaction of a portion of the consideration payable to BCPE under the Acquisition. From the Acquisition Closing Date until the first anniversary thereof, Platinum or its affiliates may acquire the New Perpetual Preferred Equity from BCPE. Platinum may exercise this option in its sole discretion following the closing of the Transactions. 103 -----

On March 8, 2023, Parent, Merger Sub and Diversey entered into the Acquisition Agreement, pursuant to which Merger Sub will merge with and into Diversey, with Diversey surviving, following which Diversey will be a wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent. At the effective time of the Acquisition, Merger Sub will merge with and into Diversey, with Diversey surviving the merger as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent, each issued and outstanding share of common stock, par value $0.0001 per share of Diversey (other than dissenting shares) (the “Diversey Common Stock”), will automatically be converted into the right to receive, in respect of shareholders other than BCPE (the controlling shareholder of Diversey and an affiliate of Bain Capital), $8.40 per share, and, in respect of BCPE $7.84 per share, in each case, without interest and less any applicable withholding taxes and BCPE will also rollover a portion of its Diversey Common Stock into an affiliate of the Sponsor, and each share of Diversey Common Stock will be cancelled, cease to be outstanding and cease to exist, and the Diversey shareholders will cease to have any other rights with respect to their Diversey Common Stock. Parent will be deemed to be the accounting acquirer for purposes of the Transactions. The purchase price for the Acquisition will be financed through: - proceeds of the Notes offered hereby; - borrowings under a new tranche of the Term Loan; - the New Perpetual Preferred Equity Investment; and - the New Equity Contribution. For a detailed discussion of the expected sources and uses of funds for the Transactions, see “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions,” and “Description of Notes.” The consummation of the Acquisition is subject to various customary closing conditions, including, among others, (i) the affirmative vote in favor of adoption of the Acquisition Agreement by holders of at least two thirds of the shares of Diversey Common Stock then outstanding and entitled to vote thereon, (ii) the expiration or early termination of the waiting periods under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act (the “HSR Act”), (iii) the absence of any order of any court of competent jurisdiction or other legal or regulatory restraint or prohibition preventing the consummation of the Acquisition or enjoining or prohibiting the consummation of the Acquisition that continues to be in effect, (iv) completion of any required information and/or consultation on procedures with a labor organization, (v) the absence of a Company Material Adverse Effect (as defined in the Acquisition Agreement), (vi) the accuracy of the representations and warranties contained in the Acquisition Agreement (subject to certain materiality qualifications), (vii) compliance with the covenants and agreements contained in the Acquisition Agreement and (viii) obtaining certain specified regulatory approvals. The Acquisition Agreement contains certain termination rights, including the right to terminate if the Acquisition has not been consummated by the Outside Date. The Acquisition Agreement also contains customary representations, warranties and covenants. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, Diversey generated revenue and Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) of $2.8 billion and $352 million, respectively, reflecting a 13% Adjusted EBITDA margin.

If any of those risks actually occur, our business, financial condition and results of operations would suffer and you could lose all or part of your original investment in the Notes. Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: On March 8, 2023, Parent, Merger Sub and Diversey entered into that certain Agreement and Plan of Merger (the “Acquisition Agreement”), pursuant to which Merger Sub will merge with and into Diversey, with Diversey surviving, following which Diversey will be a wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent. The Escrow Issuer was incorporated on April 27, 2023 in contemplation of the Transactions. The Issuer is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent and does not have any results of operations or material financial positions. The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information of Parent is derived from: (a) the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Parent Financial Information (as defined herein); and (b) the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Diversey Financial Information (as defined herein) (collectively, the “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information”). The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Parent Financial Information included in the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information is presented herein for the Solenis business, reported at the level of Parent and is derived from: (a) the unaudited pro forma condensed Parent balance sheet as of March 31, 2023 with the explanatory notes thereto (the “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Parent Balance Sheet”) and (b) the unaudited _pro forma condensed Parent statement of operations data for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, together_ with the related explanatory notes thereto (the “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Parent Statement of Operations” and, together with the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Solenis Balance Sheet, the “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Parent Financial Information”). The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Diversey Financial Information included in the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information is presented herein for the Diversey business, reported at the level of Diversey Holdings, Ltd. and is derived from: (a) the unaudited pro forma condensed Diversey balance sheet as of March 31, 2023 with the explanatory notes thereto (the “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Diversey Balance Sheet” and, together with the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Parent Balance Sheet, the “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Balance Sheet”) and (b) the unaudited pro forma condensed Diversey statement of operations data for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 (the “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Diversey Statement of Operations” and, (i) together with the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Diversey Balance Sheet, the “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Diversey Financial Information,” and, (ii) together with the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Parent Statement of Operations, the “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Statement of Operations”). The fiscal year end of Diversey, which is December 31, has not been conformed to the fiscal year end of Solenis, which is September 30, for the purpose of presenting the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information. The unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated financial information included in “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information” has not been updated to reflect the actual aggregate principal amount of the Notes, or the actual interest rates, sizing between the Dollar and Euro tranches or exchange rates for the Notes. As a result, the pro forma combined interest expense, pro forma combined net income, pro forma total liabilities and pro forma stockholders’ equity (deficit) amounts included herein have not been updated to reflect the actual aggregate principal amount of the Notes or the actual interest rates, sizing between the Dollar and Euro tranches or exchange rates of the Notes and may differ materially from actual amounts. The following Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information is presented to illustrate the effects of the Acquisition, including the payment of the consideration in connection therewith, as well as the repayment in full, or the satisfaction and discharge in full of the obligations under any governing instruments, as applicable, of the existing indebtedness of Diversey (the “Refinancing”) (which includes the issuance of the Notes). The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information is prepared, unless otherwise specified, on a basis that is consistent with the accounting policies used in the preparation of the audited financial statements of Parent as of September 30, 2022. The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Statement of Operations for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 gives pro forma effect to the Transactions as if they had occurred on April 1, 2022. The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Balance Sheet gives pro forma effect to the Transactions as if they were completed on March 31, 2023. The historical consolidated financial information of each of the Solenis business (reported at the level of Parent) and the Diversey business (reported at the level of Diversey Holdings, Ltd.) has been adjusted to give pro 108 ----- _forma effect to the transaction accounting adjustments related to the Transactions in accordance with U.S. GAAP._ The assumptions underlying the pro forma adjustments are described fully in the accompanying notes, which should be read in conjunction with the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information. The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Article 11 of Regulation S-X as promulgated by the SEC under the Securities Act or any generally accepted accounting standards. The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information has been presented for informational purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of the combined financial position or results of operations that would have been realized had the Transactions occurred as of the dates indicated, nor is it meant to be indicative of any anticipated combined financial position or future results of operations that the combined group will experience after the transactions. In addition, the accompanying Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Statement of Operations does not include any expected cost savings, operating synergies, or other transaction effects that have occurred or are reasonably expected to occur. 109 -----

Subsubsection Title: The Offering, Escrow and Escrow Release
Subsubsection Text: This offering may close concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition. If this offering closes prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, the Escrow Issuer will issue the Notes and deposit (or cause to be deposited) the gross proceeds from the sale of each series of Notes into separate segregated escrow accounts pursuant to the Escrow Agreement. At such time and until the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, each series of Notes will be secured by a first-priority security interest in the applicable escrow account and the deposits and investments therein. The Escrow Release will be subject to the Escrow Release Conditions. Unless the Acquisition closes substantially concurrently with, or prior to, this offering, substantially concurrently with the consummation of 112 ----- the Acquisition, the Escrow Issuer will consummate the Escrow Merger, pursuant to which it will merge with and into the Ultimate Issuer, with the Ultimate Issuer ultimately continuing as the surviving entity. Assuming the Escrow Release Conditions have been satisfied, on the Acquisition Closing Date, the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors will become parties to the Indenture pursuant to one or more supplemental indentures, the Escrow Issuer will cease to exist as a result of the Escrow Merger and the obligations under the Indenture will become obligations of the Ultimate Issuer and the Guarantors. The escrowed funds will be released from escrow to consummate the Acquisition even if a default or event of default has occurred and is continuing under the Indenture. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—If the Acquisition is completed on or prior to the Outside Date and the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, the proceeds from the Notes will be released from escrow even if a default or event of default under the Indenture has or would have occurred and is continuing.” In the event that (a) the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date, (b) at any time prior to the Outside Date, the Escrow Release Conditions are deemed, in the Escrow Issuer’s good faith judgment, to be incapable of being satisfied on or prior to the Outside Date, or (c) at any time prior to the Outside Date, the Acquisition Agreement is terminated in accordance with its terms without the closing of the Acquisition, each series of Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption at a price equal to 100% of the initial issue price of such series of Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date, to, but excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—In the event that the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption, and, as a result, you may not obtain the return you expect on the applicable series of Notes.” The escrowed funds will be limited to the gross proceeds from this offering of the Notes, together with any earnings thereon and investments thereof, if any, and will not include cash to fund any accrued and unpaid interest on the Notes that may be payable in the event of a special mandatory redemption. The Ultimate Issuer or one of its affiliates will issue the Equity Commitment Letter to the Escrow Issuer, for the benefit of the Trustee, the Escrow Agent and the holders of the Notes, to transfer to the Escrow Issuer an amount necessary to fund the payment of accrued and unpaid interest on the Notes in the event of a special mandatory redemption, plus certain fees and expenses. If this offering closes substantially concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition, the Notes will not be subject to the escrow procedures described in this offering memorandum. For additional information regarding the terms of, and procedures relating to, the escrow, see “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED STATEMENT OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: NOTES TO UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS Note 1 — Description of the Transactions Acquisition
Subsubsection Title: The Refinancing
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and, if applicable, the satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, we will consummate the Refinancing using proceeds from the Notes, borrowings under a new incremental tranche of the Term Loan Facility, the New Perpetual Preferred Equity Investment and the New Equity Contribution.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED STATEMENT OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: NOTES TO UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS Note 1 — Description of the Transactions Acquisition
Subsubsection Title: The Credit Facilities
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and, if applicable, the satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, the Issuer intends to borrow an incremental $750 million tranche under the Term Loan Facility and to increase the available capacity under its ABL Revolving Credit Facility to provide for borrowings of up to $700 million, subject to borrowing base capacity.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED STATEMENT OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: NOTES TO UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS Note 1 — Description of the Transactions Acquisition
Subsubsection Title: New Equity Contribution and New Perpetual Preferred Equity
Subsubsection Text: As part of the Acquisition, the Sponsor will fund a portion of the New Equity Contribution of approximately $950 million in cash to an indirect parent of Parent, which will, through a series of transactions, ultimately be contributed to Parent and which will be used as part of the consideration to be paid in connection with the Acquisition. In addition as part of the Acquisition, BCPE will rollover: (i) approximately $617 million of its existing equity interests in Diversey into common units in an indirect parent of Parent as part of the New Equity Contribution; and (ii) approximately $438 million of its existing equity interests in Diversey into preferred units in 113 ----- an indirect parent of Parent as the New Perpetual Preferred Equity, in each case, in satisfaction of a portion of the consideration payable to BCPE under the Acquisition. From the Acquisition Closing Date until the first anniversary thereof, Platinum or its affiliates may acquire the New Perpetual Preferred Equity from BCPE. Platinum may exercise this option in its sole discretion following the closing of the Transactions.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED STATEMENT OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: NOTES TO UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS Note 1 — Description of the Transactions Acquisition
Subsubsection Text: On March 8, 2023, Parent, Merger Sub and Diversey entered into the Acquisition Agreement, pursuant to which Merger Sub will merge with and into Diversey, with Diversey surviving, following which Diversey will be a wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent. At the effective time of the Acquisition, each issued and outstanding share of common stock, par value $0.0001 per share of Diversey (other than dissenting shares) (the “Diversey Common Stock”), will automatically be converted into the right to receive, in respect of shareholders other than BCPE (the controlling shareholder of Diversey and an affiliate of Bain Capital), $8.40 per share, and, in respect of BCPE $7.84 per share, in each case, without interest and less any applicable withholding taxes and BCPE will also rollover a portion of its Diversey Common Stock into an affiliate of the Sponsor, and each share of Diversey Common Stock will be cancelled, cease to be outstanding and cease to exist, and the Diversey shareholders will cease to have any other rights with respect to their Diversey Common Stock. Parent will be deemed to be the accounting acquirer for purposes of the Transactions. The purchase price for the Acquisition will be financed through: - proceeds of the Notes offered hereby; - borrowings under a new tranche of the Term Loan; - the New Perpetual Preferred Equity Investment; and - the New Equity Contribution. For a detailed discussion of the expected sources and uses of funds for the Transactions, see “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions,” and “Description of Notes.” The consummation of the Acquisition is subject to various customary closing conditions, including, among others, (i) the affirmative vote in favor of adoption of the Acquisition Agreement by holders of at least two thirds of the shares of Diversey Common Stock then outstanding and entitled to vote thereon, (ii) the expiration or early termination of the waiting periods under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act (the “HSR Act”), (iii) the absence of any order of any court of competent jurisdiction or other legal or regulatory restraint or prohibition preventing the consummation of the Acquisition or enjoining or prohibiting the consummation of the Acquisition that continues to be in effect, (iv) completion of any required information and/or consultation on procedures with a labor organization, (v) the absence of a Company Material Adverse Effect (as defined in the Acquisition Agreement), (vi) the accuracy of the representations and warranties contained in the Acquisition Agreement (subject to certain materiality qualifications), (vii) compliance with the covenants and agreements contained in the Acquisition Agreement and (viii) obtaining certain specified regulatory approvals. The Acquisition Agreement contains certain termination rights, including the right to terminate if the Acquisition has not been consummated by the Outside Date. The Acquisition Agreement also contains customary representations, warranties and covenants. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, Diversey generated revenue and Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) of $2.8 billion and $352 million, respectively, reflecting a 13% Adjusted EBITDA margin.

Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED STATEMENT OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information was prepared using the acquisition method of accounting in accordance with Accounting Standards Codification (“ASC”) Topic 805, Business Combinations (“ASC 805”), and using the fair value concepts defined in ASC Topic 820, Fair Value Measurement (“ASC 820”) and based on the historical consolidated financial statements of Solenis and Diversey. Under ASC 805, all Solenis assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination are recognized and measured at their assumed acquisition date fair value, while transaction costs and restructuring costs associated with the business combination are expensed as incurred. The excess of merger consideration over the fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed, if any, is allocated to goodwill. The allocation of the purchase consideration for the Acquisition depends upon certain estimates and assumptions, all of which are preliminary. The allocation of the purchase consideration has been made for the purpose of developing the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information. A final determination of fair values of assets acquired and liabilities assumed relating to the Acquisition could differ materially from the preliminary allocation of the purchase consideration. This final valuation will be based on the actual net tangible and intangible assets of Solenis and Diversey existing at the acquisition date. Pursuant to the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, the Acquisition is expected to close the month in which all the requisite closing conditions have been satisfied. The final valuation may materially change the allocation of the purchase consideration, which could materially affect the fair values assigned to the assets and liabilities and could result in a material change to the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information. The transaction accounting adjustments represent management’s best estimates and are based upon currently available information and certain assumptions that management believes are reasonable under the circumstances. The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information presented is for illustrative purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of the financial position or results of operations that would have been realized if the Acquisition had been completed on the dates indicated, nor is it indicative of future operating results or financial position. We have undertaken a preliminary review of both Solenis’ and Diversey’s accounting policies and did not identify any significant adjustments that would be required to be made in order to conform the accounting policies of the companies. 114 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Text: Solenis is a leading supplier of specialty chemicals and services to the pulp and paper, mining, food and beverage, power generation, refining, chemical processing, general manufacturing, municipal and pools markets. It offers chemical and equipment technologies and services designed to help customers improve operational efficiencies, enhance product quality, protect plant assets and minimize environmental impact. To meet the diverse requirements of its customers, Solenis offers a range of services, including start-up and ongoing applications support, analytical and applications laboratories and customized program offerings. Solenis’ products include biocides, cleaners, coagulants and flocculants, converting additives, corrosion inhibitors, defoamers, deposit control agents, food and beverage processing aids, internal and surface size agents, membrane treatments, mining and mineral processing aids, monitoring and control systems, odor inhibitors and neutralizers, oxygen scavengers, polyacrylamides, pulp mill additives, retention, drainage and clarification aids, scale inhibitors, sludge dewatering polymers, surface treatments, tissue making additives, wet- and dry-strength additives, colorants, surface size, antiscalants for desalination, and wood adhesives. Within the pools market (via the legacy Sigura business), Solenis is a leading supplier of sanitizers and other water treatment solutions featuring top consumer brands in residential and commercial pool and industrial water care markets. As of March 31, 2023, Solenis had 49 manufacturing facilities in 22 countries. Parent markets and distributes its products and services directly and through third-party distributors in the Americas, Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia Pacific. Solenis’ business principally consists of three operating segments: (1) Consumer, (2) Industrial (which integrates Solenis’ prior Industrial Water business and the operating results of its reverse supply agreements with BASF as well as Sigura’s Industrial business) and (3) Pools. A brief description for each of these operating segments is as follows: Consumer Solutions – The Consumer Solutions business manufactures and sells a broad array of process chemistry for the pulp and paper industry including deposit and scale control agents, defoamers, biocides, retention aids and crepe and release additives. These products are designed to deliver benefits such as enhanced operational efficiencies, system cleanliness and superior performance in a wide variety of manufacturing operations globally. In addition, the Consumer Solutions business offers functional chemistry for packaging, tissue and towel, and printing and writing producers that impart specific properties such as wet or dry strength, colorants, surface size, liquid holdout and printing ability to the final paper or board. Products and technologies include internal and surface sizing agents and wet and dry strength additives. Industrial Solutions – The Industrial Solutions business offers specialized chemicals for the utility water treatment market including influent water, boiler water, cooling water and effluent water treatments. Products include scale and corrosion inhibitors, coagulants and flocculants, biocides, defoamers, anti-scaling for desalination, membrane treatments and sludge dewatering. In addition, the Industrial Solutions business offers process additives such as frothers and collection aids, dust control additives, sterilization treatments, corn oil extraction and scale and corrosion inhibitors for mining and mineral processing, food processing, oil refining, chemicals processing and general manufacturing markets. The Industrial Solutions business includes the operating results of Solenis’ reverse supply agreements through which Solenis agreed via the joint venture with BASF to provide certain finished goods 126 ----- to BASF at below-market prices, consistent with BASF’s historical cost and pricing structure. Such agreements are intended to allow BASF to uninterruptedly sustain the businesses that BASF retained after the joint venture between Solenis and BASF which were previously serviced by BASF Paper & Water. Pools - The Pool Solutions business offers water care products and value-added services offered for residential and commercial pools and spas in consumer channels such as Mass Retail, Professional Dealer and Commercial and services top consumer brands in pool care markets. Key brands include, but are not limited to HTH®, Poolife®, GLB®, Leisure Time®, Sirona Spa Care®, and HTH Spa®. Solenis also manufactures and supplies automated equipment, including performance-based feed and control systems, proprietary monitoring devices and remote system surveillance. The utility products, services and equipment offerings are designed to protect plant assets and optimize energy, water and operational costs at customers’ facilities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Net sales
Subsubsection Text: We generate revenue from the sale of products and services within each of the four geographic markets that we serve. Our Net sales represents gross revenue net of estimates for returns and price allowances. Price allowances are inclusive of discounts for prompt payment, customer specific rebates, continuous improvement rebates, and other volume based incentives. Our overall Net sales are impacted by the following factors: - Fluctuations in overall economic activity within the geographic markets that we serve; - Fluctuations in foreign exchange rates; - Changes in the prices charged for products and services; - Changes in the overall volume of customers served based on underlying fluctuations in supply and demand; - Changes in the level of competition in the marketplace, either via price, or the launch of new products by competitors; - Changes in the application or applied usage of our products and services; and - Sales and amortization of reverse supply agreements acquired as part of the acquisition of BASF Paper & Water.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Cost of sales
Subsubsection Text: Our Cost of sales consists primarily of the following: - _Materials and production costs: We purchase raw materials from a global network of suppliers to support the production of finished products and the delivery of services; - _Employee Costs: To retain the talent necessary to deliver high-quality products and services, we incur significant employee compensation and benefits costs. Payroll costs recognized via Cost of sales relate specifically to those employees involved in the manufacturing process; - _Depreciation and Amortization Expense: Property, plant and equipment are stated at cost and depreciated based on their estimated useful lives. Acquired property, plant and equipment and definitelived intangible assets are recognized at their acquired fair values and amortized over their respective useful lives. Assets specifically related to the production of goods and services such as an allocated portion of costs incurred for our plant and buildings, and machine and equipment as well as amortization expense relative to patents, process know-how and supply agreements are recognized via _Cost of sales; and_ 127 ----- - _Other: Remaining Cost of sales relates to freight costs, warehousing expenses, costs associated with the idling of production facilities, product claims, or other general manufacturing costs. Our overall Cost of sales is impacted by the following factors: - Changes in the price of raw materials, i.e. deflationary or inflationary price changes in the costs of commodities; - Production volumes and utilization; - Improvement in production efficiency or other post-acquisition process improvements or cost savings initiatives; and - Fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Selling, general and administrative expense
Subsubsection Text: Our Selling, general and administrative expense consists of all expenditures incurred in connection with the sales and marketing of our products and services, in addition to general and administrative costs, including: - Compensation and benefits costs for management, including stock-based compensation expenses; - Expenses relating to sales personnel primarily resulting from increases or decreases in sales volume or to meet changes in anticipated demand; - Expenses related to support functions and executives; - Depreciation expense excluding that recognized via Cost of sales in addition to other general selling expenses incurred in the normal course of business; and - Service cost on our pension and other post-employment benefit plans. Changes in our Selling, general and administrative expense as a percentage of Net sales are primarily driven by: - Variances in sales volume, as fixed costs can be spread to higher sales totals; - Changes in demand which can impact our determinations of budgeted costs necessary to both maintain our customer base and increase our gross revenue on a constant currency basis; - Frequency and depth of product launches or entrances and exits into market or geographical segments; and - Fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Research and development expense
Subsubsection Text: Our Research and development expense represents costs incurred to develop new products or services, or those incurred to develop and improve upon existing products or processes.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Amortization of intangibles
Subsubsection Text: Amortization of intangibles represents the ratable recognition of expense relative to acquired definite-life intangible assets that were initially recorded at fair value. This expense is exclusive of amortization recognized through Cost of sales. Expense incurred and recognized via Amortization of intangibles primarily relates to assets that are not directly related to revenue generating activities, i.e. customer relationships, trademarks and tradenames, and land use rights. 128 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Restructuring and severance expense
Subsubsection Text: Our Restructuring and severance expense relates to costs incurred for implemented reductions in force and strategic restructuring decisions designed to reduce overall spend and better align the personnel and leadership with our organizational structure.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Impairment of goodwill and intangible assets
Subsubsection Text: We perform impairment assessments at least annually relative to any acquired goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets, including in-process research and development assets. Additionally, we assess definite-lived intangible assets for impairment to determine whether a qualitative or quantitative triggering event has occurred.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Acquisition and transaction-related expenses
Subsubsection Text: We continually seek opportunities to improve upon our market position and gain synergies via business combinations. Acquisitions and transaction-related expenses represent costs incurred from completed, in-process, or abandoned mergers and acquisition opportunities primarily for due diligence and valuation efforts.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Other operating (income) expense, net
Subsubsection Text: We recognize Other operating (income) expense, net as a result of income and expense realized in the ordinary course of our operations, but are not classified as expense types identified above. Examples include realized foreign exchange gains on operational transactions and gains and losses on sales of property, plant, and equipment, as well as bank fees and other financial costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Non-operating expense (income), net
Subsubsection Text: We recognize Non-operating expense (income), net as a result of income and expense which arise from transactions or other items which give rise to income or expense which are not in the ordinary course of our operations. Such items include the following: - Unrealized foreign exchange gains and losses; - Our share of income from our joint ventures accounted for under the equity method of accounting net of distributions; - Royalty income; - Pension expense (excluding Service cost, which is included in Selling, general and administrative expense); and - Adjustments in the value of tax indemnification assets. Other items which influence Non-operating expense (income), net include certain non-recurring items which are not related to our operations such as: - Gains and losses on foreign currency forward contracts; and - Gains and losses on extinguishment of debt.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Interest expense
Subsubsection Text: Interest expense primarily relates to costs incurred for interest expense on our external borrowings and other long-term liabilities. Other elements included in interest expense include: - Amortization of deferred financing costs incurred in connection with our external debt borrowings and ABL Revolving Credit Facility; - Accretion of original issue discount on our external debt; - Interest expense on our note payable to our shareholders; and 129 ----- - Reclassifications from Other comprehensive income related to our interest rate swaps.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Income tax provision
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to income tax in the various jurisdictions in which we operate. Though the extent of our future tax liabilities is uncertain, changes to our corporate structure, capitalization and future acquisitions are all factors which may impact future book and taxable income of our subsidiaries and Parent as a whole. Our effective tax rate fluctuates from period to period due to changes in the mix of income or losses in jurisdictions with a wide range of tax rates, permanent differences between U.S. GAAP and local tax laws, and certain one-time items including tax rate changes, benefit of non-U.S. taxes, and adjustments related to unremitted earnings of our subsidiaries. The amortization and increased interest expense related to our acquisitions and capital structure reduces our profit before tax to a level where the effective tax rate is highly sensitive.

(2,482) 14,028 Net loss ............................................................................................................. $ (68,318) $ (279) _Net sales_ Net sales increased by $59.5 million to $1.09 billion for the three months ended March 31, 2023 as compared to Net sales of $1.03 billion for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The increase in Net sales was primarily driven by the September 9, 2022 acquisition of Clearon and price increases to help offset inflationary raw material costs. These increases were offset by declines in sales volume and unfavorable foreign currency effects. _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales increased by $46.9 million, to $836.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023, as compared to Cost of sales of $789.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. This increase was driven 130 ----- primarily by the September 9, 2022 acquisition of Clearon and incremental raw material inflation between periods. These increases were offset by declines in sales volume and favorable foreign currency effects. _Selling, general and administrative expense_ Selling, general and administrative expense increased by $4.8 million to $174.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023, as compared to Selling, general, and administrative expense of $169.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The overall increase in Selling, general and administrative expense was driven primarily by incremental costs related to our September 9, 2022 acquisition of Clearon. _Research and development expense_ Research and development expense increased by $1.9 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023, as compared for the three months ended March 31, 2022. Research and development expense as a percentage of Net sales was relatively consistent between periods. _Amortization of intangible assets_ Amortization of intangible assets increased by $2.3 million to $31.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023, as compared to $29.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The increase in the Amortization of intangible assets was primarily driven by incremental depreciation and amortization expense resulting from the recognition of the purchase price allocation related to our September 9, 2022 acquisition of Clearon. _Restructuring and severance expenses_ Restructuring and severance expenses decreased by $0.9 million, to expense of $0.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023, as compared to $1.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The decrease was primarily driven by the timing of our cost-savings initiatives related to planned reductions in force in connection with the synergy objectives of the Solenis Acquisition, or in response to COVID-19. _Acquisition and transaction-related expenses_ Acquisition and transaction-related expenses increased by $4.1 million to expense of $4.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023, as compared to Acquisition and transaction related expenses of $0 for the three months ended March 31, 2022. This increase was specific to the deal costs incurred by Solenis to facilitate acquisitions closed or contemplated during the three months ended March 31, 2023. _Other operating expense, net_ Other operating (income) expense, net decreased from an expense of $1.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022 to income of $1.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. Fluctuations in Other operating expense, net were primarily related to Realized foreign exchange gains and losses related to our operations. _Non-operating expense (income), net_ Non-operating expense (income), net, decreased from income of $31.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022, to expense of $24.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. This increase was primarily related to the effect of fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates as a portion of our third-party debt is denominated in EUR and subject to foreign-exchange risk. _Interest expense_ Interest expense increased by $26.5 million from $48.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022, to $75.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023. The overall increase in interest expense was primarily driven by impact of increasing market interest rates on our variable third-party debt and incremental external debt related to the financing of our September 9, 2022 acquisition of Clearon. 131 ----- _Income tax provision_ The income tax provision decreased by $16.5 million to a benefit of $2.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023, as compared to expense of $14.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. Our income tax benefit and effective tax rates fluctuate from period to period primarily due to changes in the mix of income or losses in jurisdictions with a wide range of tax rates, permanent differences between GAAP and local tax laws, and certain one-time items including tax rate changes, and adjustments related to the repatriation of unremitted earnings of subsidiaries.

(257,260) 46,309 (7,245) Interest expense ..................................................... 201,468 16,553 165,236 Income (loss) before income taxes ........................ 110,722 (121,768) 53,020 Income tax provision ............................................. 66,420 (23,717) 25,469 Net income (loss) .................................................. $ 44,302 $ (98,051) $ 27,551 _Overview_ The following narrative compares eleven months of activity for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022 vs. the twelve months of activity for the Predecessor year ended September 30, 2021. The eleven month versus twelve month comparison is driven by the timing of the Solenis Acquisition which closed on November 9, 2021. _Net sales_ Net sales increased by $921.1 million to $3.91 billion for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022 as compared to Net sales of $2.99 billion for the year ended September 30, 2021. The increase in Net sales was driven by the Sigura Contribution on November 9, 2021. Net sales for the Sigura business during the eleven month period ending September 30, 2022 were $692.2 million. Incremental Net sales on a fully comparative basis were driven primarily by price increases to offset the impact of raw material inflation as well as increases in organically generated volume. _Cost of sales_ 134 ----- Cost of sales increased by $900.1 million to $3.02 billion for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022, as compared to Cost of sales of $2.12 billion for the year ended September 30, 2021. The increase in Cost of sales driven by the Sigura Contribution on November 9, 2021. Cost of sales for the Sigura business during the eleven month period ending September 30, 2021 were $463.8 million. Incremental Cost of sales on a fully comparative basis were driven primarily by raw material cost increases as well as increases in organically generated volume. _Selling, general and administrative expense_ Selling, general and administrative expense increased by $89.9 million to $611.2 million for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022, as compared to Selling, general, and administrative expense of $521.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2021. The increase in Selling, general and administrative expense was driven primarily by the Sigura Contribution on November 9, 2021, inclusive of realized cost synergies and the related costs to realize those synergies. Incremental Selling, general and administrative expense on a fully comparative basis were driven primarily by market based compensation increases for Solenis; legacy employees. _Research and development expense_ Research and development expense increased by $3.8 million for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022, as compared for the year ended September 30, 2021. The increase in Research and development expense was driven primarily the Sigura Contribution on November 9, 2021 and the related research and development costs required to support the legacy Pools business. _Amortization of intangible assets_ Amortization of intangible assets increased by $65.0 million to $114.9 million for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022, as compared to $49.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2021. The increase in the Amortization of intangible assets is primarily driven by incremental depreciation and amortization expense resulting from the recognition of the purchase price allocations specific to the Acquisition of the heritage Solenis business and the Sigura Contribution. _Acquisition and transaction-related expenses_ Acquisition and transaction-related expenses increased by $31.2 million to expense of $51.1 million for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022, as compared to Acquisition and transaction related expenses of $19.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2021. This increase is specific to the deal costs incurred by Solenis (as seller) and Parent (as buyer) to facilitate the closing of the Solenis Acquisition dated November 9, 2021 which includes bank success fees as well as legal and other professional service fees incurred throughout the diligence process. _Other operating expense, net_ Other operating expense, net decreased from expense of $19.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2021 to expense of $9.7 million for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022. Fluctuations in Other operating expense, net were primarily related to Realized foreign exchange gains and losses related to our operations. _Non-operating (income), net_ Non-operating (income), net, increased from income of $7.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to income of $257.3 million for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022. Incremental Non-operating (income) was primarily driven by fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates specific to our Euro-denominated external debt which resulted in incremental income of $224.0 million between periods. Remaining net losses incurred during the year ended September 30, 2022 driven primarily by the settlement of various monetary positions in connection with the Acquisition and Contribution primarily offset net losses incurred during the year ended September 30, 2021 driven primarily by the deconsolidation of our subsidiary in Trinidad and Tobago. _Interest expense_ Interest expense increased by $36.2 million driven primarily by incremental indebtedness utilized to finance the Acquisition and Contribution, offset by net reductions in weighted average interest rates driven primarily by fixed rate borrowings via the Secured and Unsecured Notes. 135 ----- _Income tax provision_ The income tax provision increased by $41.0 million to $66.4 million for the Successor period ended September 30, 2022, as compared to provision of $25.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2021. Our income tax provision and effective tax rates fluctuate from period to period primarily due to changes in the mix of income or losses in jurisdictions with a wide range of tax rates, permanent differences between GAAP and local tax laws, and certain one-time items including tax rate changes, and adjustments related to the repatriation of unremitted earnings of subsidiaries.

The increase in Net sales was primarily driven by increases in sales volume (inclusive of acquisitions), the effect of fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates and increases in pricing which increased Net sales by $106 million, $84 million and $48 million, respectively. _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales increased by $180.8 million, or 9.3%, to $2,120.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, as compared to Cost of sales of $1,939.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2020. The increase in Cost of sales was primarily attributable to the impact of raw material inflation, incremental sales volume (inclusive acquisitions) and fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, which increased Cost of sales by $66 million, $65 million and $63 million, respectively. These increases were primarily offset by changes in sales mix, which reduced Cost of sales by $16 million. _Selling, general and administrative expense_ Selling, general and administrative expense decreased by $15.7 million, or 2.9%, to $521.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, as compared to Selling, general, and administrative expense of $537.0 million for the year ended September 30, 2020. The overall decrease in Selling, general and administrative expense was driven by permanent cost reduction programs actioned in 2020 which resulted in a net decrease in Selling, general and 136 ----- administrative expense of $41 million as well as the timing of expenses incurred for non-recurring costs which reduced Selling, general and administrative expense by $6 million. These decreases were offset by fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, annual compensation cost increases and incremental incentive compensation accruals which increased Selling, general and administrative expense by $12 million, $9 million, and $8 million, respectively. Selling, general, and administrative expense as a percentage of Net sales decreased from 19.5% for the year ended September 30, 2020 to 17.4% for the year ended September 30, 2021. _Research and development expense_ Research and development expense increased by $3.3 million, or 8.1%, to $44.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, as compared to $40.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2020. Research and development expense as a percentage of Net sales was consistent between periods, equal to 1.5% for the year ended September 30, 2021, and 1.5% for the year ended September 30, 2020. _Amortization of intangible assets_ Amortization of intangible assets increased by $1.9 million, or 4.0%, to $49.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, as compared to $47.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2020. The increase in the Amortization of intangible assets was primarily driven by the current year impact of our prior year acquisitions for which we recognized amortizable “customer relationship” assets at each respective acquisition date. _Restructuring and severance expenses_ Restructuring and severance expenses decreased by $15.8 million, to $5.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, as compared to $21.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2020. The decrease was primarily driven by the timing of our cost-savings initiatives related to planned reductions in force in connection with the synergy objectives for the joint venture between Solenis and BASF or in response to COVID-19. _Acquisition and transaction-related expenses_ Acquisition and transaction-related expenses increased by $17.7 million, or 791.4%, to expense of $19.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, as compared to the Solenis Acquisition and transaction-related expenses of $2.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2020. This increase was primarily driven by the timing and relative size of our various acquisitions and contemplated actions. _Other operating expense, net_ Other operating expense, net increased from $10.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2020 to $19.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2021. Fluctuations in Other operating expense, net were primarily related to Realized foreign exchange gains and losses (including those on intercompany transactions), provisions for indirect tax contingencies, bank fees and other financial costs, and losses on abandonment or sale of property, plant and equipment. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Title: Reconciliation of Net income (loss) to EBITDA and Segment profit
Subsubsection Text: EBITDA consists of net income (loss) before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Segment profit consists of EBITDA adjusted for (i) non-operating income or expense, (ii) the impact of certain non-cash, nonrecurring or other items that are included in net income (loss) and EBITDA that we do not consider indicative of our ongoing operating performance, and (iii) certain unusual or non-recurring items impacting results in a particular period. We believe that making such adjustments provides investors with meaningful information to understand our operating results and ability to analyze financial and business trends on a period-to-period basis. We believe these financial measures are commonly used by investors to evaluate our performance and that of our competitors. However, our use of the terms EBITDA and Segment profit may vary from that of others in our industry. These financial measures should not be considered alternatives to income before income taxes, net income (loss), or any other performance measures derived in accordance with U.S. GAAP as measures of operating performance. EBITDA and Segment profit have limitations as analytical tools and you should not consider them in isolation or as substitutes for analysis of our results as reported under U.S. GAAP. Some of these limitations are: EBITDA and Segment profit: - Do not reflect the significant interest costs relative to our external debt; - Eliminate the impact of income taxes from the results of our operations; - Although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often have to be replaced in the future, and EBITDA and Segment profit do not reflect any expenditures for such replacements; and 143 ----- - Other companies in our industry may calculate EBITDA or Segment profit differently than we do, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures. We compensate for these limitations by using EBITDA and Segment profit along with other comparative tools, together with U.S. GAAP measurements, to assist in the evaluation of operating performance. Such U.S. GAAP measurements include income before income taxes, and net income (loss) amongst other performance metrics. In evaluating these financial measures, readers should be aware that in the future we may incur expenses similar to those eliminated in this presentation. Our presentation of EBITDA and Segment profit should not be construed as an inference that our future results will be unaffected by unusual or non-recurring items. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF PARENT
Subsubsection Text: To supplement our financial information presented in accordance with U.S. GAAP, we use the following non-GAAP financial measures to clarify and enhance an understanding of past performance: EBITDA, Segment profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing cash flows. We believe that the presentation of these financial measures enhances an investor’s understanding of our financial performance. We further believe that these financial measures are useful financial metrics to assess our operating performance from period-to-period by excluding certain items that we believe are not representative of our core business. We use certain of these financial measures for business planning purposes and in measuring our performance relative to that of our competitors. We utilize Segment profit as the primary measure of our segment specific performance.

Subsubsection Title: Reconciliation of Cash Flows
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted net operating cash flows and Adjusted net investing cash flows consists of reported Net cash (used in) provided by operating activities and Net cash provided by (used in) investing activities, each adjusted for the effects of cash subsequently received as part of our Accounts Receivable Facility. ASU 2016-15 requires us to evaluate the transfer of title of receivables sold under the Accounts Receivable Facility against cash received on previously-sold receivables in exchange for the transfer of title. Since there is a dichotomy between when we legally transfer title of receivables to ING Luxembourg S.A. (“ING”) or MUFG Bank, Ltd. (“MUFG”) under the ING Receivables Purchasing Agreement or MUFG Receivables Purchasing Agreement, respectively, and when the cash received on previously-sold receivables, receivables are deemed transferred in exchange for a beneficial interest in the collection of that receivable. This is considered a non-cash investing activity. Furthermore, ultimate receipts of 144 ----- cash, when settled with ING or MUFG (as relevant), are considered cash flows from investing activities, as the receipt is considered a return of capital on the beneficial interest. We believe that this may cause Net cash (used in) provided by operating activities and Net cash provided by (used in) investing activities to be potentially misleading to investors. While we do not retain legal ownership of the receivables sold, the nature, timing, and extent of cash flows have not materially changed as a result of the agreement. We use these Non-GAAP metrics to assess our own liquidity.
