Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Revenue Recognition
Subsubsection Text: Our revenue earning activities primarily involve manufacturing and selling products and services. Revenue from contracts with customers is recognized using a five-step model consisting of the following: (1) identify the contract with a customer; (2) identify the performance obligations in the contract; (3) determine the transaction price; (4) allocate the transaction price to the performance obligations in the contract; and (5) recognize revenue when (or as) we satisfy a performance obligation. Performance obligations are satisfied when we transfer control of a good or service to a customer, which can occur over time or at a point in time. The amount of revenue recognized is based on the consideration to which we expect to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services, including the expected value of variable consideration. The customer’s ability and intent to pay the transaction price is assessed in determining whether a contract exists with the customer. If collectability of substantially all of the consideration in a contract is not probable, consideration received is not recognized as revenue unless the consideration is 165 ----- nonrefundable and we no longer have an obligation to transfer additional goods or services to the customer or collectability becomes probable. Product sales, to end-customers or distributors, represents approximately 98% of our revenue and is recognized at a point-in-time, which is generally at the point in time when products have been shipped, right to payment has been obtained and risk of loss has been transferred. Revenue is measured based on the consideration to which we expect to be entitled based on customer contracts. For sales to distributors, revenue is adjusted for variable consideration amounts, including but not limited to estimated discounts and distributor rebate programs. These estimates are determined based upon historical experience, contract terms, inventory levels in the distributor channel and other related factors. Adjustments to variable consideration estimates are recorded when circumstances indicate revisions may be necessary.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Business Combinations
Subsubsection Text: Business combinations are accounted for under the acquisition method of accounting, which requires the acquired assets, including separately identifiable intangible assets, and assumed liabilities to be recorded as of the acquisition date at their respective fair values. Any excess of the purchase price over the fair value of the assets acquired, including separately identifiable intangible assets, and liabilities assumed is recorded as goodwill. Fair value determination is subject to a significant degree of estimates. The determination of the fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed involves assessments of factors such as the expected future cash flows associated with individual assets and liabilities and appropriate discount rates at the date of the acquisition. Where appropriate, external advisors are consulted to assist in the determination of fair value. For non-observable market values, fair value has been determined using acceptable valuation principles (e.g., multiple excess earnings, relief from royalty and cost methods) which is considered to be a Level 3 fair value. The results of operations for businesses acquired are included in the consolidated financial statements from the acquisition date.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Long-Lived Assets
Subsubsection Text: Long-lived assets represent a significant portion of our total assets, the aggregate amount of which was $1,513.7 million and $1,602.2 million, as of December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, respectively. Such longlived assets primarily consist of definite-lived intangible assets in an aggregate amount of $1,165.9 million and $1,292.6 million as of December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, respectively. We perform an impairment review for definite-lived intangible assets, such as customer relationships, contracts, intellectual property, and for other long-lived assets, such as property and equipment, whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value of an asset or asset group may not be recoverable. Such events may include, but are not limited to, a significant decrease in the market price of an asset or asset group, change in manner in which an asset is being used, significant change in business climate and significant cash flow or operating losses that demonstrate continuing losses associated with the use of the asset. We calculate the undiscounted value of the projected cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposition of the asset or asset group and compare this estimated amount to the carrying value of the asset or asset group. If the carrying amount is found to be greater than the undiscounted value of the projected cash flows of the asset or asset group, we record an impairment loss of the excess of carrying value over the fair value of the asset or asset group. In addition, we re-evaluate the remaining useful lives of the assets and modify them, as appropriate. Definite-lived intangible assets, such as trade names and customer relationships are amortized over their estimated economic lives. The reasonableness of the useful lives of these assets is regularly evaluated. Once these assets are fully amortized, they are removed from the balance sheet. We evaluate these assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of these assets may not be recoverable.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Goodwill and Indefinite-Lived Intangible Assets
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets represent a significant portion of our total assets. Our goodwill had a carrying value of $462.8 million and $471.5 million as of December 31, 2022 and December 31, 166 ----- 2021, respectively. Indefinite-lived intangible assets, which consist of the Diversey trade name, had a carrying value of $818.2 million and $854.7 million as of December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, respectively. We review goodwill for possible impairment on a reporting unit level, which are consistent with our operating segments. Goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets are reviewed on an annual basis as of October 1st of each year, or more frequently if an event occurs or circumstances change that would indicate that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit or the fair value of an indefinite-lived intangible asset has declined below its carrying value. Such events may include, but are not limited to, impairment of other assets or establishment of valuation allowances on deferred tax assets, cash flow or operating losses at a reporting unit, negative current events or long-term outlooks for our industry, and negative adjustments to future forecasts. In performing the annual goodwill impairment assessment, we have the option under U.S. GAAP to qualitatively assess whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value. If we conclude from the qualitative assessment that there are no indicators of impairment, we do not perform a quantitative test, which would require a valuation of the reporting unit as of October 1. U.S. GAAP provides a set of qualitative factors such as macroeconomic, industry, market and company specific factors, including cost factors, overall financial performance, market capitalization, and other events specific to Diversey to consider in performing the qualitative assessment described above, which factors are not all inclusive; management considers the factors it deems relevant in making its more likely than not assessments. If we conclude from our qualitative assessment that there are indicators of impairment and that a quantitative test is required, the annual or interim quantitative goodwill impairment test involves comparing the fair value of each of our reporting units with goodwill to its carrying value, including the goodwill allocated to the reporting unit. If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying value, there is no impairment and no further testing is required. If the fair value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying value, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount of the excess, limited to the amount of goodwill allocated to the reporting unit. Our annual assessment of the recovery of goodwill begins with management’s reassessment of its operating segments and reporting units. A reporting unit is an operating segment or one level below an operating segment, which is referred to as a component. This reassessment of reporting units is also made each time we change our operating segments. If the goodwill of a reporting unit is allocated to newly-formed reporting units, the allocation is made to each reporting unit based upon their relative fair values. Based on the results of our 2022 and 2021 annual qualitative assessments, we concluded that it was more likely than not that the fair value of each of the reporting units exceeded its carrying value. As such, it was not necessary to perform a quantitative impairment analysis, and we concluded that our reporting units were not impaired. The fair value of our reporting units is determined using both an income approach, which is based on discounted cash flows (“DCF”), and a market approach when we quantitatively test goodwill for impairment, either on an interim basis or annual basis as of October 1 of each year. Significant judgments inherent in using a DCF analysis include the selection of appropriate discount and long-term growth rates and estimating the amount and timing of expected future cash flows. The expected cash flows used in the DCF analyses are based on our most recent forecast and budget and, for years beyond the budget, our estimates, which are based, in part, on forecasted growth rates. The discount rates and growth rates used in the DCF analyses are intended to reflect the risks inherent in the expected future cash flows of the respective reporting units. Assumptions used in the DCF analyses, including the discount rate and the long-term growth rate, are assessed based on each reporting unit’s current results and forecasted future performance, as well as macroeconomic and industry specific factors, and reflect our best estimate as of the impairment testing date. Any changes in such assumptions or estimates as a result of changes in our budgets, forecasts or negative macroeconomic trends could significantly affect the value of our reporting units which could impact whether an impairment of goodwill has occurred. Determining fair value using a market approach considers multiples of financial metrics based on both acquisitions and trading multiples of a selected peer group of companies. From the comparable companies, a representative market multiple is determined which is applied to financial metrics to estimate the fair value of a reporting unit. To determine a peer group of companies for our respective reporting units, we considered companies relevant in terms of consumer use, monetization model, margin and growth characteristics, and brand strength operating in their respective sectors. If the carrying value of the indefinite-lived intangible asset exceeds its estimated fair value, an impairment equal to the excess is recorded. The 2022 and 2021 annual assessments of the indefinite-lived intangible asset did not identify any impairments. 167 ----- When performing a quantitative test, we determine the fair value of the indefinite-lived intangible asset using a relief from royalty DCF valuation analysis. Significant judgments inherent in this analysis include the selection of appropriate royalty and discount rates and estimating the amount and timing of expected future cash flows. The discount rates used in the DCF analyses are intended to reflect the risks inherent in the expected future cash flows generated by the respective intangible assets. The royalty rates used in the DCF analyses are based upon an estimate of the royalty rates that a market participant would pay to license our trade names. The future cash flows are based on our most recent forecast and budget and, for years beyond the budget, our estimates, which are based, in part, on forecasted revenue growth rates. Assumptions used in the relief from royalty DCF analyses, including the discount rate and royalty rate, are assessed annually based on the actual and projected cash flows related to the asset, as well as macroeconomic and industry specific factors. The discount rates used in our annual indefinite-lived impairment assessment was 9.5% in 2022, and the royalty rate used in 2022 was 3.0%. Based on the results of our 2021 annual qualitative assessment, we concluded that it was more likely than not that the fair value of the indefinite-lived intangible asset exceeded the carrying value. As such, it was not necessary to perform a quantitative impairment analysis, and we concluded that the indefinite-lived intangible asset was not impaired. Estimating the fair value of a reporting unit and the indefinite-lived intangible asset involves uncertainties because it requires management to develop numerous assumptions, including assumptions about the future growth and potential volatility in revenues and costs, capital expenditures, industry economic factors and future business strategy. Changes in projected revenue growth rates, projected operating income margins or estimated discount rates due to uncertain market conditions, loss of one or more key customers, changes in our strategy, or other factors could negatively affect the fair value of our reporting units or the indefinite-lived intangible asset and result in a material impairment charge in the future.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Income taxes
Subsubsection Text: Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of assets and liabilities and their respective tax basis. Deferred tax assets are also recognized for operating losses and tax credit carry forwards. Valuation allowances are recorded to reduce deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not that a tax benefit will not be realized. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates applicable in the years in which they are expected to be recovered or settled. The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax law is recognized in income in the period that includes the enactment date. We do not provide for income taxes on undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries that are intended to be indefinitely reinvested. Where we do not intend to indefinitely reinvest earnings of foreign subsidiaries, we provide for income taxes and foreign withholding taxes, where applicable, on undistributed earnings. We recognize the benefit of an income tax position only if it is “more likely than not” that the tax position will be sustained. The tax benefits recognized are measured based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized. Additionally, we recognize interest and penalties accrued related to unrecognized tax benefits as a component of provision (benefit) for taxes on income.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Pension Benefits
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Diversey Acquisition, we assumed certain defined benefit plan obligations and acquired certain related plan assets for current employees of our subsidiaries. In addition, we implemented a replacement retiree health care reimbursement plan for certain U.S. employees. The projected benefit obligation and the net periodic benefit cost are based on third-party actuarial assumptions and estimates that are reviewed and approved by management on a plan-by-plan basis each fiscal year. The principal assumptions concern the discount rate used to measure future obligations, the expected future rate of return on plan assets and the expected rate of future compensation increases. We revise these assumptions based on an annual evaluation of long-term trends and market conditions that may have an impact on the cost of providing retirement benefits. In determining the discount rate, we utilize market conditions and other data sources management considers reasonable based upon the profile of the remaining service life of eligible employees. The expected long-term rate of return on plan assets is determined by taking into consideration the weighted-average expected return on our asset 168 ----- allocation, asset return data, historical return data, and the economic environment. We believe these considerations provide the basis for reasonable assumptions of the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets. The rate of compensation increase is based on our long-term plans for such increases. The measurement date used to determine benefit obligations and plan assets is December 31. In general, material changes to the principal assumptions could have a material impact on the costs and liabilities recognized in the Diversey Consolidated Financial Statements. See “Note 13 — Retirement Plans in the Notes to the Diversey Consolidated Financial Statements,” included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of the consolidated financial statements in accordance with U.S. GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of some assets and liabilities and, in some instances, the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the applicable reporting period. Actual results could differ from these estimates. These estimates involve judgments with respect to, among other things, future economic factors that are difficult to predict and are beyond management’s control. As a result, actual amounts could differ from these estimates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: Refer to the sub-section, “New Accounting Guidance,” within Note 3 - Summary of Significant Accounting Policies in the Notes to our audited consolidated financial statements and related notes as of and for the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Guarantees and Indemnification Obligations
Subsubsection Text: We are party to many contracts containing guarantees and indemnification obligations. These contracts primarily consist of: - product and service warranties with respect to certain products sold to customers in the ordinary course of business. These warranties typically provide that products will conform to specifications. We generally do not establish a liability for product warranty based on a percentage of sales or other formula. We accrue a product warrant liability on a transaction‑specific basis depending on the individual facts and circumstances related to each sale. Both the liability and annual expense related to product warranties are immaterial to our consolidated financial position and results of operations; and - licenses of intellectual property by us to third parties in which we have agreed to indemnify the licensee against third-party infringement claims. 169 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: We have reviewed our off‑balance sheet arrangements and have determined that none of our arrangements that are not already disclosed in our consolidated financial statements have a material current effect or is reasonably likely to have a material future effect on our consolidated financial statements, liquidity, capital expenditures or capital resources.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: History and Evolution
Subsubsection Text: The Escrow Issuer is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Issuer. The Issuer is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Parent. Parent, doing business as “Solenis” from November 9, 2021, was formed on June 29, 2021 in connection with the Solenis Acquisition as an exempted limited partnership registered and domiciled under the laws of the Cayman Islands. Parent and several other holding companies and partnerships were formed by affiliates of Platinum. Parent exists as the “successor” entity for the specific purposes of (1) having consummated the Solenis Acquisition, and (2) having received the Sigura Contribution. Accordingly, the consummation of the Solenis Acquisition and the Sigura Contribution resulted in the consolidation of the operations of the legacy Solenis and Sigura businesses into the business of Parent from November 9, 2021. On September 9, 2022, Clearon was acquired by Parent and its subsidiaries from Hui Yu Xin American LLC.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Solenis Business
Subsubsection Text: Headquartered in Wilmington, Delaware, Solenis is a leading supplier of specialty chemicals and services to the pulp and paper, mining, food and beverage, power generation, petroleum refining, chemical processing, general manufacturing, municipal and pool markets. Solenis’ product and service line is comprised of chemical and equipment technologies and services designed to help customers improve operational efficiencies, enhance product quality, protect plant assets and minimize environmental impact. Solenis sells products and provide services throughout the Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific primarily to customers operating within the pulp and paper, the water treatment and the pool industries. Solenis has 49 manufacturing facilities strategically located near customers in approximately 22 countries around the globe to ensure seamless supply continuity, and employs a team of more than 6,600 professionals (including more than 2,400 field representatives with deep industry knowledge) in 130 countries across six continents. Solenis has 11 labs consisting of R&D centers and Customer Applications Laboratories spanning every region it serves, aimed at making water work more effectively and more sustainably for its more than 24,500 customers. Key brands delivered by Solenis include Zetag™, Kymene™, Hercobond™, Spectrum™, Praestol™, PerForm™ and Percol™, HTH®, Poolife®, GLB®, Leisure Time®, and HTH Spa®. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, Solenis generated Net sales and Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) of $4.4 billion and $742 million, respectively, reflecting an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 17%. See “Summary—Summary Historical Financial and Combined Financial Data.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Diversey Business
Subsubsection Text: Headquartered in Fort Mill, South Carolina, Diversey is a leading global supplier and manufacturer of sustainable, high-performance hygiene, retail and grocery, infection prevention and cleaning solutions to the facility management, retail, healthcare, hospitality, food and beverage, commercial laundry, food service, education and government, dairy, agriculture and buildings service contractors (“BSC”) markets. Diversey’s product and service line is comprised of a wide range of hygiene, infection prevention and cleaning solutions that drive operational improvements, enhance customers’ food safety initiatives and protect the environment. Diversey sells products and provides services throughout the Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific primarily to customers operating within the institutional and food and beverage industries. Key brands delivered by Diversey include Lysol®, CLAX®, Suma® and TASKI. Diversey maintains 21 manufacturing facilities (including the “Project Mega” plant facility (the new manufacturing and warehouse facility site located in northern Kentucky)) in 17 countries around the globe to allow Diversey to provide efficient and effective service to its customers across 80 countries. Diversey employs a team of more than 9,000 professionals (including approximately 1,400 technicians to provide on-site services to customers). Diversey has 7 labs spanning every region it serves with over 1,100 patents, over 2,000 unique chemical formulations and an extensive and differentiated suite of dosing and dispensing equipment and floor care machines supporting its intellectual property offering for more than 85,000 customers. 170 ----- For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, Diversey generated revenue and Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) of $2.8 billion and $352 million, respectively, reflecting a 13% Adjusted EBITDA margin. For the twelve months ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, Diversey generated Net sales of $2.8 billion, $2.6 billion and $2.6 billion, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of $330 million, $410 million and $401 million, respectively. See “Summary—Summary Historical Financial and Combined Financial Data.” In addition, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, Diversey spent $56 million, $60 million, $55 million and $41 million, respectively, on capital expenditure. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, Diversey spent $78 million, $77 million, $65 million and $46 million, respectively, on dosing and dispensing expenditures.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Combined Company
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the combination of Solenis and Diversey will create a platform with a shared commercial focus and significant global scale in complementary end markets. After giving effect to the Transactions, the combined company will be able to grow and provide a number of attractive cross-selling opportunities, including meeting customers’ increasing demand for “one-stop shop” service models across water management, cleaning and hygiene solutions. After giving effect to the Transactions, we expect to be better positioned to benefit from growing Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) and macroeconomic trends, including those around customer sustainability goals and focus points, such as: heightened focus on water consumption and recycling; the need for improved energy efficiency and raw material management; increased consumer focus on hygiene; increased environmental legislation being implemented globally; and increased levels of shipping and packaging. Together, we will offer a diverse, comprehensive portfolio of solutions and services, which will limit any obsolescence risk as no product or solution represents a material part of our business. Solenis’ and Diversey’s combined segment, geographic and end market breakdown by revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 is illustrated below.[(1) ] (2) Totals may not equal 100% due to rounding. Our leading technology has been at the forefront of the digitization of the water treatment industry and we have a strong pipeline of new and innovative products that we expect will drive significant value for our customers. 171 ----- The combination of Solenis and Diversey represents the coming together of two leading global products, services, and technologies providers with proven track records of product innovation who offer truly differentiated solutions to customers. Prior to the Transactions, we already operate across a diverse set of growing end markets and our broad geographic reach allows us to meet the needs of our customers globally. After giving effect to the Transactions, our combined footprint will continue to span six continents, with reinforced strength and scale of presence, with an increased number of laboratories and production facilities across the Americas, EMEA, and APAC, where we serve all major developed markets and are closely integrated with our customers throughout the world. After giving effect to the Transactions, through our global presence and differentiated service offering in growing markets, we believe we will be a leading provider in all of our segments and will continue to benefit from positive secular trends such as e-commerce for customers, an increased demand for sustainable packaging, a focus on ESG and incremental disposable income increases in emerging markets. The following graphic summarizes the geographic reach of laboratories and production facilities of the combined Solenis company following the Transactions. After giving effect to the Transactions, we will operate 70 manufacturing facilities and 18 laboratories in 23 countries. (1) Includes research, customer application, and development sites. (2) Pro forma for Project Mega facility and associated plant consolidations. See “—Growth Strategy.” There is limited existing overlap between Solenis’ and Diversey’s offerings in water treatment chemicals with legacy Solenis operating in the water treatment and pool solutions markets and legacy Diversey operating in the food and beverage and institutional end markets. We believe the combined company platform will be able to “circle the customer” and create opportunities for new business wins, increasing our customer spending. For example in hotels today, Solenis has a limited presence in pool solutions while Diversey provides kitchen care, building care, floor care, infection prevention and laundry care. After giving effect to the Transactions, we believe the fact that Solenis and Diversey provide different services to their combined customers will provide the combined company with the opportunity to offer existing hotel customers our full suite of products and services, including water treatment. Similarly, Solenis does not currently serve cruise ships or hospitals but will have the opportunity to offer its services to Diversey’s customers in these markets. Protein processing plants are another customer type that each of Solenis and Diversey have a moderate presence with, and going forward, a combined company platform may enable both companies to expand their offerings with such customers. We believe the Transactions present the opportunity to combine our existing services into a “one-stop shop” provider across water management, cleaning 172 ----- and hygiene solutions for our customers. The following graphic summarizes the potential cross-selling opportunities for the combined company. After giving effect to the Transactions, we believe that we will be able to implement near-term strategic initiatives in the legacy Diversey to better optimize processes, drive growth and create value. Some key initiatives will include (i) increasing scale by bundling our leading global cleaning and water treatment solutions across Industrial and Food & Beverage to increase win rates and cross-selling opportunities, (ii) increasing efficiencies by standardizing corporate functions, (iii) implementing a global enterprise resource planning (ERP) system, (iv) investing in growth opportunities such as expansion efforts within: North America commercial and institutional, high growth global strategic accounts (“GSAs”), distributor partnerships and building out new product introduction (NPI) capabilities and (v) applying our performance management capabilities to existing processes. We believe by creating real-time visibility into financial performance we will be able to drive accountability at a more localized level and assist in informing business decisions (such as pricing and have better insight into profitability and distributors’ sell-through). We believe we will be able to further supplement our efforts by deploying commercial excellence tools such as roll-outs and trainings. Additionally, we believe we can continue implementing Diversey’s “Project Mega” by continuing to develop Diversey’s manufacturing and warehouse facility in Northern Kentucky alongside consolidating certain existing service centers to provide manufacturing and logistical efficiencies and insourcing opportunities. We believe our business exhibits highly attractive financial characteristics, including significant recurring revenues, improving margin profile and substantial free cash flow conversion. The combined company will provide greater scale, a broader global reach, superior customer service capabilities and a number of attractive cross-selling opportunities. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, we generated pro forma Net sales on a combined historical basis and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies) of $7.2 billion and $1.3 billion, respectively, inclusive of $205 million of estimated run-rate annual cost synergies from actions expected to be taken within 24 months after the Acquisition and $40 million of cumulative run-rate annual cost synergies from actions that were taken within 18 months of the Solenis Acquisition Closing Date and $13 million of estimated run-rate annual cost synergies from actions already taken or expected to be taken within 24 months of the Clearon Acquisition Closing Date. We believe our combined earnings profile after giving effect to the Transactions will generate significant free cash flow, which we expect will be used to support growth initiatives and drive de-leveraging. We believe that the Transactions create an opportunity to realize meaningful synergies resulting from the integration of Solenis and Diversey. In combining these two complementary businesses, we believe the combined company is entering a new and exciting chapter in a long history of helping customers address core challenges such as water and energy management, partnering on sustainability issues to work towards a cleaner, safer world, and reducing environmental impacts. We expect to realize approximately $205 million of synergies from integration related to the consolidation of support functions and sales teams, the consolidation of sourcing of direct materials, and the consolidation of facilities between the two businesses, as a result of actions expected to be taken within 24 months of the closing of the Transactions. However, there can be no assurance that we will be able to achieve such synergies. For more information on anticipated synergies, including certain factors that may impact our ability to 173 ----- achieve such synergies or operational improvements, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition and the Legacy Acquisitions—We may not achieve some or all of the expected benefits from the items reflected in the adjustments included in Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies).” The prospective unaudited financial information contained in this offering memorandum was not prepared with a view toward compliance with published guidelines of the SEC or the guidelines established by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants for preparation or presentation of prospective financial information. The prospective unaudited financial information included in this offering memorandum has been prepared by, and is the responsibility of, Parent’s management. PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP has not audited, reviewed, examined, compiled nor applied agreed upon procedures with respect to the prospective unaudited financial information and, accordingly, PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP does not express an opinion or any other form of assurance with respect thereto. The PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP report incorporated by reference in this offering memorandum relates to Parent’s previously issued financial statements. It does not extend to the prospective unaudited financial information and should not be read to do so.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Consumer Solutions Segment (29% of Combined Company Net Sales)
Subsubsection Text: Our Consumer Solutions segment provides chemicals and on-site services to customers in four major end markets: Consumer Packaging, Graphic & Specialty Paper, Tissue & Towel and Food Packaging & Molded Fiber Packaging. The Consumer Solutions segment’s portfolio includes both functional additives that impact the end-use characteristics of the finished product, as well as process additives that improve raw material utilization, process efficiency, reduce costs and protect capital intensive pulp and papermaking assets. Our product offering is extensive and includes products such as Sizing, Strength, Biocides, Retention & Drainage Control (“RDC”), Contaminant Control, Pulp, Crepe & Release and Defoamers. Examples and descriptions of Key End Products, Products / Applications and Customer Benefits for each end market can be found in the chart below.

Subsubsection Title: Pool Solutions Segment (12% of Combined Company Net Sales)
Subsubsection Text: Our Pool Solutions segment offers water care solutions and value-added services for residential and commercial pools and spas. The water treatment process begins with testing; specifically pool pH and chlorine levels on a weekly basis. The next step is balancing, i.e., maintaining certain levels of pH, total alkalinity and calcium hardness. Sanitizing, which is keeping water clean and disinfected, is most frequently done using stabilized chlorine products. Specialty maintenance products such as algaecides and clarifiers are typically used on a semimonthly basis, in addition to the normal sanitizing process, to target specific pool needs such as algae prevention or stain control. Lastly, shock treatment can be used to address one-off pool care needs, especially following inclement weather and high pool usage. We are a leading producer of pool chemicals for the residential and commercial markets worldwide and provide various water treatment products including shock, sanitizer, specialty maintenance products, and test strips. Our offerings include a full suite of products and applications aimed at public pools, health clubs, aquatic parks, hotels, motels, apartments and condominiums in the form of water-soluble pods, convenient floaters and automatic feeders. Our portfolio of brands includes iconic brands such HTH®, Poolife®, GLB®, Leisure Time® and HTH Spa®. We believe we are the world’s largest producer of calcium-hypoclorite (“cal-hypo”), a primary chemical used in water treatment and sanitation. We believe we are one of only two players with a complete brand and product offering in the U.S. pool and spa chemicals market and we believe we are the only player with a truly global offering. We have total market access to all residential channels from Mass Retail (40.6% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023), to Professional Dealer (29.3% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 177 ----- 2023), to Commercial (10.1% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023), to Repack and Private Label (18.7% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023) and Other Pool (1.3% of Pool Solutions Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023), as well as growing e-commerce and Direct to Consumer (“DTC”) channels. Demand for products from the Pool Solutions segment is driven by the existing installed base of pools in the regions it operates, which have seen growth tailwinds due to COVID-driven investment in outdoor spaces. Going forward, ongoing maintenance of these pools will drive sustainable and recurring future demand for our products. The Pool Solutions segment generated 12% of pro forma Net sales for the combined Solenis company for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023. We have relationships with key customers across channels including in (i) the mass retail market: Walmart, Ace Hardware, Amazon and Costco; (ii) the pro dealer market: Pool Corp, Leslie’s Poolmart, Poolwerx, Heritage Pool Group and a large fragmented base of individual pool and spa dealers; and (iii) in the commercial market: Pool Corp, Sea World and Bellagio.

In our Industrial Solutions segment we serve a wide range of global customers. Our key customers include (i) for heavy industry: Marathon Petroleum, Georgia Pacific, International Paper, Raizen, Barrick Gold Corporation, BASF, Eastman Chemical, Arkema, Hexion, Inc., Chemstream; (ii) for municipal: Brenntag, City of Houston, East Bay Municipal Utility District (EMBUD); and (iii) for light industry: Diageo, Bridgestone and Lego. Solenis currently has an existing distribution relationship with Diversey through which we provide water treatment products 176 ----- to be marketed to Diversey’s existing customer base within its Food & Beverage segment. After giving effect to the Transactions, Diversey’s Food & Beverage segment will become a reportable segment of the combined company. We believe, based on a report by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021, that we have a leading market position in the Industrial Solutions segment, based on Net sales, and we believe we are one of only three market participants, including Ecolab / Nalco and Suez, that are present in all geographies and market segments. The industry is highly fragmented with many regional players, some of which have significant market share in their respective regions. Based on the same report, the industrial chemicals market is expected to grow at a 4.0% CAGR for the five-year period from 2020 to 2025. The Industrial Solutions segment generated 20% of pro forma Net sales for the combined Solenis company for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023.

Subsubsection Title: Food & Beverage Segment (12% of Combined Company Net Sales)
Subsubsection Text: After giving effect to the Transactions, our Food & Beverage segment will offer a broad range of products, solutions, as well as equipment and machines including chemical products, engineering and equipment solutions, as well as knowledge-based services, including training through our Diversey Hygiene Academy, and water treatment services. We will deliver these solutions to enhance food safety, operational excellence, and sustainability for customers in the beverages, Pharmaceuticals and Agriculture industries. As mentioned above, Diversey and Solenis currently have an existing distribution relationship with the Diversey Food & Beverage segment, through which Solenis provides water treatment products to Diversey to be marketed to Diversey’s existing customer base. 180 ----- Examples of key end products, products and applications and customer benefits for each end market can be found in the chart below.

Subsubsection Text: 4% 4% 3% 3% (1) Note: Excludes Distributor and Other sales equal to 6% and 1% of March 31, 2023 LTM Net sales, respectively. In our Institutional Solutions segment we will serve a wide range of customers. Representative customers will include: Vizient, Ahold / Delhaize, Radisson, BP, ISS, Walmart, Sodexo, Accor, McDonald’s, Compass Group, Yum! Brands, Intrakoop, Aramark and Amazon. We will be one of the major global players within the segment, therefore, we believe we will have the product breadth, scale, supply chain flexibility and service capabilities to compete with Ecolab. Further, we believe there is an opportunity to capture customers within underserved sectors such as cruise ships, logistics, warehousing, casinos, and theme parks. We believe that our Institutional Solutions segment’s revenue base will be recurring and stable due to the ‘sticky’ nature of our business model. Our cleaning products will be consumable in nature and require periodic replacement, generating highly recurring revenue. Additionally, the optimal application of our chemicals will be controlled by our proprietary dosing and dispensing equipment installed at customer sites, which will increase customer switching costs and generate operating efficiencies for our customers. Based on a third-party report completed in February 2023, manufacturing and commercial and healthcare and hospitality end markets are growing at a CAGR of 5.1% and 5.5%, respectively for the four year period 2022 to 2026. The Institutional Solutions segment generated 27% of pro forma Net sales for the combined Solenis company for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023. 179 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: New Product Development Capabilities and Innovations
Subsubsection Text: Our service and product offering, through all five of our combined company segments and various end markets, is enhanced by our new and innovative products which carry higher than average margin profiles, which represent a significant mix lever for the combined company and which help our customers meet their goals and improve operational efficiencies and product quality. We believe our sophisticated product development capabilities meet our customers’ evolving needs and help keep us at the forefront of macroeconomic trends. Our robust innovation pipeline currently has approximately 47 projects with over 85% including a focus on solving our customers’ environmental and sustainability challenges, placing us at the forefront of the ESG mega trend. Of our 47 projects, 15 projects are in Consumer Solutions, 14 are in Institutional Solutions, 7 are in Industrial Solutions, 7 are in Food & Beverage and 4 are in Pool Solutions. 100% of our Institutional Solutions, Industrial Solutions and Pool Solutions projects include a focus on ESG, while over 87% of our Consumer Solutions and 86% of our Food & Beverage projects include a focus on ESG. The following chart summarizes some of the new product development capabilities and innovations we are creating to help customers meet sustainability goals, improve operational efficiency and enhance product quality. ###### End Market Geography

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: In our Food & Beverage segment we will serve a wide range of customers. Representative customers will include: Diageo, The Coca-Cola Company, Anheuser Busch, PepsiCo, Heineken, Brenntag, Nestle, Mondelez International and Yili Group. We believe that our Food & Beverage segment’s revenue base will be recurring and stable. Our CleaningIn-Place (“CIP”) and Open Plant Systems will integrate our chemicals, lubricants, floor care equipment, and cleaning and dispensing tools, while our highly skilled technical application experts will help customers achieve 181 ----- production efficiencies through customized solutions that utilize our products. The highly integrated and customized nature of the resulting solutions are expected to drive operational efficiencies as well as high switching costs for our customers, leading to very high customer retention. The food and beverage industry is widely fragmented and we believe the combined company has the ability to win business driven by an increasing customer demand for water treatment being bundled with food and beverage solutions. Based on a third-party report completed in February 2023, food and beverage is growing at a CAGR of 6.5% for the four year period 2022 to 2026. The Food & Beverage segment generated 12% of pro forma Net sales for the combined Solenis company for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Customers and Suppliers & Procurement
Subsubsection Text: _Customers_ We serve a large base of customers across a diverse set of end markets. Our customer base for the combined company includes many of the top paper and industrial players across our Industrial Solutions and Consumer Solutions segments, including WestRock, International Paper, and Marathon Petroleum, across big-box retailers such as Wal-Mart and Leslie’s Poolmart in our Pool Solutions segment, across Compass, ISS and McDonald’s in our Institutional Solutions segment and across PepsiCo and Nestle in our Food & Beverage segment. We believe that the combination of Solenis and Diversey will further reduce customer concentration. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, the top ten customers for the combined company represent approximately 12% of total pro forma combined company Net sales with the largest customer representing approximately 2% of pro forma combined company Net sales. As of March 31, 2023, at Solenis, the top ten customers represented approximately 19% of total Net sales with the top three customers representing approximately 11%. Historically, large accounts have grown 1.3x faster than the base business, driven by collaboration with customers on new technology development, embedded service engineers and focus on consistent delivery and service. As of March 31, 2023 at Diversey, customer concentration was relatively in line with that of Solenis so low customer concentration is set to become even less concentrated as a result of the combination of Solenis and Diversey. Further, Diversey is a major global player with capabilities to serve GSAs, which represents approximately 20% of revenue. Both Solenis and Diversey have long-tenured, diverse and high quality customer relationships. We believe our customer base is inherently sticky, attributable to the mission critical nature and service-led models that Solenis and Diversey provide, leading to highly recurring, non-discretionary spend on products and services. On-site technicians, employees and equipment at customer locations create high switching costs and disruption risk. As a result, we believe Solenis’ Net sales is approximately 97% recurring, driven by our differentiated solutions and value proposition and will continue to remain over 97% recurring in the combined company. _Suppliers & Procurement_ We source materials from multiple suppliers creating low supply chain concentration. On April 30, 2021, Solenis and BASF agreed to extend the supply agreements applicable to certain products that are critical to Solenis’ supply chain and for which Solenis takes all of BASF’s production, which now will not expire until November 2028. Our largest raw material spend includes General Liquids (5.4% of total spend), Caustic and Chlorine (3.3% of total spend), Acrylonitrile (2.9% of total spend), HDPE (2.2% of total spend) and Sodium Hydroxide (2.1% of total spend) resulting in a top five materials of 15.9% or $590 million. The top five key suppliers represent 23% of total expenditure, or $854 million, with the top supplier representing 13% of total expenditure. 183 Slow Dissolve Calcium** Slowed dissolve tablet platform delivers better solution for pool water Pool Solutions Hypochlorite** clarity and water utilization ----- The following graphic summarizes our pro forma combined company expenditure on raw materials and to key suppliers for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023. ###### Raw Materials Key Suppliers

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Specialty Chemicals – Consumer
Subsubsection Text: The Consumer market is comprised of water treatment chemicals and solutions for pulp and paper specific process applications (e.g., strength additives and sizing agents across wet-end/dry-end of paper process). Based on a report by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021, the global Consumer market was estimated to be approximately $8 billion in 2020. The Packaging market is one of the key market segments within the Consumer market that can be broken into consumer packaging and food packaging. Based on the same report, the Consumer packaging market was estimated to be $2.7 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 3.4% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030, which we believe will be driven primarily from the growth of e-commerce and megatrends in pharmaceuticals and cosmetics and beauty. Approximately 10% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated from the consumer packaging market. Based on the same report, the food packaging market was estimated to be $1.8 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 1.9% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030 (including food packaging barrier film expected to grow at a 4.7% CAGR), driven by increased demand for ecofriendly packaging and changing lifestyles centering on more take-away and individually packed food. We believe the shift away from plastic and the growth in the barrier coating market, which is not included in the market size estimate, may drive additional growth in food packaging over this period. Approximately 7% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated from the food packaging and molded fiber packaging market. The Graphic & Specialty Paper market has been adversely impacted by the continued substitution of printed material with electronic media. Reduced use of commercial office spaces in Europe and North America as a result of COVID-19 is also a negative factor for the sector outlook. The Graphic & Specialty Paper market, based on the same report, was estimated to be $1.9 billion in 2020 and is expected to decline at a 0.9% CAGR for the ten-year period from 2020 to 2030. However, we have limited exposure to newsprint, which accounts for approximately 2.5% of Consumer Solutions sales, and we are shifting our focus to higher margin products to offset the expected volume decline in this market. Approximately 5% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated from the Graphic & Specialty Paper market. The Tissue & Towel market is benefiting from strong demographic/socioeconomic trends and increasing hygiene standards, especially in developing markets. However, stagnating population growth in some mature markets, and cost-cutting in the public sector and private company spending is expected to limit global market growth. The Tissue & Towel market, based on the same report, was estimated to be $1.2 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 2.6% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030. Approximately 6% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated from the Tissue & Towel market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Specialty Chemicals — Industrial
Subsubsection Text: The industrial market supplies water treatment chemicals and solutions for heavy and light industries and municipalities (e.g., cooling tower, boiler, influent/effluent, process water). Broadly speaking, the industrial market 184 ----- consists of core water treatment which includes end markets such as pulp, mining and oil and gas, and wastewater, which includes end markets such as municipal and industrial wastewater markets. Based on the same report, the global industrial market was estimated to be approximately $23 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 4.0% CAGR for the five-year period 2020 to 2025 for both the wastewater and core water treatment markets. The municipal market is expected to grow at a 4.3% CAGR for the five-year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same report, as demand continues to increase from higher per capita usage of water, population growth and increasing regulatory demands. Growth in the core water treatment market, including both heavy and light industrial markets, is expected to be driven by increasing sustainability and environmental policies, growing regulatory demands and global industrial growth. This growth is expected to be highest in the food and beverage market (5.5% CAGR for the five year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same report) and the refining and petrochemicals market (4.0% CAGR for the five-year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same report). Approximately 20% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 was generated from the Industrial market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Pool
Subsubsection Text: The aftermarket for the residential pool industry is comprised of three main segments: (1) Chemicals, (2) Equipment, Parts, and Accessories and (3) Services. Our main focus is on the Chemicals segment which is the largest and most stable component of aftermarket pool spend. Pool chemicals sales are tied to: (1) the pool installed base and (2) total gallons of treatable water, and not new builds. The U.S. pool installed base has displayed long-term stability as it has consistently grown for decades, including all years through the housing-led recession and during the COVID-19 pandemic period, which is providing current tailwinds for the business. As of December 31, 2022, the installed base of U.S. in ground pools was 9 million, based on a recent study by a leading research firm in the pool and spa market. However, new builds account for less than 4% of the installed base annually, meaning that new build rates are unlikely to materially impact our long-term performance. The Pool Solutions segment also benefits from a stable aftermarket spend that mirrors the steady dynamic of the installed base. Our chemical-based products result in 100% aftermarket exposure, which reduces our exposure to cyclical industry trends such as housing starts. Pool chemical use is entirely non-discretionary in that it is a requirement for owning and using a pool. Pool owners who have already made the significant upfront investment of constructing a pool, estimated to cost $40,000 to $100,000, will continue to purchase pool chemicals, at the de minimis annual expense of $300 to $400 in order to maintain their pools. The pool chemical treatment market includes products such as primary sanitizers (71% of total market sales), specialty chemicals, other shocks and alternative sanitizers. Primary sanitizers include cal-hypo, sodium hypochlorite (“sodium-hypo”), trichlor, dichlor and packaged shocks. The total market for U.S. residential pool chemicals, based on retail dollar value, was approximately $2.6 billion in 2020 and grew by 28% in 2021 to approximately $3.4 billion, primarily due to higher prices resulting from scarcity of chlorine based on a recent study by a leading research firm in the pool and spa market. We believe the U.S. residential pool chemical market, on a volume basis, will exceed the expected growth of the installed base of U.S. residential pools, which was estimated to be 3.0% from 2020 to 2025 based on a recent study by a leading research firm in the pool and spa market. We further believe that volumes in our pool solutions segment will exceed the market as we expand our customer base and increase market sale with new dealer relationships and e-commerce.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Institutional
Subsubsection Text: The Institutional Solutions market growth is driven by an aging population, increasing demand for healthcare facilities, return to office policies continued to drive an increase demand for cleaning, the introduction of new sanitization standards arising post-COVID and a focus on new infrastructure bills to expand healthcare and transportation networks. Based on a third-party report completed in February 2023, the Institutional Solutions segment is growing at a CAGR of 5.3% for the four year period 2022 to 2026. The manufacturing and commercial and healthcare and hospitality sub-end markets are expected to grow at a CAGR of 5.1% and 5.5%, respectively, for the four year period 2022 to 2026. 185 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Food & Beverage
Subsubsection Text: The Food & Beverage market growth is driven by an increase in governmental concerns over food safety and oversight driving increased regulation, shifting consumer preferences in (1) mature markets, towards organic and simple and (2) in emerging markets, towards more processed foods and a growing global population driving increased consumption of food and beverage. Based on a third-party report completed in February 2023, the Food & Beverage segment is expected to grow at a CAGR of 6.5% for the four year period 2022 to 2026.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Competitive Landscape
Subsubsection Text: _Consumer Solutions_ We believe, based on a report by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021, that we are the market leader in specialty chemicals for the Consumer Solutions segment. Based on the same report, we believe that we maintain market leadership positions in almost all technologies and regions. The competitive landscape, as segmented by geography or technology, remains fragmented. We have particularly strong market positions in 187  Recovering economy post-COVID  Increasing global population driving growth and increased free disposable income in Food & Beverage 6.5% $14.3 12% developing countries  Growing interest in green cleaning products and dosage / packaging solutions that streamline cleaning process costs ----- process chemicals within the biocide, contaminant control, defoamer, tissue specialties and pulp specialties technologies. Our strength is based on the complete product portfolio, premium product performance and strong technical support we offer. We believe we have the best and the broadest offering to help customers achieve their operational efficiencies. We are a trusted supplier known for our data analytics capacities, with a focus on service excellence, sustainability, productivity and cost savings for our customers. Many customers are starting to embrace digital technology / data analytics to help track performance and starting to partner with suppliers with strong R&D capabilities to develop innovative solutions to drive efficiency and achieve sustainability objectives. This trend is expected to continue and we expect to benefit from it due to our robust value-added chemistry and technology solutions offering. _Industrial Solutions_ The global industrial water chemicals market is fragmented, with the top seven players, based on a report by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021. This is due to the required application-specific expertise and track-record of performance. Hence, by region and by end-user market, three to five players may have a disproportionately high share. We believe we have an outsized share of the global pulp and paper market, which is one of our larger markets within the Industrial Solutions segment. We believe we offer the lowest per unit cost for comparable chemicals compared to our industry peers and believe that the competitive pricing is our greatest strength in the Industrial Solutions segment. Additionally, we offer an array of innovative solutions and comprehensive product lines both in core water treatment and wastewater segment. Notable competitors include Ecolab / Nalco, Suez, ChemTreat, Kurita, Kemira and SNF. Ecolab, which acquired Nalco in 2011, is the largest water treatment player followed by Suez. Similar to the Consumer market, technology and R&D are becoming increasingly important beyond the chemical product itself as customers are moving towards advanced analytics to optimize the volume of chemical treatment, driving select industry participants to increasingly focus on equipment / engineering solutions as opposed to chemical solutions. _Pool Solutions_ We believe we are the only true global player in the Pool Solutions segment with leading market positions in North America, South America, and EMEA. We believe the acquisition of Clearon further enhanced our market leading position. Our primary competitor in this segment is KIK Custom Products, which provides various pool chemical solutions, with a focus on North America. Other smaller competitors also compete in this market, with varying breadth and geographical focus, including Hasa Pool, Jandy, Lo-chlor and Jack’s Magic. We believe we are the world’s largest producer of cal-hypo, a primary chemical used in water treatment and sanitation. All three of our cal-hypo facilities are co-located with chlor-alkali producers meaning that raw materials (chlorine and caustic soda) are delivered into our production plants via a direct pipeline. We believe this is a major competitive advantage and barrier to entry in the Pool Solutions segment as we believe it would not be economical for our competitors to open a new cal-hypo facility that is not co-located with a supply of raw materials. The acquisition of Clearon provided additional manufacturing capabilities for trichlor and dichlor and we are now the only producer of cal-hypo, trichlor and dichlor, which we believe will give us a significant advantage over our competitors. Further, Clearon’s manufacturing facility located in West Virginia was isolated from the impact of natural disasters that other competitors have experienced with facilities located on the Gulf Coast. _Institutional Solutions_ Diversey is a major global player in the Institutional Solutions segment and competes primarily with Ecolab. Other competitors in this segment include: SC Johnson, Gojo, Kalykim and Jasol. In this highly fragmented market, Diversey and Ecolab together hold approximately a 20% global market share. Geographically, Diversey believes it is the number one or number two player in the North America, Europe, Middle East and Africa, Latin America and Asia-Pacific regions. Other competitors are focused on niche segments and geographies, focusing on regional and local customers. 188 ----- Diversey is positioned to compete using a recurring revenue business model built on consumable products that require periodic replacement and high customer switching costs via a suite of proprietary dosing and dispensing equipment installed at customer sites. Further, to better compete with Ecolab in North America, Diversey is in the process of opening a new co-manufacturing / co-warehouse facility in Northern Kentucky, alongside consolidating certain existing service centers to increase manufacturing and logistical efficiencies and insourcing opportunities. After giving effect to the Transactions, we believe that we will be better positioned to compete with Ecolab for leadership across all markets. We believe that the combined company is best positioned to capture share on a global scale due to Diversey’s strong existing market position, combined with our own position and track record of sustained growth and the white space afforded by such a fragmented market. _Food & Beverage_ Diversey is one of the only two global players in the Food & Beverage segment and competes primarily with Ecolab. The Food & Beverage market is largely consolidated and Diversey and Ecolab together hold approximately half of the global market share. Ecolab and Diversey generally compete within cleaning and hygiene solutions. Other, smaller competitors exist including Zep, Reckitt and Kersia. These players tend to service more regional markets and operate with highly limited product and distribution capabilities. Prior to the Transactions, we entered into a distribution relationship with Diversey through which we provide water treatment products to be marketed to Diversey’s existing customer base within its Food & Beverage segment. This current offering sets Diversey apart from Ecolab and represents an opportunity for additional market capture and cross-selling in the future following the consummation of the Transactions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Sustainability and Environmental and Social Governance
Subsubsection Text: We drive sustainability by reducing water and energy use and raw materials waste while improving operational productivity. Increased focus on sustainability and ESG is a key trend across both Consumer Solutions and Industrial Solutions segments and is driving demand as our customers aim to reduce water and energy consumption, optimize raw materials spend and reduce waste emission. These objectives require increased chemical use which is driving increased demand for our business. Institutional products are designed to enhance cleanliness, safety, environmental sustainability, and efficiency needed to serve our customers in the healthcare, education, food service, retail and grocery, hospitality, and building service contractor industries. Food & Beverage solutions will maximize food safety, operational excellence, and sustainability for our customers in the brewing, beverage, dairy, processed foods, pharmaceutical and agriculture industries. At the micro level, we provide solutions to customers with specific sustainability goals. For example, our offering of PFAS-free oil and grease resistant technology has been selected by major brand owners as a replacement in food service bowls. We also made a series of recommendations to a chemical company which resulted in a reduction of 28,000 cubic meters of water per year and 3,000 tons of CO2 emissions. The resulting savings for our customer were approximately $27 million per year. Further, our cal-hypo-based shocks that are sold at big-box retailers eliminate the need to drain and refill pools due to over stabilization, resulting in potential water savings of up to 600 gallons per pound used instead of dichlor and we estimate approximate water savings of up to 25 billion gallons per year. Diversey’s Clax® Advanced laundry solution supports clean and bright laundry at low wash temperatures to lower operational costs and reduce its customers’ environmental impact. Further, its delivers excellent linen hygiene and extends linen life. Clax® Advanced provides solutions in a variety of industrial laundry applications globally such as hotels and nursing homes, with substantial operational savings in conserving energy and water while reducing waste. Benefits of this offering include: (1) up to a 35% reduction in water use (or 8,000 kilo liters; the equivalent of three Olympic swimming pools), (2) up to a 40% reduction in steam use (or 600 metric tons), up to a 15% reduction in electricity use (or 5,000 kilowatt hour), (3) up to a 16% reduction in wash time (or ~150 work days), (4) up to 35% effluent (or 8,000 kilo liters), (5) up to 100 metric tons reduction in CO2 emissions and (6) up to 30% extension in linen life. Our management is dedicated to, and focused on, building and marketing our strong ESG reputation, shifting to green products and providing value-added services to help our customers achieve their sustainability targets. Focusing on solving customers’ environmental and sustainability challenges has led to notable results for Solenis. As of September 30, 2022, (1) 86% of innovation projects in the pipeline had a sustainability / circularity focus, (2) 83% of Net sales was driven by projects that support customers’ sustainability goals, (3) 15% of innovation programs focused on carbon footprint projects, (4) reduced our CO2 emissions by 5% from fiscal year ended 2018 and (5) we had an Environmental Incident Classification (“EIC”) score of 49 with a goal to reduce by 189 ----- 10% each year. As of the end of fiscal year 2022, Diversey’s notable results include: (1) eliminating 100 metric tons of waste, (2) conserving 10 billion gallons of water, (3) saving 1.1 billion kilowatt hours of energy and (4) saving 290 thousand metric tonnes of CO2-equivalent emissions. We are also focused on long term sustainability goals for our business that include the following long term goals: (1) over 92.5% of our suppliers to be compliant with our sustainable procurement standards, (2) 20% reduction in CO2 emissions, (3) 5% reduction in water consumption, (4) over 90% of new innovation projects to have a sustainability / circularity focus, (5) over 90% of our revenues to support our customers’ sustainability goals, (6) 100% of our plants to be ISO 9001, RC14001, ISO 14001, ISO 45001 and SEDEX certified and (7) 5% return on investment from every commercial person focusing on reduction in energy, water and raw materials as well as improved productivity. Diversey’s long term sustainability goals for its business include the following long term goals: (1) environment: achieving (i) net positive impact for energy, water, waste and GHG, (ii) net zero carbon emissions and (iii) 100% core packaging contributing to a circular economy, (2) social: (i) fostering an inclusive and diverse workforce with 40% gender diversity globally and 25% ethnic diversity in the United States, (ii) improving its employee engagement score to the top quartile, (iii) ensuring 100% employee safety, with zero workplace injuries and (iv) improving the lives of people in the communities Diversey operates in, and (3) governance: ensure (i) engagement with stakeholders, (ii) transparency of results and (iii) 100% compliance with policies.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsection Title: Summary of Operational Improvements and Synergies Initiatives related to the Acquisition
Subsubsection Text: We, along with Platinum, have identified expected synergies resulting from the Transactions. We identified an estimated $205 million in net annual cost synergies expected to be implemented within 24 months of closing the Transactions which are expected to be realized through consolidation of support and sales functions, materials sourcing consolidation and facility consolidation, as follows: - Approximately $97 million of cost synergies are expected to be achieved through organizational design opportunities via consolidation of Diversey’s back office into Solenis’ across the finance, information technology, human resources, legal, environmental, health and safety, commercial, research and development and marketing functions. The foregoing includes $51 million in optimizing overall organizational structure and number of employees for key functions, $33 million in elimination of redundant leadership positions and management roles and $14 million for the leveraging of existing shared service centers across the combined company. - Approximately $44 million of cost synergies are expected to be achieved related to direct and indirect sourcing opportunities, including $30 million related to leveraging combined chemicals and commodities spend and higher purchasing power to drive more favorable contracts by both product type and supplier and $13 million related to leveraging combined indirect spend categories with supplier rationalization to reduce fragmentation and tail spend in certain categories, consolidation of technologies, and telecom, network and data center optimization. - Approximately $64 million of cost synergies are expected to be achieved through manufacturing and distribution center optimization and consolidation, transportation logistics efficiencies and real estate consolidation, including $23 million related to consolidating overlapping footprints and removing excess capacity, $37 million related to optimizing outbound transportation based on facility consolidation and production shifts between plants to optimize shipping networks to nearest point of origin, procuring freight more effectively and improving contract compliance, and $5 million related to optimizing office footprint to reduce redundancies, underutilized office space by renegotiating leases and eliminating smaller offices with little to no headcount by converting to remote work or providing alternative locations. To achieve the identified synergies, we expect to incur approximately $190 million in total of one-time costs related to severance, retention, information technology system integration and consulting, among other costs. The initiatives to realize the Transactions synergies have and will be executed by a dedicated implementation team with support from Platinum operational executives and third-party resources. However, there can be no assurance that we will be able to achieve these synergies or operational improvements. For more information about our anticipated synergies, including certain factors that may affect our ability to achieve such synergies or operational improvements, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition and the Legacy Acquisitions—We may not achieve some or all of the expected benefits from the items reflected in the adjustments included in Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project 190 ----- Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies).
