Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsection Title: Summary of Operational Improvements and Synergies Initiatives related to the Legacy Acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: We, along with Platinum, identified synergies resulting from the Solenis Acquisition. We achieved $40 million in annual cost synergies from actions that were taken within 18 months of the Solenis Acquisition Closing Date. We, along with Platinum, also identified expected synergies resulting from the Clearon Acquisition. We identified an estimated $13 million in net annual cost synergies from actions taken or expected to be taken within 24 months of closing the Clearon Acquisition. As of March 31, 2023, we have achieved $6.5 million and expect to achieve $6.5 million from actions taken to date or to be taken in the next 15 months. These synergies are expected to be realized through headcount rationalization and non-labor optimization spend net of certain incremental expenses. The initiatives to realize both the Solenis Acquisition and Clearon Acquisition synergies have and will continue to be executed by a dedicated implementation team with support from Platinum operational executives and third-party resources. However, there can be no assurance that we will be able to achieve the remaining synergies or operational improvements. For more information about our anticipated synergies, including certain factors that may affect our ability to achieve such synergies or operational improvements, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition and the Legacy Acquisitions—We may not achieve some or all of the expected benefits from the items reflected in the adjustments included in Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies).” The prospective unaudited financial information contained in this offering memorandum was not prepared with a view toward compliance with published guidelines of the SEC or the guidelines established by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants for preparation or presentation of prospective financial information. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Leading Provider in Growing Water Intensive and Relatively Recession Resilient End Markets
Subsubsection Text: We believe the size of Solenis’ total addressable market was $39 billion as of 2020 and that the market is relatively fragmented, with four top players, presenting an opportunity for us to capture share. Further, we believe the size of Diversey’s total addressable market is $46 billion. Our combined platform will create a scaled leader across all water intensive industries. Based on a report by a third-party expert advisor completed in June 2021, we believe that we have the #1 market position in the Consumer Solutions segment and are one of the top market players in the highly fragmented Industrial Solutions segment. Additionally, we believe we are one of two top 191 ----- players in the U.S. pool and spa chemicals market. After giving effect to the Transactions, we believe we will be one of the top players in the Institutional Solutions and Food & Beverage markets. We serve a variety of growing diverse water-intensive end markets, including consumer chemicals (estimated by a third-party expert advisor to grow at 1.8% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030), industrial chemical (estimated by a third-party expert advisor to grow at 4.0% CAGR for the five-year period 2020 to 2025), and pool and spa (estimated by a recent study by a leading research firm in the pool and spa market at 3%+ CAGR). As a combined company, other end markets will include institutional (estimated by a third-party expert to grow at over 5.3% CAGR for the four-year period 2022 to 2026) and food & beverage (estimated by a third-party expert to grow at 6.5% CAGR for the four-year period 2022 to 2026). We have a comprehensive portfolio of solutions including Biocides, Antifoams, Raw and Waste Water treatments, Deposit Control, Dosing & Dispensing Equipment, proprietary owned chemical formulas among others for our customers to address their needs in these growing end markets. We believe that the majority of the end markets we serve are relatively recession resilient, which in combination with our business management, will protect us from any severe impact to our profitability in the event of an economic downturn. The following table summarizes our belief on the recession resiliency the end market for each of our segments. Segment End Market Food Packaging & Molded Fiber Packaging End Market Resilience Market Drivers - Minimal impact to food packaging as focus on sustainable High alternatives drives continued momentum Consumer Solutions Consumer Neutral Packaging Tissue & High Towel Graphic & Specialty Neutral - Limited impact to general packaging as lower consumer purchasing is partially offset by continued shift to eCommerce - Tissue & Towel volumes remain robust during recessionary periods driven by continued consumer demand for non-discretionary end products irrespective of macroeconomic conditions - Graphic & Specialty paper is impacted by a shift to online modes and experiences little to no demand impact due to food packaging - Return to work and back to school rebound will continue to drive category up over artificially low post pandemic base - Healthcare, education, and retail largely unaffected in recessionary periods due to criticality of end markets and need for consistent hygiene and infection prevention services, regardless of broader macroeconomic conditions - Food service, hospitality, and building services end markets remain resilient during recessionary periods. Dishwasher chemicals and laundry chemicals are partially tied to end consumer traffic and disinfectants and sanitizers are correlated with foot traffic Institutional Solutions Healthcare High Hospitality Neutral Manufacturing & Commercial - Moderate impact from decline in manufacturing during Neutral recessionary periods Industrial Solutions Wastewater High - Wastewater treatment is generally resilient due to the critical nature of the process and limited macroeconomic impact 192 ----- Core Water Neutral Treatment Food & Food & Beverage High Beverage - Other industrial water treatment is exposed to industrial manufacturing end markets, which presents a moderate impact during a downturn - Food & Beverage is largely unaffected during recessionary periods driven by continued need for protein processing, beverage production, and other food processing regardless and market conditions - Pool and spa end markets maintain strong demand during recessionary periods due to the necessity of constant maintenance or risk of expensive complications with the pool infrastructure - While commercial pool use may suffer slightly during recessionary periods, increased use of residential pools should lead to stronger consumer pool demand Pool Solutions Pool & Spa High

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Global Leader with Diverse Sticky Customer Base
Subsubsection Text: After giving effect to the Transactions, we will have a large geographical footprint that enables us to provide global service to our customers. We are present on six continents, with both laboratories and production facilities across the Americas, EMEA, and APAC, where we serve all major developed markets. After giving effect to the Transactions, we will have approximately 15,600 employees with a substantial presence across the North Americas, EMEA, and APAC regions. Our strategic global footprint allows us to efficiently and effectively serve customers around the world by providing consistent products and service. Diversey offers further expansion opportunities, particular given by its strength in EMEA. Our service and technical abilities are mission critical to our customers. Typically our trained value-add employees, scientists, and service engineers are embedded at customers’ sites, creating strong and long-term relationships. We represent a lower overall percentage of our customers’ cost base and have been able to achieve significant value add documented savings for our customers. We are highly engrained in our customers’ workflow, and it is often difficult, expensive, and potentially disruptive for customers to switch to a competitor. As a result, we believe Solenis’ Net sales is approximately 97% recurring, driven by our differentiated solutions and value proposition and will continue to remain over 97% recurring in the combined company. After giving effect to the Transactions, the top ten customers for the combined company are expected to represent approximately 12% of total Net sales with the largest customer representing approximately 2% of the combined company Net sales.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Differentiated Business Model with Best in Class Service, Chemistry, and Technology
Subsubsection Text: We believe our suite of comprehensive products and services unlocks customer value as a result of our industry leading employees and innovative technology offerings. Our solutions represent a small portion of our customers’ overall end costs and provide a significant return on investment. Our differentiated service model, with approximately 2,400 of our sales and service engineers on site with our customers, leads to highly recurring, nondiscretionary spending on our products and services, and with our solutions and value propositions including industry leading technology and equipment and artificial intelligence abilities, Solenis was able to achieve $179 million of value-add documented savings for our customers in the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. We offer innovative chemistries to address customers’ operational and sustainability challenges while our technology is at the forefront of the digitization of the water treatment industry. Further, we have product development capabilities to meet customers’ new and evolving needs, based on three main pillars. First, we have approximately 270 dedicated research and development professionals with two-thirds of our annual technology spend supporting those efforts. Second, our innovation pipeline includes approximately 47 projects, representing significant potential run-rate revenue, and features approximately 4,130 patents, including patents for chemical and equipment technologies. In total, Solenis has 2,259 patents issued and 613 patents currently pending, while Diversey has 1,108 patents issued and 150 patents currently pending. Lastly, our strategically located facilities around the world focus on analyzing and diagnosing products and processes, as well as conducting testing to recommend effective improvements that enhance both productivity and quality for our customers. This is critical as new and innovative products carry a higher than average margin and this mix shift is expected to drive increased profitability for our business. 193 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Attractive Financial Profile with Strong Top Line Growth, Expanding Margins, and Robust Free Cash Flow Generation
Subsubsection Text: Our global business has shown strong topline growth, and we believe Solenis’ Net sales is approximately 97% recurring, driven by our differentiated solutions and value proposition and will continue to remain over 97% recurring in the combined company, with the core business growing during the COVID-19 pandemic. By optimizing our cost structure through a strict focus on maximizing operational efficiencies using new technologies, reducing redundancies and leveraging existing infrastructure, we have seen improved Adjusted EBITDA growth and attractive margin expansion. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, our Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies) margin was approximately 18%. Our topline growth and price increases offsetting inflation along with low working capital intensity and minimal capital expenditures allow for significant free cash flow generation. See “Summary—Summary Historical Financial and Pro Forma Financial Data.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Long Tenured, Industry Leading Management Team with Strong Track Record
Subsubsection Text: We have an experienced management team with long tenures in the industry and experience in the sector, which has been recognized as a US Best Managed Company by Deloitte and The Wall Street Journal for 2021, 2022 and 2023. We are led by John E. Panichella, who has been CEO of Solenis since its inception in 2014, following the initial carve-out from Ashland. Through organic growth and M&A, particularly the merger with BASF, Panichella has steered Solenis to global leadership in the specialty chemicals for water-intensive industries. Prior to leading Solenis, John served as President of AWT, SVP of Ashland, Group Operating Officer of Ashland Specialty Ingredients and AWT, and President of Ashland Aqualon Functional ingredients. Surrounding John is a deep bench across operations, technology, commercial and finance, including Philip M. Patterson, Jr, our CFO, Edward Connors, President of the Americas, Jacques Herber, President of Eurasia, and Robert Baird, President of the Pool Solutions business. Our experienced team will drive long-term stability of the business and support future growth.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Well Positioned to Grow with Macro and ESG Mega Trends
Subsubsection Text: We believe our sophisticated product development capabilities meet our customers’ evolving needs and help keep us at the forefront of macroeconomic trends. Our ability to evolve is based on three pillars that allow us to grow our product offering alongside client demands: R&D, Innovation and Customer Application Laboratories. Our R&D team has approximately 270 dedicated professionals and two thirds of annual technology investment supports R&D. Our robust innovation pipeline currently has approximately 47 projects and features approximately 4,130 patents, including those for chemical and equipment technologies. In total we have 3,367 patents issued and 763 patents currently pending. Customer application laboratories are strategically located facilities around the world focused on analyzing and diagnosing products and processes, as well as conducting testing to recommend effective improvements that enhance both productivity and quality. We focus on solving our customers’ environmental and sustainability challenges, placing us at the forefront of the ESG mega trend. Through identification of specific goals such as reduction of water consumption, reduction of energy consumption, reduction of waste emissions or optimization of raw materials utilization, we have been able to work with customers to meet their unique needs. Our sophisticated capabilities have helped customers meet evolving sustainability goals and achieve measurable results.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Pricing Discipline to Drive Margin Growth
Subsubsection Text: We have a track-record of actively monitoring and managing prices, enabling the pass-through of raw material cost increases to maintain margins. Through Solenis’ value-documentation program, sales teams have accountability requirements to show that at least 5% of Net sales deliver a value advantage to customers, which enables price capture even in deflationary environments. This has enabled us to pass through a majority of increases in raw chemical materials, which are one of the major drivers for cost inflation, to customers by adjusting prices accordingly. We began to see a significant increase in the price of our raw materials, including ethylene and propylene, during the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 and we began to pass on price increases to our customers. Typically, we experience an approximately 90-day lag in implementing our price increases, however, during the six months ended March 31, 2023, we exceeded our goals and were able to drive price increases even faster with price exceeding cost during the six months ended March 31, 2023 in all of our business segments. While Diversey continues to adjust prices to pass through increases in raw materials costs, Diversey was slower to react to the inflationary cost environment than Solenis, which resulted in more pronounced margin compression throughout 2022 than Solenis. Once combined, Diversey’s performance is expected to improve as they will operate on Solenis’ value-documentation program. Typically, Diversey experiences an approximately 90-day lag in implementing our price increases, however, during the six months ended March 31, 2023, Diversey exceeded its goals and was able to drive price increases even faster with Cost of goods sold inflation during the six months ended March 31, 2023 in its Institutional Solutions and Food & Beverage segments. The charts below summarize our and Diversey’s success in implementing price increases and maintaining price ahead of cost. 195 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Enhance Profitability Through Identified Synergies and Operational Improvements
Subsubsection Text: We believe that through the realization of the synergies and operational improvement initiatives, which we have identified together with Platinum, we will enhance our profitability and support our strategic initiatives. The approximately $205 million of synergies was identified with the collaboration of the Solenis and Diversey management teams, along with Platinum, and reflect actions which we believe can be implemented within 24 months of the closing of the Transactions. The Platinum team has an extensive track record of leveraging our operational resources to achieve anticipated cost savings. We cannot assure you we will be able to achieve all of these cost synergies. For more information about our anticipated cost synergies and operational improvements, including certain factors that may affect our ability to achieve such cost synergies and operational improvements, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition and the Legacy Acquisitions—We may not achieve some or all of the expected benefits from the items reflected in the adjustments included in Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega), Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Legacy Acquisitions, Related Synergies and Project Mega) and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After the Acquisition and Related Synergies).” The prospective unaudited financial information contained in this offering memorandum was not prepared with a view toward compliance with published guidelines of the SEC or the guidelines established by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants for preparation or presentation of prospective financial information. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Selectively Pursue Strategic Acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: While our primary focus is on organic growth, our global presence, scale and broad product offering position us well to execute on opportunistic acquisitions given the large and fragmented nature of the markets we serve or to expand into new markets. We estimate that the markets adjacent to our market represent a total market size of $42 billion and represent potential expansion areas, including the ion exchange and coagulants markets. We believe that we can create significant value through strategic acquisitions given our track record of integration. Solenis has completed 17 acquisitions since 2014, including the transformative and successful merger with BASF’s water and paper business in the fiscal year ended September 30, 2019 and the Solenis Acquisition in fiscal year 2022. We will focus on maintaining a disciplined acquisition strategy centered on: (i) expanding our customer base in new and growing end markets and geographies; (ii) improving our customer offering through access to new products and technological capabilities; and (iii) generating significant purchasing and other operational synergies. 196 ----- The graphic below sets forth a summary of our acquisitions since 2014.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Strategically Invest in High Return Capital Expenditures Expansion
Subsubsection Text: Our key capital expenditure projects include production capacity expansion for polyvinyl amine (“PVAM”) at our Suffolk, Virginia facility and calcium hypochlorite (cal-hypo) at our Charleston, Tennessee and Kempton Park, South Africa facilities. Our expansion efforts will eliminate existing capacity constraints and better position us to capitalize on customer demand for these high-margin products. Our engineering estimates for all facilities are underway with expansion efforts expected to be online in 2026. We expect the PVAM and cal-hypo expansions to cost $150 million and $100 million, respectively. A majority of our customers, especially those producing packaging and tissue and towel products, are focused on improving strength. We are a market leader in strength chemistry, with the broadest portfolio of synthetic strength additives like PVAM and are the leading supplier of global PVAM production. Previously PVAM was originally sold by BASF and we acquired full commercial rights as part of 2019 merger. However, in advance of the merger, BASF raised prices substantially, resulting in lost sales. Post integration, we refilled the pipeline and returned the product to growth, however, in recent years, our PVAM volumes have been constrained despite debottlenecking programs implemented and we have been unable to return to pre-BASF merger levels. Further, in fiscal year 2022, we experienced shutdowns and product issues resulting in production allocation and customer management challenges. To solve our capacity constraint, we are looking to build incremental capacity at our existing Suffolk, Virginia facility, which is expected to be online by the end of 2026 that will enable us to increase capacity by approximately 100%. Cal-hypo is a highly concentrated source of chlorine in solid form and is a cost-effective solution primarily used for pool sanitization and maintenance with secondary uses to disinfect water in industrial and municipal markets. Our Solenis HTH[ TM] and Poolife[TM] offerings are cal-hypo-based shocks that eliminate the need to drain and refill pools due to over stabilization with other benefits including minimized storage requirements, dry formulation for shelf stability and easy handling, reduced shipping and handling costs and reduced maintenance. We are currently experiencing capacity constraints at our Kempton Park, South Africa facility. Further, given over 50% of global supply is produced in either China or India, importing incremental capacity is both challenging and costly. Due to these constraints, we are looking to expand our capacity. Expansion efforts at our Kempton Park facility are underway and are expected to be completed by fiscal year ended 2023 or 2024. Further, we are pursuing a site selection process for additional capacity including assessing potential new locations, with the expectation that all facilities will be online by 2026. In the interim, we will look to temporarily source incremental capacity via third parties to pre-seed the plant which we believe will drive top line growth in the near team and insourcing savings in the future. Following its return to the United States market, Diversey’s current management team identified potential 197 ----- manufacturing and logistical efficiencies and insourcing opportunities by re-positioning and consolidating certain existing service centers. This supply chain improvement process is referred to as “Project Mega.” Project Mega includes a largely complete consolidation of the North American supply chain footprint through the creation of a manufacturing plant and co-located warehouse in Northern Kentucky, as well as warehouse consolidation in Europe. Diversey started shipping from the new Kentucky warehouse in July 2022 and is consolidating its manufacturing capabilities into the same Kentucky facility. Further, Project Mega is consolidating five Diversey (three Institutional and two Food & Beverage) plants into four plants (two Institutional and two Food & Beverage) and is planning on closing two Wisconsin plants. By co-locating its main warehouse and manufacturing capabilities, and adding more capacity to bring currently contracted volumes in-house and optimizing freight lanes, the project is expected to drive approximately $30 million of annual cost savings. The run rate cost savings includes $11 million related to manufacturing efficiencies from increased insourcing from contract manufacturers, more efficient lines and fixed absorption, co-location of liquid manufacturing and wipes conversion and an optimized flow of processes, $10 million related to logistics and the ability to avoid shipping between sites along with having new sites closer to suppliers and customers, $7 million related to direct savings achieved from materials sourcing using larger orders (i.e. from drums to bulk orders), $1 million related to warehousing from lower rent and co-locating with manufacturing and $2 million related to other. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: We believe we are well positioned to grow organically and capture share through several distinct strategies. Supportive end market trends that drove historical growth are expected to continue over the next five to ten years. We have successfully maintained strong pricing discipline to offset inflationary increases to input costs and shift customers to a more profitable mix, driving margin growth. The combination creates unique, value accretive synergy opportunities, with line of sight on approximately $205 million of estimated cost synergies (resulting from actions expected to be taken within 24 months of the closing of the Transactions). Additionally, we achieved $40 million of cost synergies related to the Solenis Acquisition from actions that were taken within 18 months of the Solenis Acquisition Closing Date and we identified $13 million of cost synergies related to the Clearon Acquisition which are expected to be realized from actions already taken or expected to be taken within 24 months of the Clearon Acquisition Closing Date. As of March 31, 2023, we have realized $6.5 million of cost synergies related to the Clearon Acquisition. We are also well positioned to continue to grow through acquisitions via multiple M&A avenues. We have a proven track record as an M&A platform, with 17 transactions completed since 2014, including the transformative fiscal year 2019 merger with BASF’s water and paper business and the Solenis Acquisition in fiscal year 2022. We believe there is an opportunity for both strategic bolt-ons and transformational targets going forward. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Solenis
Subsubsection Text: Since the joint venture arrangement with BASF in January 2019, Solenis’ business has principally consisted of three operating segments: Pulp & Paper, Industrial Water, and Reverse Supply Agreements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Pulp & Paper. The Pulp & Paper (“P&P”) business manufactures and sells a broad array of process
Subsubsection Text: chemistry for the pulp and paper industry including deposit and scale control agents, defoamers, biocides, retention aids and crepe and release additives. These products are designed to deliver benefits such as enhanced operational efficiencies, system cleanliness and superior performance in a wide variety of manufacturing operations globally. In addition, the P&P business offers functional chemistry for packaging, tissue and towel, and printing and writing producers that impart specific properties such as wet or dry strength, colorants, surface size, liquid holdout and printing ability to the final paper or board. Products and technologies include internal and surface sizing agents and wet and dry strength additives.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Industrial Water. The Industrial Water (“IWT”) business offers specialized chemicals for the utility water
Subsubsection Text: treatment market including influent water, boiler water, cooling water and effluent water treatments. Products include scale and corrosion inhibitors, coagulants and flocculants, biocides, defoamers, anti-scaling for desalination, membrane treatments and sludge dewatering. In addition, the IWT business offers process additives such as frothers and collection aids, dust control additives, sterilization treatments, corn oil extraction and scale and corrosion inhibitors for mining and mineral processing, food processing, oil refining, chemicals processing and general manufacturing markets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Reverse Supply Agreements. As part of the joint venture with BASF in January 2019, Solenis agreed to
Subsubsection Text: provide certain finished goods to BASF, consistent with BASF’s historical cost and pricing structure, intended to allow BASF to uninterruptedly sustain its retained businesses. These arrangements and related activities comprise the Reverse Supply Agreements (“RSA”) segment of Solenis. As part of the resegmentation described below, RSA will become part of the go-forward Industrial Solutions segment. 198 ----- Solenis also provides automated equipment, including performance-based feed and control systems, proprietary monitoring devices and remote system surveillance. The utility products, services and equipment offerings are designed to protect plant assets and optimize energy, water and operational costs at customers’ facilities. As part of the resegmentation described below, equipment destined for packaging mills will become part of the go-forward Consumer Solutions segment. Equipment provided by refineries will form part of the go-forward Industrial Solutions segment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Sigura
Subsubsection Text: Beginning with the quarter ended March 31, 2021 and following the divestiture of its Surface Water business in October 2020, Sigura moved its commercial pools segment from the previous Industrial, Commercial, Municipal & Surface Water segment (now known as Industrial & Municipal Water segment) to be consolidated with the previous Residential Pool Segment under a newly named Pool Solutions segment. Additionally, Sigura has a third Other segment for other operations. Pools._** Sigura’s pool business offers the sale of sanitizers and other treatment chemicals for pools, spas and water parks. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, Sigura’s Pool segment had Net sales of $540 million, of which 71% was generated in North America, 22% in EMEA and 7% in Latin America. - **_Recreational Water. Sigura’s recreational pool and spa care portfolio brings clean, healthy water to households worldwide with a variety of shock, sanitizers, oxidizers, algaecides and balancers. Sigura’s trusted brands ensure clean and healthy water for its customers’ and consumers’ pools and spas across seasons. - **_Commercial Pools & Spas. Sigura’s commercial pool brands have been at the cutting edge of swimming pool water treatment for over 30 years. Its chlorination solutions are used worldwide for amusement parks, community pools, hotels, resorts, and professional training venues. Sigura specializes in powerful sanitizers, coagulants and pool maintenance products in order to deliver water clarity, color and sparkle to customers’ pools, while ensuring the highest level of water quality, and Sigura’s range of automated feed systems make such professional pool treatment easy to achieve. Industrial & Municipal Water._** Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal Water segment offers treatment of water for drinking, agriculture, irrigation, food processing and industrial applications. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal Water segment had Net sales of $63 million, of which 43% was generated in North America, 43% in EMEA and 14% in Latin America. - **_Industrial Water. Sigura’s Industrial segment (56% of twelve months ended June 30, 2021 total segment sales) is a leading specialty chemical supplier to the global water treatment market and is also a specialty chemical manufacturer. Sigura offers oxidizing and non-oxidizing biocides, feeders and dosing equipment to customers for use in power plants, cooling cycles, food and beverage and the paper industry. The combination of innovative technologies, patented solid biocide feed systems and thorough application knowledge allows Sigura to deliver leading edge solutions to its customers’ most demanding problems. - **_Municipal Water. Sigura’s Municipal segment (44% of twelve months ended June 30, 2021 total segment sales) is focused on helping provide access to clean drinking water and safe water supplies, which is fundamental to human health. Sigura’s global team of drinking water experts provide easy to use, modular chlorination systems, designed to solve each location’s unique operational requirements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: Following a strategic review related to Solenis’ operating segments and in anticipation of the closing of the Solenis Acquisition, changes were introduced in the segment reporting from October 1, 2021 onwards. The segmentation changes were made for the following reasons: (i) to align the segment structure to ensure that our financial reporting segments are in line with its strategic approach in demarcating its operations and (ii) to manage the business and make business decisions based on product lines and services in the most effective manner. Major changes to highlight included: (i) the creation of a new Pool Solutions segment to account for the contribution of Sigura’s Pools segment, focused on delivering products for the treatment of pools, spas and water 199 ----- parks, (ii) the renaming of the Pulp & Paper business as the Consumer Solutions business, (iii) the renaming of the Industrial Water business as the Industrial Solutions business, (iv) the reallocation of the food processing aspects of the business from the newly named Industrial Solutions business to sit with the other consumer-based products and services within the newly named Consumer Solutions business, (v) the reallocation of the pulp processing aspects of the business from the newly named Consumer Solutions business to sit with the other industrial-focused products and services within the newly named Industrial Solutions segment, (vi) the contribution of Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal Water business to the newly named Industrial Solutions segment and (vii) the inclusion of Solenis’ RSA business within the newly named Industrial Solutions segment. Consumer Solutions._** The Pulp & Paper segment of the historical Solenis business was renamed as the Consumer Solutions segment. The Consumer Solutions segment is mostly affected by the removal of Pulp and its reallocation to the Industrial Water segment (now renamed as the Industrial Solutions segment). Industrial Solutions._** The Industrial Water segment of the historical Solenis business was renamed as the Industrial Solutions segment. The Industrial Solutions segment is mostly affected by the inclusion of the RSA segment, the removal of Food and its reallocation to the Pulp & Paper segment (now renamed the Consumer Solutions segment) and the contribution of Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal business. Pool Solutions._** Sigura’s Pool segment, including residential and commercial pools, forms the new Pool Solutions business segment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Wellbeing, Health & Safety of Our People. Our long-standing reputation for solving highly complex
Subsubsection Text: customer challenges is directly attributed to our approximately 15,600 outstanding professionals, including 2,400 field representatives, working in 41 countries across five continents. It is our ambition to educate and engage our employees to reach their full potential and to create a safe and inclusive work environment in which they can continuously grow and succeed, and this is prioritized in our approach to culture, health and safety, diversity and inclusion, and training and development.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Protecting our Planet. In our operations, our focus is on ensuring responsible stewardship of the natural
Subsubsection Text: environment, by focusing on climate change and energy use initiatives, supporting circular economy and material 200 ----- use principles (increasing the contribution of recycled materials to overall materials demand), promoting water management and waste and pollution management and enabling our customers to manage resources and manufacturing processes more effectively. This includes continuing to ensure that all our sites meet, or exceed, all regulatory and environmental requirements, keeping abreast of changing applicable environmental laws and regulations, and providing products and services to our customers to help them meet, or exceed, their own environmental objectives.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Partnerships in Our Value Chain. Given our global reach, we recognize our responsibility towards
Subsubsection Text: employees, customers, suppliers, governments, investors and the local communities of which we are part. We are dedicated to responsibly managing relationships with our key stakeholders. An important element of this is partnering with employees to help address the needs of the communities where we operate and collaborating with our suppliers to increase transparency and sustainability in our supply chain.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Responsible Business Practices. We focus on operating with the highest ethical standards in all aspects of
Subsubsection Text: our business and protecting the rights and interests of all our stakeholders, individually and collectively. We treat personal data confidentially, adhering to effective policies and procedures securing lawfulness, fairness, transparency, integrity and confidentiality of personal data entrusted to Solenis by our employees, customers, suppliers, business partners and other individuals with whom we work. We are recognized globally for our legacy of technology innovation and we invest in developing new chemistries to improve customers’ products and processes. In 2020, Solenis embarked on a digital transformation effort focused on enhancing the customer experience using digital solutions. Our ambition for the future is to create more value for all our stakeholders while consuming less, thereby minimizing our impact on the environment and society. Supporting our customers in their sustainability journeys will always be central to our business. However, going forward we will also look inward, with a focus on consumption reduction and on product development with sustainability at its core. Following completion of the Transactions, the Diversey business will be integrated into these sustainability goals and commitments.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: Global demand for solutions that save water, use less energy, eliminate waste, and convert everyday products to more sustainable materials is continuing to grow. As a leader in sustainability, Solenis has been helping its customers tackle these complex challenges for more than 100 years. Global trends show that sustainability strategies are becoming strong differentiators for businesses and that stakeholders are increasingly interested in how key ESG issues are managed. ESG covers a broad set of issues, from the carbon dioxide footprint to labor practices to corruption. Consumers and employees are demanding higher standards of sustainability and quality of employment. Regulators and policy-makers are also interested in sustainability, and they see the corporate sector as a key player in the journey toward achieving sustainable development. One of the most relevant environmental issues for the chemical industry is the management of water resources. As freshwater sources like rivers or lake become increasingly stressed, the chemical industry is working with other sectors to increase water efficiency and to reduce water use in their operations and value chain. Businesses are also investing in recycling technologies, as well as incorporating renewable and recyclable materials in their product portfolio. With a water treatment heritage of more than a century, helping customers meet their environmental goals has always been one of the company’s highest priorities. In 2020, with a view to advancing our sustainability goals and commitments, we carried out a materiality assessment to identify the most material topics to stakeholders and the business. The aim was to identify ways to enhance the company’s existing sustainability efforts, improve transparency and disclosure, look for more opportunities to drive sustainable solutions and improve operational efficiency and productivity. Although involved in numerous sustainability initiatives for many years, the materiality assessment helped to inform the development of the company’s strategic sustainability approach going forward, organizing its actions and commitments across four focus areas:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: Although the COVID-19 pandemic presented us with many hurdles to overcome, we achieved considerable business successes through our business agility and creative approaches to solving customer problems. During the pandemic, the business remained strong, owing to the essential markets we serve, which include consumer packaging, tissue and towel, municipal and many other essential goods producers. These customers have ongoing needs for products and services to protect water and production assets. For consumer-related manufacturing, such as bath tissue and packaging for e-commerce, our customers increased production significantly in response to demand driven by the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences. In addition, COVID-19 has accelerated and driven many trends and changing behaviors globally, one of which is the concept of “cocooning.” This has resulted in a greater focus on the home environment, which has translated into increased residential pool builds in the North American and European geographies. Additionally, greater focus on home entertainment and health has increased residential pool usage and maintenance, which has positively impacted the demand for pool chemicals. A downside experienced from COVID-19 is the reduction in tourism and travel, which has resulted in a negative impact on commercial pool usage and resulted in decreased chemical usage in commercial pools. Overall, we believe that the positive impact on residential pools chemical usage during the COVID-19 pandemic has outweighed the negative impact to the commercial pools chemicals usage. We continued to observe strong market trends driving growth in sustainability, recycling, water reuse and plastic conversion to fiber. We are moving numerous programs through our R&D processes to put new services and products in the hands of our commercial team. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a meaningful impact on the Institutional Solutions segment being contributed by Diversey. Beginning the second quarter of 2020 and continuing through the first quarter of 2021, strong demand for our infection prevention products and services offset volume related declines in sales to restaurants, hotels and entertainment facilities. In the remainder of 2021 and into 2022, we saw restrictions and lockdowns start to ease in some markets, resulting in stronger than anticipated sales in those markets, except for 201 ----- infection prevention products. Sales of infection products normalized in the last three quarters of 2021 and in all of 2022. As economies around the world reopened, increases in demand created significant disruptions to the global supply chain during 2022, which affected our ability to receive goods on a timely basis and at anticipated costs. These supply chain disruptions have been caused and compounded by many factors, including changes in supply and demand, industry capacity constraints, raw material shortages and labor shortages. Global logistics network challenges have resulted in delays, shortages of certain materials, and increased transportation costs. We have materially mitigated to date the impact of these disruptions through the work of our procurement and supply chain teams, but there continues to be significant uncertainties regarding the future impact of supply chain disruptions, which we cannot predict. Additionally, we are in the process of consolidating certain facilities within North America, which includes opening a new manufacturing and warehousing facility, which could present short-term operational challenges and supply chain disruptions. We are a diversified business in regards to both industry segments and global geographic regions. These different aspects of our business are each impacted differently by COVID-19, supply chain disruptions and broader economic conditions. Therefore, the recovery cycle and related timing will also be different for each segment and region.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: Due to the nature of our business, we are subject to various laws and regulations pertaining to the environment, manufacturing, sale, transportation and disposal of hazardous products. These laws pertain to, among other things, air and water, management of solid and hazardous wastes, transportation, and human health and safety. Various federal, state, local and foreign laws and regulations regulate our products and often require us to obtain pre-market approval of our products and comply with specified requirements. In the U.S., we must register our sanitizing and disinfecting products with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and products intended for controlling microbial growth on humans, animals and processed foods with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Such products are regulated in a similar way at the European Union level by the European Chemical Agency or by member state competent authorities. Similar requirements exist in other countries such as China, Russia and South Korea. To date, the cost of complying with such product registration requirements has not had a material adverse effect on our business, consolidated financial condition, results of operations or cash flows. We maintain reserves for any anticipated liabilities pertaining to environmental laws and regulations. The total reserves for environmental remediation, reflect estimates of the most likely costs that will be incurred over an extended period to remediate identified conditions for which the costs are reasonably estimable, without regard to any third-party recoveries. Environmental remediation reserves are subject to numerous inherent uncertainties that affect our ability to estimate our share of any such costs. Such uncertainties involve the nature and extent of contamination at any site, the extent of required cleanup efforts under existing environmental regulations, widely varying costs of alternate cleanup methods, changes in environmental regulations, the potential effect of continuing improvements in remediation technology, and the number and financial strength of other potentially responsible parties at multiparty sites. As of March 31, 2023, Solenis had recorded environmental remediation reserves of $1.8 million, related to two ongoing and probable environmental remediation proceedings. Of the $1.8 million reserved, $1.0 million relates to potential exposure surrounding groundwater and soil contamination associated with a plant in Araraquara, Brazil. The remaining $0.8 million relates to management’s best estimate for potential exposure related to ground contamination at Solenis’ Milwaukee, Wisconsin plant as well as a reserve for a potential Environmental Protection Agency matter. The amount reserved for both matters represents management’s then-current best estimate of total expenses to be incurred. Diversey, similarly, is subject to loss contingencies resulting from environmental laws and regulations, and accrues for anticipated costs associated with investigatory and remediation efforts when an assessment has indicated that a loss is probable and can be reasonably estimated. These accruals are not reduced by potential insurance recoveries, if any. We do not believe that it is reasonably possible that liability in excess of the amounts that have been accrued for environmental matters will be material to our consolidated financial condition or results of operations. 202 ----- We are not currently aware of any other material environmental liabilities or other material environmental issues at our properties or arising from our current operations. However, we cannot assure you that such liabilities or issues will not materially adversely affect our business, financial position or results of operations in the future. We review environmental, health and safety laws and regulations pertaining to our operations and believe that compliance with current environmental and workplace health and safety laws and regulations has not had a material effect on our capital expenditures or consolidated financial condition.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: Our business competes on the basis of its demonstrated value, technical expertise, innovation, chemical formulations, customer support, detection equipment, monitoring capabilities, and dosing and metering equipment. Our principal competitors include Ecolab (Nalco), Kemira and SNF. We believe that we are well positioned to compete in our markets. In particular, we believe our differentiated product portfolio, with strong intellectual property, gives us a real competitive advantage. We executed a clear strategy around several growth vectors, including corporate accounts, emerging markets, new technologies, focused investment in water-intensive industries and polyacrylamide (PAM) manufacturing capabilities investment — and all showed good returns. Our scale provides a competitive benefit when compared with the smaller local or regional competitor providers, as we are able to leverage our distribution network to service smaller customers in a cost-effective way. We also differentiate from our competitors through (i) the breadth of our offering — we are a truly global player with a full portfolio of water-intensive industry solutions, with best-in-class dosing and dispensing technologies and advanced analytics to optimize the processes for the customer, (ii) our delivery of a total solution to customers — operating as their trusted advisor in assessing operational efficiencies and leveraging our network of experts to solve customers’ most difficult problems on a time-critical path through our fast track laboratories, (iii) our commitment to constantly developing our portfolio to improve products, our development of new technologies to deliver increased customer savings, and our addition of new product categories to meet more customer needs, and (iv) the expertise of our workforce — who are highly trained in focused industries, and the majority of whom are embedded in customer facilities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Our Culture. Our mission is to strive to be each customer’s most trusted supplier. Our solutions drive
Subsubsection Text: sustainability by reducing water and energy use and raw material waste while improving operational efficiency and productivity. At its core, our focus is on profitable sustainability. Our culture is centered on fundamental beliefs around the importance of our people, continuous performance improvement and creating positive experiences in our interactions for every customer to fuel the growth of the business. Solenis brings together diverse perspectives in a safe, collaborative workplace that empowers our employees to solve the world’s most challenging process and sustainability challenges. We nurture a culture of inclusion and accountability and promote learning and development of all employees.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Health & Safety. We continuously strive to be a leader in health and safety. Our long-term ambition is to
Subsubsection Text: operate with zero injuries. To support this ambition, we have set a target to reduce our total recordable incident rate by at least 10% versus the prior year.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Diversity & Inclusion. A diverse workforce is integral to deliver our strategy. By embracing the unique
Subsubsection Text: strengths of each person and respecting and promoting differences, we believe that we can build the most effective teams and enhance Solenis’ performance across our global operations. Our ambition is to double the number of diverse people in the company by 2030. 203 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Training and Development. In addition to recognizing and rewarding our employees for their
Subsubsection Text: achievements, we offer continuous learning and development opportunities. We proactively focus on creating personalized development plans for every individual, ensuring that joining Solenis — and staying with us — leads to a rewarding career that focuses on lifelong learning as well as personal and professional growth opportunities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: As of March 31, 2023, after giving effect to the Transactions, we had approximately 15,600 employees worldwide directly supporting our operations with approximately 3,919 employed in the United States. As of March 31, 2023, 184 of our employees in the United States, representing approximately 5% of our employees in the United States, were subject to collective bargaining agreements. These collective bargaining agreements are negotiated with various unions representing our employees. Our employees are at the heart of our mission and strategies, and to drive both, we focus on our culture.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: We strategically manage our portfolio of patents, trade secrets, copyrights, trademarks and other intellectual property. Specifically, we rely upon trade secrets to protect the formulation of many of our chemical products, as well as our manufacturing processes. We own or have licenses under patents and trademarks which are used in connection with our business. Some of these patents or licenses cover significant product formulations and processes used to manufacture our products. As of March 31, 2023, after giving effect to the Transactions, we held 498 U.S. patents, 2,869 foreign patents, and 85 U.S. and 678 foreign pending patent applications. The trademarks of major products in each business are registered in key jurisdictions or licensed from third parties. Certain intellectual property is also protected by confidentiality agreements or other agreements with suppliers, employees and other third parties. In part, our success can be attributed to the existence and continued protection of these trademarks, patents and trade secrets. The Diversey trademark and a select number of major sub-brands, including CLAX, SUMA and TASKI are material to the Diversey business, and while important, we do not believe that our overall business is materially dependent on any individual trade name, trademark or patent.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the matters described above (see “—Environmental Matters”), there are various claims, lawsuits and administrative proceedings that are pending or threatened. Such actions seek remedies or damages, some of which are for substantial amounts. We have accrued for legal reserves of $3.4 million as of March 31, 2023 and $2.8 million as of September 30, 2022. While we cannot predict with certainty the outcome of such actions, we believe that adequate reserves have been recorded and losses already recognized with respect to such actions. In addition to its uncertain tax positions, we have accrued for various contingent liabilities related to indirect taxes. As of March 31, 2023 and September 30, 2022, we have accrued for potential exposure related to these positions of less than $0.1 million and less than $0.1 million, respectively, of which Solenis is indemnified for less than $0.1 million and less than $0.1 million, respectively, by the former owners of Solenis’ business combinations since inception. In the normal course of business both in the United States and abroad, we are a defendant in various lawsuits and legal proceedings which may result in adverse judgments, damages, fines or penalties and is subject to inquiries and investigations by various governmental and regulatory agencies concerning compliance with applicable laws and regulations. In view of the inherent difficulty of predicting the outcome of legal matters, we cannot state with confidence what the timing, eventual outcome, or eventual judgment, damages, fines, penalties or other impact of these pending matters will be. We believe, based on our current knowledge, that the outcome of the legal actions, proceedings and investigations currently pending should not have a material adverse effect on our financial condition. Diversey is subject to various legal claims arising in the normal course of business. Based on information currently available, it is the opinion of Diversey management that the ultimate resolution of pending and threatened legal proceedings will not have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial position, or cash flows. However, in the event of unexpected future developments, it is possible that the ultimate resolution of such matters, if unfavorable, could have a material adverse effect on Diversey’s results of operations, financial position, or cash flows. 206 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Text: Below are the names, ages as of March 31, 2023, positions and a brief account of the business and experience of certain of the individuals who serve as executive officers and directors of the Issuer.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: John E. Panichella
Subsubsection Text: John E. Panichella has been Chief Executive Officer of Solenis since the company’s inception in 2014. Mr. Panichella has held leadership roles in the global water industry for nearly 40 years, including Senior Vice President of Ashland, Inc. from 2008 to 2014, President, AWT at Ashland, Inc. from 2013 to 2014, Group Operating Officer, Ashland Specialty Ingredients and AWT at Ashland, Inc. from 2012 to 2013, President, Ashland Specialty Ingredients at Ashland, Inc. from 2008 to 2012, President, Ashland Aqualon Functional Ingredients for Ashland, Inc. from 2006 to 2008, Vice President of General Electric Water and Process Technologies from 2001 to 2006, and Vice President, Global Hydrocarbon Processing at BetzDearborn from 2000 to 2001. He is also a member of the board of directors for the American Chemistry Council, the European Chemical Industry Council and United Way of Delaware. In 2016, he received the Winthrop-Sears Medal for Entrepreneurial Achievement from The Chemists Club of New York. Mr. Panichella holds a master’s degree in business administration from the University of Phoenix, in Tempe, Arizona, and a bachelor’s degree in chemistry from the University of Pittsburgh.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Philip M. Paterson, Jr.
Subsubsection Text: Philip M. Patterson, Jr. has been Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer for Solenis since 2018. Mr. Patterson was previously the Senior Vice President, Strategy and Chief Financial Officer, CP Kelco division of J.M. Huber Corp. from 2011 to 2018, Chief Financial Officer, Engineered Materials Division, CP Kelco division of the J.M. Huber Corp. from 2010 to 2011, and Chief Financial Officer of Aqualon Group, Hercules, Inc. from 2007 to 2010. Mr. Patterson holds an executive master’s degree in business administration in finance and a bachelor’s degree in accounting, both from the University of Delaware. He has also completed coursework in strategy at The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Mr. Patterson is a Certified Public Accountant, a member of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the Delaware Society of Certified Public Accountants and the CFO Advisory Board.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Edward J. Connors
Subsubsection Text: Ed Connors has been President, Americas and Global Water Technology for Solenis since 2019. Mr. Connors is responsible for all sales, marketing and technology operations in North America and Latin America, in addition to global strategy for the company’s industrial water treatment business. Mr. Connors was previously Senior Vice President, Industrial Water Technologies for Solenis from 2014 to 2018, Group Vice President, Ashland Specialty Ingredients at Ashland, Inc. from 2013 to 2014, Group Vice President, Coatings and Construction Specialties for Ashland, Inc. from 2011 to 2013, and Vice President, Research and Development Marketing for Hercules, Inc. from 2007 to 2011. A co-inventor on six U.S. patents, Mr. Connors holds a doctorate and a master’s degree in polymer chemistry from Drexel University in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He holds a bachelor’s degree in chemistry from St. Joseph’s University and has completed the Executive Education Program at The Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, both in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He is Six Sigma certified.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Robert Baird
Subsubsection Text: Sigura CEO Robert Baird leads our Pool Solutions division. Robert P. Baird, Jr. has been serving as Chief Executive Officer of Innovative Water Care LLC since August 2019. Mr. Baird has experience leading businesses across 25 categories of consumer goods. He has previously served as the CEO for A.T. CROSS, the luxury pen manufacturer, as well as the CEO at Dorel Sports and Chief Customer Officer at Royal Philips Electronics. Across 207 ----- these positions, Baird succeeded in growing sales, expanding profit margins and increasing shareholder value. His earlier career included leadership positions at top consumer companies including Samsonite, Norelco, General Motors, Scott Paper Company, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Procter & Gamble and General Electric.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Jacques Herber
Subsubsection Text: Jacques Herber has been President, Eurasia for Solenis since July 2022. Mr. Herber is responsible for all sales, marketing and technology operations in Europe and Asia, in addition to global strategy for our paper chemicals business. Mr. Herber was previously Managing Director and CEO of BMS Materials Suisse from 2021 to 2022, Chief Operating Officer of Selecta from 2020 to 2021, Chief Operating Officer of Unilabs from 2019 to 2020, Senior Vice President and General Manager, Latin America and other senior roles at Ecolab from 2007 to 2019. Mr. Herber holds an executive master’s of business administration degree from the London Business School in the United Kingdom and the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois, a master’s degree in business management and a marketing degree from ICN Business School in Nancy, France, and a bachelor’s degree in mechanical engineering from the Université de Metz, France.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsubsection Title: Mary Ann Sigler
Subsubsection Text: Ms. Sigler is Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Platinum. She joined Platinum in 2004 and is responsible for overall accounting, tax, and financial reporting as well as managing strategic planning projects for the firm. Prior to joining Platinum, Ms. Sigler was with Ernst & Young LLP for 25 years where she was a partner. Ms. Sigler has a B.A. in Accounting from California State University Fullerton and a Master’s in Business Taxation from the University of Southern California.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF DIVERSEY
Subsection Title: About Parent and the General Partner
Subsubsection Text: Parent is a Cayman Islands exempted limited partnership that was formed and registered under the Exempted Limited Partnership Act (as amended) (“ELP Act”) on June 29, 2021. A key feature of an exempted limited partnership is that it is not a separate legal person distinct from its partners. Under Cayman Islands law, any rights or property of an exempted limited partnership (whether held in that partnership’s name or by any one or more of its general partners) shall be held or deemed to be held by the general partner (in the case of Parent, this will be the General Partner), and if more than one by the general partners jointly, upon trust as an asset of the exempted limited partnership in accordance with the terms of the partnership agreement. Any debts or obligations incurred by the general partner in the conduct of Parent’s business are the debts and obligations of Parent. In the event that the assets of Parent are inadequate, the General Partner will be liable for all such debts and obligations of Parent. Registration under the ELP Act entails that the exempted limited partnership becomes subject to, and the limited partners therein are afforded the limited liability (subject to the partnership agreement) and other benefits of, the ELP Act. As a general matter, a limited partner of an exempted limited partnership will not be liable for the debts and obligations of the exempted limited partnership save (i) as provided in the partnership agreement or otherwise agreed, (ii) if such limited partner becomes involved in the conduct of the partnership’s business and holds himself out as a general partner to third parties or (iii) if such limited partner is obliged pursuant to section 34 of the ELP Act to return a distribution made to it where the exempted limited partnership is insolvent and the limited partner has actual knowledge of such insolvency at the time of such distribution. The General Partner was incorporated as a Cayman Islands exempted limited company on June 29, 2021. The business of Parent will be conducted by the General Partner. 208 -----
